fields.headline: England go for Eriksson
fields.trailText: The Football Association tonight confirmed they are in talks with Lazio manager Sven-Goran Eriksson with a view to him taking over as England manager.
fields.body:
The Football Association tonight confirmed they are in talks with Lazio manager Sven-Goran Eriksson with a view to him taking over as England manager.

After Italian news agency ANSA reported that the 52-year-old Swede has signed a contract which will begin on July 1, 2001, FA executive director David Davies said: "Meetings have taken place over the past 24 hours with Sven-Goran Eriksson and representatives of his club, Lazio.

"The FA have discussed the possibility of him taking charge of the England team both for key games in the short term, and in a full-time capacity in the long term."

If he accepts the post Eriksson would be the first foreigner to become England manager. He is known to be an admirer of English football and nearly took over as Blackburn manager four years ago.

The Swede guided Lazio to the Serie A title last season and has also coached Roma, Fiorentina, and Sampdoria, while he won the Swedish championship with IFK Gothenburg in 1981 and titles in Portugal with Benfica.

When asked this evening about the reports that he has accepted a five-year contract worth around £2million a year Eriksson would only say: "I have no comment to make."

Although he is known to have been flattered by the FA's offer, Eriksson said only last Tuesday: "I have a contract with Lazio until June 2001 and I am not taking into consideration any offer that does not come from the Biancoceleste (Lazio)."

If Eriksson, who speaks excellent English, does take over in July next year then he will face a baptism of fire in his first competitive game as England manager - they are away to Germany on September 1.

There remain two more qualifiers for World Cup 2002 in Korea and Japan after then; home matches against Albania four days later and finally against Greece on October 6, 2001.

webTitle: Stewart attack starts war of words

fields.headline: Stewart attack starts war of words
fields.trailText: Alec Stewart has risked plunging England's winter tour into a war of words with Pakistan's coach Javed Miandad by condemning the playing conditions experienced so far and questioning the decision to play day-night cricket at all in the host country prior to today's one-day series decider.
fields.body:
Alec Stewart has risked plunging England's winter tour into a war of words with Pakistan's coach Javed Miandad by condemning the playing conditions experienced so far and questioning the decision to play day-night cricket at all in the host country prior to today's one-day series decider.

Heavy dew marred the two opening one-day internationals in Karachi and Lahore, and on Friday the problems were intensified by swarms of small flies. As Pakistan moved towards victory in Lahore there was the unusual sight of England's bowlers running in with their lips pursed to avoid swallowing more insect life.

"They were the most uncomfortable conditions I've played in," said Stewart. "You shouldn't have to play in those conditions. The flies, or midges, whatever they were, were diabolical. There were millions of them. They were everywhere. I'm still tasting them. And if day-night conditions don't work in certain countries then don't play them. They've got a few problems here. The flies, obviously, and there is also a problem with the dew."

But last night England's vice-captain was attacked by Miandad. "These are just excuses," he said. "When we lose we do not make excuses. We had the worst of the conditions in the first match. England played well and we did not play so well. We do not blame the conditions. If you lose a match you should be positive and look forward to the next one."

But some members of the Pakistan camp had more sympathy. The former captain Wasim Akram said: "The flies came because it was so humid that night. There were no flies there at the same time two days before when we practised. But they were everywhere on Friday. Andrew Flintoff came over for dinner and said he didn't want anything to eat because he'd already had a million flies.

"But the dew is a bigger problem. It makes it difficult to play night cricket between August and March. And before that it is too hot to play. If the [Pakistan] Board had asked us we would have told them. But they didn't. They find out for themselves. Then the Board changes and they start all over again."

Even Moin Khan, the current captain, has his doubts about floodlit cricket here. "You should ask the Board why they did it. I think they did so to bring in crowds. But we already have packed stadiums during the day."

At practice last night the Pakistan players could be seen with a bucket of water into which they regularly immersed the ball to simulate the conditions in the second half of these matches. As for the flies, heavy duty repellent will be sprayed to keep them away.

webTitle: Jubilant Jayasuriya rips sorry India to shreds

fields.headline: Jubilant Jayasuriya rips sorry India to shreds
fields.trailText: A rampant Sri Lanka, fired by a near-record innings of 189 for their captain Sanath Jayasuriya, skittled India for 54 all out, the third lowest total in the history of one-day internationals, as they scored a humiliating 245-run victory in yesterday's final of the Champions Trophy triangular tournament in Sharjah.
fields.body:
A rampant Sri Lanka, fired by a near-record innings of 189 for their captain Sanath Jayasuriya, skittled India for 54 all out, the third lowest total in the history of one-day internationals, as they scored a humiliating 245-run victory in yesterday's final of the Champions Trophy triangular tournament in Sharjah.

Sri Lanka's winning margin was the highest ever achieved in one-day internationals, beating the previous best total of 233 runs recorded by Pakistan against Bangladesh in the Asia Cup in Dhaka earlier this year.

India were ripped to shreds by the pace of Chaminda Vaas and the spin of Muthiah Muralitharan as they chased a target of 300. Vaas finished with five for 14 in 9.3 overs while Muralitharan, who took a world record seven for 30 against India in Friday's pool game, closed with three for six in six overs.

The lowest one-day score is 43 by Pakistan against West Indies in Cape Town in 1992-3. The second lowest is 45 made by Canada against England in Manchester in 1979.

Earlier, the left-handed opener Jayasuriya equalled the second highest score in limited overs internationals when he struck a colossal 189 off 161 balls, equalling Viv Richards'score against England at Old Trafford in 1984, to drive his side to 299 for five off 50 overs.

He was just five runs short of the record set by Saeed Anwar of Pakistan against India in 1996-7 when he was finally stumped by the Indian wicketkeeper Vijay Dahiya while going for a big hit off the bowling of the India captain Saurav Ganguly. Fatigue played its part, as he was overcome several times by nausea during his 48-over marathon.

Jayasuriya smashed 21 boundaries including four sixes, and ran up 18 runs apiece in separate overs from the pacemen Ajit Agarkar and Venkatesh Prasad.

However, he received solid support only from Russel Arnold, another left-hander, who came in at 116 for four and contributed 52 not out from 62 balls. At the same time, Arnold reached the personal milestone of 1,000 runs in one-day internationals.

Meanwhile, a 10th international century by Gary Kirsten was the lynchpin in South Africa's five-wicket victory over New Zealand on Saturday, giving the Springboks an unbeatable 3-0 lead with two matches remaining in the six-match series.

As South Africa chased the New Zealand total of 287 for six, Kirsten - who notched up 101 from 107 deliveries including 10 boundaries - and Jacques Kallis, with 93, set a South African record second-wicket partnership of 172. Nicky Boje and Mark Boucher took South Africa to 289 for five with seven balls to spare.

The public hearings into alleged match-fixing by Hansie Cronje , the former South African captain, have been postponed until next year, according to Judge Edwin King, who leads the inquiry. The hearings were suspended in June while further evidence was gathered from Indian investigators.

fields.headline: Wolves ghost eludes Taylor
fields.trailText: Graham Taylor was immortalised as a root vegetable during his turbulent time as England manager but amid such crudities it is easy to lose sight of the fact that at club level, where he has won seven promotions during his time with Lincoln, Aston Villa and Watford, he remains one of the finest English managers of his generation.
fields.body:
Graham Taylor was immortalised as a root vegetable during his turbulent time as England manager but amid such crudities it is easy to lose sight of the fact that at club level, where he has won seven promotions during his time with Lincoln, Aston Villa and Watford, he remains one of the finest English managers of his generation.

It is fitting that on his return to Wolves, where he was sacked in the autumn of 1995 after 18 months in charge, Taylor admitted that his acrimonious departure from Molineux, and not his ignominious exit from Lancaster Gate, was the most painful experience of his managerial career. "Leaving Wolves was the lowest point in my career. It was the first time in my career that I'd been asked to resign," said Taylor.

In fact Taylor's "failure" was to guide Wolves into the play-offs during his only full season at the club - a feat matched only once by the club since his departure.

Moreover, Taylor revealed that, even though his experiences with England had been traumatic, he felt greater torment at leaving Wolves as he feared at the time that he had lost his standing in the English game. "I'm very thankful that Watford gave me an opportunity to get back into the game because leaving Wolves was a low point.

"The reality, whatever people say about being the England manger, is that once you've lost the Wolves situation it can be very, very difficult to stay in the game; that's what pissed me off."

After a first-half performance yesterday that saw his table-topping Watford take a two-goal lead - albeit against the run of play, through Neil Cox, with his fourth goal in six games from right-back, and Tommy Mooney - Taylor looked like laying to rest the demons of his darkest day in management.

But within two minutes of the restart Wolves had halved the deficit from the penalty spot through Kevin Muscat after the half-time substitute Carl Robinson was judged to have been impeded by Darren Ward. This set up a rousing second period and a Tony Dinning volley 15 minutes from time capped a spirited Wolves' fightback.

But, despite remaining the only unbeaten league side in England and enjoying their best start to a season, Taylor is reluctant to make an issue of his side's 14-game sequence or talk of another promotion.

"People turn around and mention unbeaten records but all I know is we're on 36 points from 14 games and, whatever we do in our next league game, those 14 games have no further bearing."

fields.headline: Oxford still waiting for Godot
fields.trailText: Just when Reading looked sunk Tony Rougier parted the waves. In 16 sopping minutes at the end of this game, the Trinidadian international scored two goals, his first for the club, won the man-of-the-match award and rescued all three points for Reading.
fields.byline: Robert Pryce at the Madejski stadium
fields.body:
Just when Reading looked sunk Tony Rougier parted the waves. In 16 sopping minutes at the end of this game, the Trinidadian international scored two goals, his first for the club, won the man-of-the-match award and rescued all three points for Reading.

"I'm very blessed by the grace of the almighty God to be among the elite at this club," he said, after an almost biblical flood had given way to a rainbow over the Thames Valley. "It's a brilliant place to be."

If God really is taking an interest in the Second Division, why is he withholding his infinite mercy from Oxford United? Robert Maxwell saddled them with a debt that grew to £10m. One of his successors left an abandoned half-built stadium. Their centre forward, the ever-willing Steve Anthrobus, has not scored for 10 months.

This defeat leaves Oxford six points adrift at the bottom of the table and lifts their bitterest rivals to the top. The famine must be over soon, surely?

"The club's been a mess for three years now," said their caretaker manager Mike Ford, the latest in a succession of conscientious men to attempt to forge a competitive team out of cast-offs, reclamation projects and Joey Beauchamp. "Things have got to change."

There are some hopeful signs, though even the most devout of Oxford fans is not yet ready to surrender to optimism. Last week it was announced that building work on the new stadium would resume. Today the chairman Firoz Kassam is due to discuss the managerial vacancy with Joe Kinnear. And on Saturday the team showed effort, character and ability enough to reduce their much more expensively assembled opponents to desperate measures.

As the centre of the pitch disappeared under water, Reading flooded forward. Lee Hodges forced Richard Knight into a flying save and then, from the consequent corner, lured him into a miscalculation that allowed Rougier to head his first and level the scores at 3-3.

Then, with four minutes left, Andy Linighan, the steadiest of Oxford's defenders, attempted a volleyed clearance that fell at Rougier's feet. The goal was a gift and elevated Reading to the top of the table, above Walsall and Brett Angell. But it was probably not quite divine.

fields.headline: Hughes takes the strain
fields.trailText: Waiting for a home win at Huddersfield must be rather like waiting for a Great North Eastern train; you know one will turn up eventually but soon learn not to expect it in the next 90 minutes.
fields.byline: Mark Tallentire at the McAlpine stadium
fields.body:
Waiting for a home win at Huddersfield must be rather like waiting for a Great North Eastern train; you know one will turn up eventually but soon learn not to expect it in the next 90 minutes.

Huddersfield's fans were again left disappointed on Saturday, as they have been since March when Crewe were the visitors. As they begin to get used to life at the bottom some must have wondered what might have been if the former manager Steve Bruce had succeeded in his efforts to sign his old Manchester United team-mate Mark Hughes, Blackburn's new No9.

Hughes held the ball up in a manner which Huddersfield could only contemplate, often pulling his marker Chris Lucketti, literally and figuratively, out of position and always giving his team-mates options.

"A defender would not treat him like that at Ewood Park and be on the pitch for long," said the Blackburn manager Graeme Souness, who was deadly serious in suggesting that the 37-year-old Wales manager needs to be protected by referees.

"If you don't try and match him he will always be the winner," was the Huddersfield caretaker Lou Macari's verdict, and in that respect his whole team are to be commended for their application and effort in attempting to match a technically superior Blackburn side in an often compelling game.

The goal, when it came, was devastatingly simple, possibly illegal and all Norwegian, Henning Berg launching a big header in the general direction of Egil Ostenstad lurking outside the area. After a tussle which finished with Steve Jenkins on the floor he advanced, drew Nico Vaesen and sidefooted a low shot between the keeper and his left-hand post.

"He must have had the wrong studs in and slipped," said Ostenstad, who is revelling in the extra freedom he is finding playing alongside Hughes. "He has done well for us, holding the ball up. It takes the pressure off me and lets me play a bit."

It all left Macari, whose four-match spell in charge has produced one point, to reflect: "It was one of those [decisions] that is difficult to make. But nine out of 10 times the referee would have given a foul against Ostenstad for leaning into him but unfortunately for us this was that time when he didn't."

Blackburn, for whom this was a fourth consecutive win, had begun like a team in a hurry and only Vaesen kept the hosts in it during the first 20 minutes when Ostenstad, Damien Johnson, Garry Flitcroft and David Dunn went close.

But they crept back into the game as Scott Sellars had a sweet free-kick saved by John Filan before Ben Thornley hit an upright from the edge of the box in first-half injury- time. That was as near as they were to get, although Thornley and Rob Kozluck went close towards the end of the match.

Now all that remains is for the chairman Barry Rubery to name a new manager before Saturday's visit to Fulham, and Macari is on a shortlist of three.

"I would hate to think I am being judged on 90 minutes or a couple of matches," he said. "They [the board] know what people are capable of and everybody knows what we have to do: get away from the bottom."

fields.headline: Grimsby gifted by misses
fields.trailText: Grimsby Town, offered a first-half reprieve by the profligate finishing of Lee Hughes, capitalised with a stylish recovery that earned Lennie Lawrence's side their fourth win in five games.
fields.body:
Grimsby Town, offered a first-half reprieve by the profligate finishing of Lee Hughes, capitalised with a stylish recovery that earned Lennie Lawrence's side their fourth win in five games.

Grimsby's win - the only home victory in the First Division this weekend - saw them leap five places while West Brom passed up the opportunity to move into the top four.

But how different it could have been if Hughes, normally so reliable in front of goal, had not wasted half of the 12 chances Albion created before the interval.

Grimsby's underrated keeper Danny Coyne reacted particularly well to frustrate Hughes on two occasions, but Albion's manager Gary Megson was justifiably upset at their failure to make their domination count.

"We had a dozen chances and didn't take any of them. That's very poor at this level," said Megson. "I know their keeper made some good saves, but our finishing wasn't too clever."

The second half provided a stark contrast, with Albion creating just one opening - for Hughes of course - while Grimsby took control.

They took the lead in the 59th minute when Tony Gallimore, under pressure from Hughes, hooked a clearance beyond an advancing Albion defence and left Bradley Allen clear to lob over keeper Brian Jensen.

Grimsby could have scored again through Paul Groves and John McDermott before on-loan David Nielsen sealed Albion's second defeat in 13 games with a crisp 84th-minute volley.

Megson said: "The manner in which we lost is disappointing. We've thrown it away, but we are still fifth from top - it's not an absolute calamity."

Even Lawrence accepted that Grimsby rode their luck in the first half. He said: "Albion are a difficult side to play against and we were fortunate to be level at half-time, but Danny Coyne showed that he's in impressive form. To use a familiar phrase, it was a game of two halves."

fields.bodyText: Grimsby Town, offered a first-half reprieve by the profligate finishing of Lee Hughes, capitalised with a stylish recovery that earned Lennie Lawrence's side their fourth win in five games. Grimsby's win - the only home victory in the First Division this weekend - saw them leap five places while West Brom passed up the opportunity to move into the top four. But how different it could have been if Hughes, normally so reliable in front of goal, had not wasted half of the 12 chances Albion created before the interval. Grimsby's underrated keeper Danny Coyne reacted particularly well to frustrate Hughes on two occasions, but Albion's manager Gary Megson was justifiably upset at their failure to make their domination count. "We had a dozen chances and didn't take any of them. That's very poor at this level," said Megson. "I know their keeper made some good saves, but our finishing wasn't too clever." The second half provided a stark contrast, with Albion creating just one opening - for Hughes of course - while Grimsby took control. webTitle: Fulham stick in the mud as Owls learn to fly

fields.headline: Fulham stick in the mud as Owls learn to fly
fields.trailText: Ten days ago this result would have seemed impossible. Fulham supporters had been ticking off the matches in anticipation of celebrating a record-breaking win at Hillsborough; Wednesday fans were considering other ways to spend Saturday afternoon.
fields.body:
Ten days ago this result would have seemed impossible. Fulham supporters had been ticking off the matches in anticipation of celebrating a record-breaking win at Hillsborough; Wednesday fans were considering other ways to spend Saturday afternoon.

What a transformation. Fulham, after 11 straight wins, have not won in three, while in the same period Wednesday, after eight consecutive defeats, have not lost. As Paul Jewell, the Wednesday manager, joked afterwards: "That's three on the bounce for us and Fulham are in free-fall."

His side could not have timed their mini-revival better. They are currently languishing 12 points behind their city rivals United but in two days they have the chance to regain a portion of local bragging rights when they take on Neil Warnock's side in the Worthington Cup, the first Sheffield derby for 6 years.

The Owls supporters at least now know their team will put up a fight. Few expected them to recover on Saturday in the final 20 minutes from 2-1 and a man down against one of the division's high-flyers.

"The supporters are just desperate for these players to go out there, cross the white line and give everything they've got for the shirt. They'll come as long as they see people trying," Jewell said.

He, in turn, expects some sympathy from the fans. "It takes time to get a team playing the way you want, to get a spirit in the camp that you want and we're on the right road. We've got a lot of injuries, a lot of young players and no money, but you make do with the best of what you've got. I said when I first came that it's not a quick-fix job."

Jewell can only dream of Fulham's riches but, while Jean Tigana's side has made a tremendous start, the concern that their attractive style may come unstuck as pitches become churned up has not been assuaged in the past week.

On Saturday their passing was crisp throughout but, with the not insurmountable presence of Kevin Pressman in their opponents' goal, they were guilty of over elaboration. Shoot on sight is not in Tigana's coaching manual.

It was of little surprise then that Wednesday's three goals all came from free-kicks while Fulham's involved rather more subtlety. Gerald Sibon responded to the rare sound of cheers rather than boos by crafting and scoring Wednesday's first. His free-kick found Owen Morrison on the left wing and the cross was met with a firm Sibon header.

Fulham, though, led within 10 minutes of the interval. First Louis Saha headed them level, then Barry Hayles skipped through four challenges and toe-poked home.

Wednesday responded with aggression. Alan Quinn made two crude tackles on John Collins and was rightly sent off. Unperturbed, the Owls equalised when Ashley Westwood headed a free-kick to Morrison, who bundled the ball over the line.

Their character was further tested when Luis Boa Morte's shot was deflected into the goal by Andy Melville but still there was time for one last twist when Westwood headed a goal in injury-time.

Collins said afterwards that the draw felt like a defeat; Wednesday's fans celebrated a moral victory. They will be hoping for many more sensations like this in days to come.

fields.headline: Collymore makes his mark
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore may have frequented more last-chance saloons than Wyatt Earp but after yesterday maybe, just maybe, the nomadic centre-forward should not be perceived as a cowboy after all.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore may have frequented more last-chance saloons than Wyatt Earp but after yesterday maybe, just maybe, the nomadic centre-forward should not be perceived as a cowboy after all.

With patience running out at Valley Parade, Collymore did his best to earn Chris Hutchings a stay of execution here with the type of goal that, before the tantrums, the Priory clinic and everything else that has sullied his career, was once regarded as his forte.

Collymore being Collymore, things have a habit of going awry, of course. His manic celebrations in front of the Leeds supporters will not have gone down well with the powers that be at Lancaster Gate. But, of more consequence to his new employers, just as his acrobatic goal seemed destined to secure their first victory since beating Chelsea on August 22, a rare win bonus was denied them by Mark Viduka's equaliser 11 minutes from time. The wait goes on.

Even so, Collymore's goal and a return to the old-fashioned Bradford ways of rolled-up sleeves and perspiration should allow Hutchings not to break out in a cold sweat every time his telephone rings over the next few days.

Judging by the comments of Geoffrey Richmond last week, had Bradford lost this soggy Yorkshire derby it would have been difficult to envisage any other situation than Hutchings being removed from office by his trigger-happy chairman. As it was, he can breathe a little easier, for now at least.

"It has been a long week but that performance says it all," said Hutchings. "It was a great team display. The players gave everything for Bradford and everything for me and Stan was fantastic. All he wants to do is concentrate on his football, forget about everything else and do his best for this club."

Collymore's signing may have carried more than a hint of desperation given the inevitable baggage he brings with him but those who believe his partnership with Benito Carbone will be to a relegation fight what Pepsi and Shirley were to popular music will have a good portion of humble pie facing them this morning.

Initially Collymore looked out of shape and Carbone out of luck but when they finally connected after 20 minutes the end product was exemplary, the timing exquisite.

Carbone can claim an assist with his right-wing cross but the ball was still falling behind Collymore when he contorted his body and produced an overhead kick of stunning power and precision into the bottom corner of Paul Robinson's net. Few would have had the audacity to try such a shot, even fewer would have pulled it off.

"It was a fantastic goal," said Hutchings. "Stan's missed a lot of training over the last few weeks so it was a gamble to play him but he gave me everything he'd got. I had to take him off after 70 minutes because he was knackered but in that time he showed what a great player he can be."

Quite why Collymore decided to stain the moment by crudely baiting Leeds's travelling fans is another matter entirely. "I think he was just delighted with the goal," mumbled Hutchings, his explanation as watery as the Valley Parade pitch. The FA's compliance officer Graham Bean was among the crowd and, even though the referee Stephen Lodge took no action, Collymore's mail this week is likely to include an invitation from Lancaster Gate to explain his actions. They certainly have his address.

That Bradford preserved their lead for so long owed much to their goalkeeper Matt Clarke who was in defiant form all afternoon along with Ian Nolan who, twice in the first half, dug out goal-line clearances to deny Danny Hay and Dominic Matteo.

Leeds had finished the opening period showing signs that they were adapting better to the rainy conditions and the second half was a story of almost unremitting pressure from O'Leary's depleted team.

Collymore continued to be a threat until being withdrawn but Bradford's attacks were becoming few and far between and such was the level of activity around the Bradford penalty area there was an air of inevitability about Viduka's equaliser, the Australian striker jumping unchallenged to clip a neat header beyond Clarke from Matteo's cross.

An indignant O'Leary also claimed that Leeds should have had a penalty when Alan Smith was felled by Peter Atherton although television pictures showed the Bradford defender got the slightest of touches on the ball.

As it is, Bradford remain second from bottom while Leeds are now nine points adrift of Manchester United and Arsenal.

"I'm not a genius and my players are not rocket scientists," said O'Leary.

"We've been devastated by injuries and there was no way we could keep up with the two biggest and best clubs around. We just have to dig in and hopefully when we have players coming back at Christmas we won't be too far off."

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Chesterfield had their lead at the top of the division cut to five points after a 2-2 draw with Cardiff, although the Spireites were glad to get a point after going two down.
fields.body:
Chesterfield had their lead at the top of the division cut to five points after a 2-2 draw with Cardiff, although the Spireites were glad to get a point after going two down.

Kevin Evans and Jason Bowen put the Bluebirds in front before Ryan Williams pulled one back and Luke Beckett levelled in the 86th minute.

Brighton and Rochdale both took advantage, winning away from home at Darlington and Exeter respectively. It was Rochdale's first win at St James' Park in 16 visits, and extended their unbeaten run to six games.

Behind the top three, Leyton Orient lost 2-1 to Hartlepool and Cheltenham slipped up against in-form Blackpool, for whom John Murphy's 11th goal of the season after only seven minutes clinched a fourth successive win.

The performance of the day, though, came at Underhill where Barnet , three goals down after 26 minutes, beat Lincoln 4-3.

At the bottom of the table Halifax ended a run of five straight defeats with a 0-0 draw at Macclesfield , while Carlisle lost 2-1 to Scunthorpe thanks to Lee Hodges' controversial first-half penalty.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: It took just 63 seconds for Brentford's Andy Scott to score the day's fastest goal and send top-of-the-table Walsall on their way to a second defeat in eight days.
fields.body:
It took just 63 seconds for Brentford's Andy Scott to score the day's fastest goal and send top-of-the-table Walsall on their way to a second defeat in eight days.

The rest of the top five all won, both Wigan and Rotherham by virtue of a solitary goal - the Latics at home to Bury and Rotherham at Sixfields, inflicting Northampton's first home defeat this season.

Rotherham's win came despite being reduced to 10 men after just 11 minutes when Guy Branston picked up a second booking.

After Stewart Talbot's winner for the visitors, the Cobblers manager Kevin Wilson said: "I look back almost 12 months to the day when Rotherham did the same and won 1-0. It is like they have got a curse on me."

Three goals in 20 first-half minutes saw Millwall set up an unassailable lead over Cambridge at the New Den. Jonas Axeldal's reply was not enough to stop United slipping to their third successive defeat.

Darren Ferguson's 87th-minute winner completed an unlikely comeback for Wrexham, who had been trailing 3-0 at Luton Town. Goals from Mark Allot and Lee Duxbury gave Oldham a much needed 2-0 win at Bristol Rovers.

A Danny Invincible brace was not enough to earn Swindon a point at Meadow Lane as David Joseph's late penalty gave Notts County a 3-2 win.

Tony Thorpe bagged a brace as Bristol City extended their undefeated run to nine games with a 2-1 win at Adams Park over Wycombe. Michael Cummins got the only goal as Port Vale won 1-0 at Swansea , who lost for the third successive game.

Early goals for Bjarni Gudjonsson and James O'Connor sent Stoke to a 2-1 win over struggling Bournemouth while Andy Clarke's 89th-minute strike secured a 3-1 win for Peterborough over Colchester.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Birmingham City spurned a chance to close the gap on Watford and Fulham at the top when they missed a penalty in a 1-1 draw at Portsmouth. Behind to Lee Bradbury's goal at half-time, City's penalty came a minute after the break when Andy Johnson was brought down by Linvoy Primus, but Martin Grainger's effort was touched on to the bar by goalkeeper Russell Hoult. The substitute Dele Adebola scored City's goal two minutes later but they could do no more in a game played out in storm-force winds and driving rain.

Behind to Lee Bradbury's goal at half-time, City's penalty came a minute after the break when Andy Johnson was brought down by Linvoy Primus, but Martin Grainger's effort was touched on to the bar by goalkeeper Russell Hoult. The substitute Dele Adebola scored City's goal two minutes later but they could do no more in a game played out in storm-force winds and driving rain.

Bolton, now without a win in five games, looked anything but promotion hopefuls as lowly Crystal Palace matched them in a 3-3 draw.

Gudni Bergsson tapped in on 20 minutes but Palace hit back when Dougie Freedman headed home before half-time. Then two goals in two minutes from Michael Ricketts and Per Frandsen appeared to have secured the points before Freedman added his second with three minutes to go. Clinton Morrison equalised deep into injury time.

Nottingham Forest ground out a 2-1 win at Stockport after Jack Lester's late double overhauled Christian Edwards' own-goal. "If you're going to get into the play-offs, no disrespect to Stockport, you have got to come to places like this and take three points, and thankfully we did that," said the Forest manager David Platt.

Wimbledon and Sheffield United stay marooned in mid-table after a goalless draw while Gillingham extended their time without a goal to 362 minutes in four games as Crewe won 1-0 at Priestfield. Paul Tait and Colin Little combined well for the latter's decisive goal.

Two struggling sides produced a thriller as QPR battled back to earn a point at Tranmere . Jason Koumas headed home to give Tranmere a second-half lead before Karl Connolly's superb free-kick rescued a point for the visitors in the 83rd minute.

webTitle: Cascarino claims he was ineligible for Ireland

fields.headline: Cascarino claims he was ineligible for Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Cascarino's claims that he was ineligible to play for the Republic of Ireland could lead to him losing the record-breaking 88 caps that he won for his country, the Football Association of Ireland warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Tony Cascarino's claims that he was ineligible to play for the Republic of Ireland could lead to him losing the record-breaking 88 caps that he won for his country, the Football Association of Ireland warned yesterday.

The FAI is to investigate Cascarino's revelation that the Irish grandfather who allowed him to be eligible to play for his country was not a blood relative. The striker said that his mother told him in 1996 that she was adopted and that his "grandfather" was, therefore, not her natural father.

Cascarino, who last played for Ireland against Turkey last November, won a further 24 caps for his country after his mother's bombshell. He also shared a lucrative testimonial with Steve Staunton in a match against Liverpool in Dublin in May.

Cascarino makes the claims in a book Full Time: The Secret Life of Tony Cascarino, and the FAI's president Bernard O'Byrne criticised the timing. "It is sad that Tony did not learn about all these things until much later in life," he said. "But it is also sad if some of these facts are now being revealed to promote a book."

Lazio's chairman Sergio Cragnotti said yesterday that Sven-Goran Eriksson, who the Football Association are expected to approach this week about the England manager's job, had not yet signed an extension to his contract.

"I will do everything I can to prevent Eriksson going to England," said Cragnotti. "He has not yet signed an extension to his contract which runs out on June 30 2001. But I've already spoken with Sven-Goran Eriksson about the renewal of his contract and we have agreed on everything and made an appointment for before Christmas to put pen to paper."

Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, has warned Brazil that they could be banned from international competitions, including the 2002 World Cup, because of political interference in the domestic game.

Brazil's congress has launched two inquiries to investigate allegations of corruption, the financial difficulties afflicting many clubs and the exodus of top players abroad. "If we consider that there has been outside control of football, the situation is clear: Brazil will be suspended from all international activities," Blatter said.

Sheffield, the oldest club in the world, failed to reach the first round of the FA Cup on Saturday when they were beaten 5-1 by Northwich Victoria. In the draw for the first round, the Second Division strugglers Luton face a tricky tie against Rushden & Diamonds, who are second in the Conference, the leaders of which, Yeovil, will play Colchester if they get past Horsham.

Japan won the Asian Cup yesterday by beating the defending champions Saudi Arabia, who included the Wolves striker Sami al-Jaber, 1-0 with a goal from Shigeyoshi Mochizuki.

But I've already spoken with Sven-Goran Eriksson about the renewal of his contract and we have agreed on everything and made an appointment for before Christmas to put pen to paper." Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, has warned Brazil that they could be banned from international competitions, including the 2002 World Cup, because of political interference in the domestic game. Brazil's congress has launched two inquiries to investigate allegations of corruption, the financial difficulties afflicting many clubs and the exodus of top players abroad. "If we consider that there has been outside control of football, the situation is clear: Brazil will be suspended from all international activities," Blatter said. Sheffield, the oldest club in the world, failed to reach the first round of the FA Cup on Saturday when they were beaten 5-1 by Northwich Victoria. In the draw for the first round, the Second Division strugglers Luton face a tricky tie against Rushden & Diamonds, who are second in the Conference, the leaders of which, Yeovil, will play Colchester if they get past Horsham. Japan won the Asian Cup yesterday by beating the defending champions Saudi Arabia, who included the Wolves striker Sami al-Jaber, 1-0 with a goal from Shigeyoshi Mochizuki.

webTitle: West Ham give thanks as luck turns

fields.headline: West Ham give thanks as luck turns
fields.trailText: There is something to be said for the fog over the transfer system, due to clear tomorrow. Bryan Robson apart, managers who might normally buy their way out of bother have been working with what they have instead of casting around the world. Coaches may actually be coaching.
fields.body:
There is something to be said for the fog over the transfer system, due to clear tomorrow. Bryan Robson apart, managers who might normally buy their way out of bother have been working with what they have instead of casting around the world. Coaches may actually be coaching.

Both defences at Upton Park were depleted to the limit. West Ham welcomed back Ian Pearce after a 15-month cruciate absence and moved Rio Ferdinand to the centre. Harry Redknapp thinks England should be built about him. Here was a chance to judge, against the man about whom Kevin Keegan built England's Euro 2000 campaign.

Bobby Robson, suffering the ill effects of Keegan's neglect of Newcastle's reserves, is holding fire on two defenders, the Argentine Pablo Paz and PSV Eindhoven's Ernst Faber. On Saturday, with only two regular defenders fit, he played the midfielder Robert Lee as sweeper for the first time.

Lee, at 34, was terrific, showing what good instruction, discipline and intelligence can do. "He played like Beckenbauer," said Robson, possibly believing himself. Ferdinand, at 21, was not a patch in distribution or defence, where he tends toward distraction. A future around Ferdinand looks as ill-fated as the recent past around Alan Shearer.

A short-term future with Robson was understandably attractive to the Football Association. He knows how to get players to play as he wants. The Chilean Clarence Acuna fitted in well beside Kieron Dyer in a midfield that got the better of West Ham's by recognising the advantage in the wind of keeping the ball on the ground. But Shearer needed classier support than Lomana Lua-Lua.

Lua-Lua's most significant contribution was the tackle that led to Joe Cole's departure. Cole was beginning to buzz and burst forward. His loss might have been fatal for West Ham. But in four minutes his replacement Davor Suker slipped a pass through for Frédéric Kanouté to blast in. For once Aaron Hughes, not Alain Goma, was marking the Frenchman.

Redknapp's faith in Kanouté is touching if not touched. Paolo di Canio, too, is disappointing at present, going a twist too far and frustrating himself and fans alike. At the end he begged for a decision but the referee had been listening to the Prime Minister.

Redknapp admits he leaves his front men to play off the cuff. He almost admitted he did as little with the rest, which might explain Ferdinand's prodigious stagnation. All he has to tell the youngsters, he says, is to look at Stuart Pearce. "Where do you find a man of that age [38] playing with that enthusiasm [shared by the manager], that will? He's got the body of a 20-year-old. I love having him around the place. He's a special character and great example."

Early tackles on Shearer and Dyer were a statement of intent; late headers carried it through: his last club would not pass. They are without a win in London in 20 visits. West Ham have their first at home for half a year. "We are out of the relegation zone," said the PA. "Drive home with pride." Thanksgiving might have been more apt.

fields.headline: Taylor busy England dreaming
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor, England's manager of the month, admits that when he first became a coach, he would drive his wife mad by leaving hundreds of envelopes around the house with imaginary formations scribbled on the back of them.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor, England's manager of the month, admits that when he first became a coach, he would drive his wife mad by leaving hundreds of envelopes around the house with imaginary formations scribbled on the back of them.

So though he claims that his mind is concentrated 100% on Leicester's next game (home to Crystal Palace in the fourth round of the Worthington Cup on Wednesday), one suspects that anyone bothered enough to take a close look through the Filbert Street bins would find several possible England line-ups for the game against Italy on November 15.

If Taylor committed any new thoughts about England to the back of an envelope over the weekend, he could have utilised the space on the front usually occupied by a stamp to record the exciting moments of this game.

Apart from the three excellent goals, there were none. And the eclectic mix of scorers, none of whom can be named in the national squad by Taylor on Thursday week, highlights the problems of the England manager.

The Irishman Rory Delap, switched from full-back to striker by his manager Jim Smith to keep him from the area where he might have done most damage - the Derby defence - scored the first with a crisp shot from the edge of the box in the 13th minute.

Muzzy Izzet, who might have delayed his decision to renounce England for Turkey had he known Taylor was going to get the job, equalised with a sweet right-foot shot. And Arnar Gunnlaugsson, showing the coolness you would expect of a man from Iceland, shimmied inside a couple of makeshift challenges before curling home the winner with his left foot.

It was his first touch after replacing Steve Guppy in the 74th minute and were he not such a modest individual, Taylor might have held it up as an example that he has nothing to declare but his likeness to Oscar Wilde.

Instead, he confessed to having picked the mind of former England Under-21 colleague Dave Sexton, saying: "He taught me that there is more than one way to win a game and it can be a good idea to bring on a player with different qualities. Arnie can beat people quickly and easily."

If only Howard Wilkinson had such an open mind, England might have done better than draw in Finland in their World Cup qualifier a fortnight ago.

The Derby manager Jim Smith has no such pleasant diversion from the task of trying to lift, or rather excavate, the fortunes of the only team in the country without a win.

Even his attempt to bring the ex-Derby hero Colin Todd back as coach has descended into a grubby row with Swindon Town over compensation. "It's ridiculous," said Smith, "the whole thing is now in the hands of the lawyers."

When m'learned friends have finished discussing the finer legal points of that one, perhaps they could turn their minds to whether Derby's defenders could be charged for the criminal negligence that has left their side marooned at the foot of the Premiership.

webTitle: Strachan undone by the writing on a Brazilian wall

fields.headline: Strachan undone by the writing on a Brazilian wall
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan must have left Wearmouth with a thumping migraine having spent 90 minutes hammering his head against a brick wall. His side played the more impressive football, scored a legitimate goal which was ruled out, and then had their young goalkeeper impeded, beaten and booked early in the second half.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan must have left Wearmouth with a thumping migraine having spent 90 minutes hammering his head against a brick wall. His side played the more impressive football, scored a legitimate goal which was ruled out, and then had their young goalkeeper impeded, beaten and booked early in the second half.

"The Wall" in this case was Emerson Thome, the £4.5m record signing from Chelsea who earned the nickname during his days shoring up the Benfica back line. The Brazilian's header from a Julio Arca corner extended the Black Cats' unbeaten run to eight; his defensive strength has contributed to almost seven hours without a goal conceded.

"I don't take all the credit," he said. "It was rainy and windy and we didn't play the best game in the world, but the team worked really hard. I was pleased the referee missed their goal, but I didn't see anyone blocked on mine."

Strachan and his opposite number Peter Reid disagreed. John Aloisi wriggled into space after 32 minutes and struck a low cross-shot towards Sunderland's far post which was converted by Craig Bellamy. Although the linesman's flag cut short the celebrations, Reid later conceded that the Welshman was at least two yards behind the last defender when the ball was played.

"Peter knows his stuff and clearly analyses games well," said Strachan, although his reaction to the disallowed goal paled into insignificance when Kevin Phillips appeared to block his 19-year-old goalkeeper Chris Kirkland as Thome headed the winner.

Kirkland, on his third senior start, has had an unhappy baptism. Sent off against Chelsea seven days earlier, he was booked for protesting on Saturday. "But he is not a petulant goalkeeper," insisted Strachan. "He made the referee aware that he was getting blocked at set-pieces and asked him to watch out particularly at corner-kicks. Mr Wiley said he would, but when Chris complained about the goal the referee just said he'd missed that one." It was Sunderland's first corner of the game.

Coventry continued to play the more incisive football and the final whistle was greeted with as much grumbling as celebration among the home supporters. Reid said: "I told the lads before the game just to concentrate on keeping a clean sheet and we might nick one at a set-piece."

Reid's problem is that it is now more than seven hours since the Wearsiders scored from open play in the Premiership. "That does concern me," he added. "We can be more fluent and we need to improve in the final third, but it's not happening at the moment. But if I was in Gordon's shoes I'd feel hard done by. Coventry deserved something out of the game. I thought we were fortunate."

fields.headline: Sheringham's best comes of age
fields.trailText: "Twenty-four hours later, as [I was] enjoying a quiet cup of tea, the office door burst open and Steve booted the ball into the room, sending it ricocheting off the wall so violently that it smashed the fluorescent light. 'There's your effing ball,' he said and marched off."
fields.body:
"Twenty-four hours later, as [I was] enjoying a quiet cup of tea, the office door burst open and Steve booted the ball into the room, sending it ricocheting off the wall so violently that it smashed the fluorescent light. 'There's your effing ball,' he said and marched off."

That was what happened when Sir Alex Ferguson tried to deny Steve Archibald the match ball after a hat-trick in his days at Aberdeen. Should he try to do the same to Teddy Sheringham then he had better get his pen out for an update of Managing My Life: My Autobiography, for this is a 34-year-old striker with a burning point to prove. Six months ago it seemed that Sheringham was out the door. Manchester United were willing to pay £19m for the young PSV Eindhoven striker Ruud van Nistelrooy and Sheringham was the man to make way.

How quickly things have changed. Van Nistelrooy's knee collapsed, Sheringham signed a new one-year deal worth £1.2m, and now the talk is not just of a contract extension but even a place in England's starting line-up for the match against Italy on November 15. "He's arguably in the greatest form of his career," Mark Lawrenson said on Match of the Day.

Glenn Hoddle had no doubts. "He still has a lot to offer his club and his country," the Southampton manager emphasised, and as if to confirm his opinion, the cameras later picked out Steve McClaren, the United and now England coach, making studious notes on the sidelines.

Hoddle, a former England coach himself, suggested that not only was Sheringham in top form, he was in fact getting better because, first, he had never depended on pace, and, second, he was gathering greater experience.

"A player who relies on pace may not be able to play at this level at his age but as he never relied on his pace it means he is still as good as ever," he said. "I played until I was 38 and a set of curtains opens in your mind when you are older and you begin to read the game better."

Having displaced Dwight Yorke at United as the partner for Andy Cole, Sheringham - with nine goals now in United's 11 league games - was already in the running for a new contract.

"I don't see why we can't do it," Ferguson said. "His new contract has given him some assurance that he's wanted here. He made the point that he's not been the No1 choice over the years but he's started the season well and he's never looked back." Admittedly, an easily cowed Southampton were never going to be the greatest test of a striker's ability, but Sheringham was able to demonstrate that the guile, skill, timing and positional sense needed to unlock international defences were well within his repertoire, as was the necessary understanding with England's current main striker Cole.

After Cole had softened up the visitors with a shot that squirmed through the hands of Paul Jones in an odd reprise of Massimo Taibi's howler in this fixture last season, Sheringham set his mind to the task in hand.

His first goal was typically intelligent, a Cantona-like chip over the goalkeeper from the left of the area. The second was a wafted shot into the top corner of the net and the third saw him arrive with perfect timing to whip the ball off Cole's feet and into Jones' bottom left-hand corner.

"That is my first hat-trick for Man United and hopefully I can get some more," he said. "Things are going well. We're top of the league, winning games and a couple of goals are going in as well, so things are fine."

Cole's header then rounded things off and the warm congratulations from his partner suggested that the icy relationship between them was at least thawing.

Ferguson added a decent touch of his own by substituting the pair in the 74th minute, allowing them both a standing ovation.

fields.headline: Rotating Henry keeps forward momentum
fields.trailText: Not long after Thierry Henry had stormed off in anger at being substituted against Sparta Prague last week, Arsène Wenger sought the striker out. "The game was won," Arsenal's manager told him, "and the main match is against Manchester City. We need you then."
fields.body:
Not long after Thierry Henry had stormed off in anger at being substituted against Sparta Prague last week, Arsène Wenger sought the striker out. "The game was won," Arsenal's manager told him, "and the main match is against Manchester City. We need you then."

Henry responded that he understood. If Arsenal's players are hardly jigging with delight at being rested or taken off, they realise that without those frustrations they would not be flying, matching Manchester United point for point, 5-0 for 5-0 and cruising in Europe.

"They're not happy," Wenger admitted, "but I feel, and they feel as well, that if we had played with the same 11 in the Champions League and the Premiership we could not have had the same results." Gianluca Vialli clearly ended up with the wrong squad.

Henry was certainly outstanding here, his pace, aggression and movement giving him two goals and a role in the others. It is the forwards Wenger likes to rotate above all and the introduction of Sylvain Wiltord injected a freshness and urgency which blew away a tiring, 10-man City. But the enforced rests have gone deeper than that.

"It's true to say that a couple of years back if we didn't have our first 11 out we tended to struggle a little bit," said Lee Dixon, a victim - or rather beneficiary - of the system this season. "But I think that the big difference is that the full depth of the squad is being used now and so more of the players are getting more opportunities to play more regularly.

"I think we've now caught up with Manchester United in the use of the squad and the results that follow."

These days, of course, Arsenal have the depth required. Two Octobers ago Luis Boa Morte, Christopher Wreh and Alberto Mendez were coming off the bench. On Saturday it was Wiltord, Fredrik Ljungberg and Dixon, with Nwankwo Kanu not even called upon.

And much as a Champions League exit might seem an advantage domestically, the reality is different. Three games a week makes it easier for Wenger to keep people not only contented but in peak condition.

Moreover, whereas European failure in the past two seasons inflicted a psychological blow which, Wenger says, made it hard to rediscover the "confidence and motivation you need to fight for the Premiership", now Arsenal feel invincible. With Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars gone, there is also a new spirit in the squad.

The scoreline was given a lopsided look by the dismissal of Danny Tiatto late in the first half. But Joe Royle's anger at the officials - he felt Tiatto's first booking was "nonsense", Henry should have gone for kicking Spencer Prior and two goals ought to have been disallowed - could not hide the fact that City were always second best.

Only several good saves by Nicky Weaver kept the score down as Arsenal flexed their attacking muscles. "I have never played against that many good strikers," Weaver said. "They have so much pace, and the first touch and movement is unbelievable. They have midfielders coming on, full-backs coming wide. They come at you from all angles."

Ashley Cole set Arsenal on their way from 25 yards after Tiatto had fouled Henry and seen red, Dennis Bergkamp curled in No2 and after Shaun Goater had suggested it should be Feed the Donkey rather than Feed the Goat by missing from two yards, Wiltord inspired a stylish finish.

Finally approaching his best after missing several weeks of training because of his dispute with Bordeaux, he was put in by Henry and twice returned the compliment. That he may not start next week is why opponents should worry.

But Joe Royle's anger at the officials - he felt Tiatto's first booking was "nonsense", Henry should have gone for kicking Spencer Prior and two goals ought to have been disallowed - could not hide the fact that City were always second best. Only several good saves by Nicky Weaver kept the score down as Arsenal flexed their attacking muscles. "I have never played against that many good strikers," Weaver said. "They have so much pace, and the first touch and movement is unbelievable. They have midfielders coming on, full-backs coming wide. They come at you from all angles." Ashley Cole set Arsenal on their way from 25 yards after Tiatto had fouled Henry and seen red, Dennis Bergkamp curled in No2 and after Shaun Goater had suggested it should be Feed the Donkey rather than Feed the Goat by missing from two yards, Wiltord inspired a stylish finish. Finally approaching his best after missing several weeks of training because of his dispute with Bordeaux, he was put in by Henry and twice returned the compliment. That he may not start next week is why opponents should worry.

webTitle: Ipswich are no laughing matter on the fringe

fields.headline: Ipswich are no laughing matter on the fringe
fields.trailText: For those who may still doubt the ability of Ipswich to stay in the Premiership, their manager George Burley has a simple response: "Come and watch us play, then make your minds up."
fields.body:
For those who may still doubt the ability of Ipswich to stay in the Premiership, their manager George Burley has a simple response: "Come and watch us play, then make your minds up."

At present it is an invitation worth accepting. Away from the major productions at Old Trafford and Highbury and wannabes like Liverpool, Chelsea and Leeds, Ipswich are providing fringe theatre of a beguiling quality.

Burley's team pass the ball instinctively well and, to a man, work tirelessly to win it back. Their football is perceptive and imaginative and does not rely on one or two players to make it tick.

In the Premiership playing prettily will not in itself guarantee survival. Ipswich are prospering because so far they have also managed to live with the extra pace and power that winning promotion from the First Division inevitably demands.

They are, moreover, a predominantly homegrown team. Including substitutes, nine of those who defeated Middlesbrough on Saturday to lift the club to fifth place were born in England.

The performance typified a team in form and enjoying it. "We could have tried to survive by getting nine men back behind the ball and humping it forward," he explained, "but that was never going to be our game. We're going to keep doing what we're good at. We encourage people to play."

Ipswich are undefeated in six league matches and, on form, should take a useful haul of points from their next five when they meet Newcastle, Charlton, Coventry, Manchester City and Derby County.

Burley has also been able to rest Titus Bramble, his awesomely talented 19-year-old centre-back, and leave out David Johnson, their leading scorer last season, without disturbing the pattern. On Saturday Richard Naylor justified his inclusion at Johnson's expense by giving Ipswich the lead after 25 minutes, although the goal was essentially a gift.

Mark Schwarzer was one of eight Middlesbrough players missing through injury and his replacement in goal, Mark Crossley, looked ill at ease from the start, especially with clearances. So it was not altogether surprising that he should race beyond the penalty area to deal with a through-ball from Jim Magilton only to knock it straight to Naylor, who calmly found the empty net.

Three minutes later Middlesbrough fell for a three-card trick which involved Jamie Clapham tapping a free-kick to Jermaine Wright who stunned the ball, allowing Mark Venus to drive it inside the near post.

Dean Gordon, Middlesbrough's most persistent attacker, briefly raised their hopes when his free-kick took a deflection to send Richard Wright the wrong way. But it was a token revival and Wright did not have a shot to save during the remaining 22 minutes.

Weakened by injuries Middlesbrough may be, but such a sad sack of a performance boded ill for their chances of pulling out of this latest plunge down the Premiership with any speed. A third successive defeat has left Bryan Robson's team above the bottom three only on goal difference.

Up to now the strength of Robson's relationship with his chairman Steve Gibson has ensured his survival as manager and presumably he will at least be given a chance to turn things around once players such as Paul Ince, Alen Boksic, Robbie Mustoe and Ugo Ehiogu, recently signed from Aston Villa for £8m, are fit.

At the same time Riverside supporters are entitled to wonder precisely where the club is heading after being involved in more than £120m-worth of transfer business, buying and selling, during Robson's time.

All that Robson could say at Portman Road was that "we've got serious work to do" and "you need your best players". With upcoming matches against Arsenal, Manchester United and Leicester he can say that again - and probably will.

webTitle: Spurs angst mounts with loss of London pride

fields.headline: Spurs angst mounts with loss of London pride
fields.trailText: An FA Cup, Cup Winners' Cup, League Cup, a third-place finish in the Premiership and a quarter-final of the Champions League. What would Spurs fans give for that record since 1998?
fields.body:
An FA Cup, Cup Winners' Cup, League Cup, a third-place finish in the Premiership and a quarter-final of the Champions League. What would Spurs fans give for that record since 1998?

Yet Chelsea still sacked Gianluca Vialli, proving that the definition of success remains as elusive as ever. Right now Tottenham fans are feeling increasingly agitated about their club's failure just to get into the top five.

Two schools of White Hart Lane thought exist as to what ails Spurs, and neither is new. One blames the manager for failing to produce a decent side. The other, as ever, blames the chairman for not dipping into his pocket to buy more quality players.

As a result George Graham is being subjected to abuse from a small bunch of fans who want the former Arsenal man out. And Sir Alan Sugar's position is being targeted by Save Our Spurs, a new campaign group which plans to regain former glories by lobbying shareholders into revolution.

However, like many of this year's populist uprisings, from paedophile vigilantes to petrol blockades, the reasoning involved is dangerously narrow-minded.

Counterparts ranging from Gérard Houllier to Bobby Robson and even Sir Alex Ferguson, who took three years to kick-start Manchester United, would surely agree with Graham's assertions that "it's not going to be a quick fix" and "spend, spend, spend is not necessarily the answer".

Indeed, Spurs have not actually been a great side since 1962 and while the jury remains out on whether Graham still possesses what it takes to win the title, it is worth remembering that in 1998 Vialli inherited the strong foundations laid by Ruud Gullit while, since that same year, Graham has been picking up the pieces left by the hapless Christian Gross.

The aggressive minority who hurled abuse at Graham on Saturday because Spurs failed to stop their winless streak against Chelsea extending to 23 games would do well to remember this. And also the fact that Tottenham's squad was down to the bare bones, missing the likes of the £11m striker Sergei Rebrov, Sol Campbell, Oyvind Leonhardsen and Steffen Iversen through injury.

Yet, to Tottenham's credit, it needed two Ed de Goey saves in the first 10 minutes to keep Chelsea in the game. And the home side only went ahead through a debatable penalty - Ramon Vega guilty of handball, but only after being leant on by Gustavo Poyet.

The converter of the spot-kick was Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, as it had been a week earlier when Chelsea opened the scoring against Coventry with an equally controversial penalty.

And the Dutchman haunted Spurs further on 39 minutes, when he nodded on a Dennis Wise cross for Gianfranco Zola to score the second with a diving header.

Spurs continued to show commendable spirit - a notable plus in Graham's reign - but three minutes from time Hasselbaink added a third with a bending, skidding 30-yarder.

The scoreline flattered Chelsea. And afterwards, as the rain-soaked Graham reflected on those two early scoring chances plus a third on the hour when De Goey again denied Korsten, he must have wondered how different this result might have been had the striker he brought to Leeds as a virtual unknown still been his player. Hasselbaink has now banged in six goals in four games, lifting his season's total to 11 and helping Chelsea rise to sixth in the table.

Claudio Ranieri knows his defence needs tightening to maintain that progress, but with the £7.5m signing of the Danish international left-winger Jesper Gronkjaer due this week, Chelsea's season is no longer looking pear-shaped.

The fruit Graham is concerned about is the banana. Or rather the banana skin that could be tomorrow's Worthington Cup tie at home to Birmingham. Defeat, and Graham might be unexpectedly available for the England job.

fields.headline: Books Unlimited launches reading group
fields.trailText: The Books Unlimited reading group is a chance to read and discuss books with other book lovers. We'll be discussing one book a month, choosing the next month's book when the discussion starts - so there's plenty of time to read up.
fields.body:
The Books Unlimited reading group is a chance to read and discuss books with other book lovers. We'll be discussing one book a month, choosing the next month's book when the discussion starts - so there's plenty of time to read up.

The reading group is run through the Books Unlimited talkboards, where you can also join in with or begin discussions on all matters literary. You need to register to use the talkboards; for an easy guide to how to do it, click here.

Once you're registered, you can find the reading group here. Each book up for discussion has its own thread or discussion area, and you can also nominate books you'd like to read in the future.

During November we'll be discussing Rose Tremain's Whitbread Prize-winning novel Music and Silence, about a 17th-century lute player at the Danish court. December's choice is very different: Paul Auster's Timbuktu is a tale told by a dog who does indeed live a dog's life, torn between solicitude for his tramp master and a longing for bones.

January's choice is still up for grabs; you can post your nominations here.

fields.headline: Peter Ainsworth: Profile
fields.trailText: October 30 2000: Peter Ainsworth , Tory culture spokesman, has been having fun with soft targets such as the Dome. But with the publication of the broadcasting white paper imminent, he faces a tougher battle.
fields.body:
It's dubbed the ministry of fun, and if you believe the papers, Tory culture spokesman Peter Ainsworth is a fun kind of guy. He smoked dope at college, so he can't be all bad. And shadowing Chris Smith in parliament is hardly a tough task - the culture secretary has not exactly covered himself in glory recently. It would be hard to cock it up. "It is one of the best portfolios," admits Ainsworth with a smile.

It is not, however, easy to take a Tory culture spokesman seriously. In government, the Conservatives' broadcasting legacy was the discredited auction system that turned ITV into a free-for-all for the highest bidder. Successive national heritage secretaries were lambasted for being ineffectual (think Stephen Dorrell and Virginia Bottomley). And the Broadcasting Standards Commission, set up as a sop to the right-wing clean-up campaigners, has turned out to be a toothless tiger. Arts groups remember the Tories for slashing arts spending - even though it was the Conservative government that set up the national lottery. The one consolation is that the Tories at least enjoy plenty of friends in the press.

So when Ainsworth was appointed to the brief after the last election, he had a hard task ahead of him. He could have just made a name for himself by providing handy quotes to the Daily Mail when it gets outraged about Channel 5 (and he has done his fair share of that), and wait until something better comes along.

But, instead, Ainsworth has quietly been doing the rounds of the media circles. He is known to all the major broadcasters and lunches newspaper editors. He has immersed himself in all the issues that concern his wide brief (today the "historic environment" is at the front of his mind, following a meeting with English Heritage), and by all accounts, he has taken on board what people have said. Yet until the Mail on Sunday outed a crop of Tory frontbenchers as having tried cannabis in their youth, there was nothing much more to say about him.

But with a white paper imminent, it is important for the Tories to be seen to have a thought-out communications policy. It's not enough just to moan about the BBC, you've got to have a view about what to do about it.

And at least he watches TV and reads the papers. (There's a photocopy of the Sun's mocking front page the day after Greg Dyke was appointed to the BBC on his wall.) He enthuses about My Family, the BBC sitcom that has debuted to mixed reviews ("very high-quality comedy"), Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? ("great theatre"), and, of course: "I became addicted to Big Brother. And yes, I voted." So did he go for Scouse builder Craig, or lesbian former nun Anna? "I was one of the 49%." An Anna man, then.

So that takes care of BBC, ITV and Channel 4. What about Channel 5, which he condemned as "gross" in the Mail earlier this year after it exposed Keith Chegwin's bodily parts to an undeserving public? He makes the right noises about protecting children, but adds: "Well, you can switch it off. You don't have to watch it."

Suddenly, he swaps his smooth Oxford-educated received pronunciation for a mock-south London accent to imitate a constituent who complained about the channel. "He said to me, 'It's absolute filth innit, it goes on all night.' I replied, 'You don't have to watch it, there is the off button. And he said, 'Funnily enough, that's what my wife says.'" Clearly Ainsworth isn't that concerned about Channel Filth.

He is far more exercised with the BBC. It's not surprising: for the Conservatives, the corporation has always been a handy whipping boy. Full of pinko liberal subversives, it was a corrosive source of counter-revolutionary thought that had to be stamped on at all costs. The arrival of Dyke as director-general appeared to confirm that view. William Hague demanded that his appointment be blocked, and cries of "Labour stooge" went up as soon as he was confirmed in the post. Now, however, Dyke presents something of a problem for politicians of the right. In moving the Nine o'Clock News to 10pm with such haste, he has incurred the wrath of Smith. In slashing management costs, he has shown himself to be a shrewd businessman. And in showing a determination to increase the BBC's revenue from external sources, he has displayed a commercial eye that was lacking in the previous regime.

Hence, a marked change in tune from the Tories. "Greg is a highly commercial individual," says Ainsworth. "To his core he is a commercial operator. That has merits. It's a breath of fresh air, a management style that's welcomed. He's an engaging guy, all that is good. What gives some cause for concern is that there is a degree of impetuousness which we saw with the sudden decision to bring forward the move of the news. That was a highly commercial thing to do."

But Ainsworth doubts whether the commercialism of Dyke is necessarily a good thing for the corporation. "Is there going to be a culture clash between the BBC as an institution and a man who is so entrepreneurial?"

So far, so reasonable. Many in the BBC would say the same thing. But lest we be in any doubt, Ainsworth calls back later after thinking about what he has said. Dyke is still very much on probation as far as his political bias is concerned. "We are watching him like hawks. It's not an issue that can simply be brushed aside. I wouldn't want to give the impression that I think everything is rosy in the garden."

During his interview, in his cramped offices at Millbank, he expresses serious concerns about the ratings-driven strategy that appears to have been adopted by Dyke, Mark Thompson and Lorraine Heggessey at the BBC. While he acknowledges that BBC1 must continue to be popular if the argument for the licence fee (which he supports) is to be sustained, he believes that the corporation has over-stepped the mark. Moving the news was "opportunistic". And it calls into question the role of the BBC governors, and the whole way in which the BBC - and the rest of the broadcasting industry - is regulated.

While he says that "any new parliamentary measures should be as profoundly deregulatory as humanly possible", he agrees with the commercial sector's argument that the corporation should be brought under an overarching broadcasting regulator. The BBC governors cannot be "judge and jury" any more. But he does not advocate their abolition: "There is plenty for them to do." Instead, they would play the role of "non-executive directors".

It is unfair, he says, that ITV should have had to jump through so many hoops when it wanted to move News at Ten, when the BBC could do it in a matter of weeks without reference to an independent body. And it is equally unfair that those who wish to complain about the BBC's actions are also referred to the governors, who are ultimately responsible for the decisions in the first place.

But he is a supporter of the licence fee "for the time being", and would not countenance allowing advertising onto the BBC. "It would be devastating for the commercial sector."

And even in the light of the News of the World's dispatch of the Broadcasting Standards Commission's hapless Lord Holme, he does not favour a privacy law. The PCC works well, he says, and is about the only sector where backdoor deals appear to be worthwhile - most complainants are satisfied with a personal letter of apology from an editor, or a phone call of explanation.

As the Dome scandal dies down - Ainsworth has been particularly active in keeping Smith on the ropes over this one - he is now preparing for another political rollercoaster over the broadcasting white paper. These are not dull times.

"It's a wonderful brief, full of interesting issues and worthwhile people creating all sorts of things that are worthwhile in their own right - and are contributing increasingly to the economy. And everybody's got an opinion. It's intrinsically interesting - the whole sector, from sport to the 'historic environment' to broadcasting. And it will all assume a greater importance in our lives as we live longer and spend less of our time at work. Any political philosophy that ignores this, does so at its peril."
