And it is equally unfair that those who wish to complain about the BBC's actions are also referred to the governors, who are ultimately responsible for the decisions in the first place. But he is a supporter of the licence fee "for the time being", and would not countenance allowing advertising onto the BBC. "It would be devastating for the commercial sector." And even in the light of the News of the World's dispatch of the Broadcasting Standards Commission's hapless Lord Holme, he does not favour a privacy law. The PCC works well, he says, and is about the only sector where backdoor deals appear to be worthwhile - most complainants are satisfied with a personal letter of apology from an editor, or a phone call of explanation. As the Dome scandal dies down - Ainsworth has been particularly active in keeping Smith on the ropes over this one - he is now preparing for another political rollercoaster over the broadcasting white paper. These are not dull times. "It's a wonderful brief, full of interesting issues and worthwhile people creating all sorts of things that are worthwhile in their own right - and are contributing increasingly to the economy. And everybody's got an opinion. It's intrinsically interesting - the whole sector, from sport to the 'historic environment' to broadcasting. And it will all assume a greater importance in our lives as we live longer and spend less of our time at work. Any political philosophy that ignores this, does so at its peril."

fields.headline: Adams fury as deal falters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Frantic efforts to save the Northern Ireland peace process from collapse were underway last night as Gerry Adams launched a vitriolic attack on the Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble.
fields.body:
Frantic efforts to save the Northern Ireland peace process from collapse were underway last night as Gerry Adams launched a vitriolic attack on the Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble.

The visibly angry Sinn Fein leader accused Mr Trimble of "arrogant" behaviour and "stupid and unattainable demands" in the wake of his threat to bar Sinn Fein from attending a cross-border council meeting later this week.

He queried Mr Trimble's commitment to sharing power with nationalists and republicans at Stormont. "Sinn Fein does not hold executive position by dint of patronage from the UUP. We have a mandate," he said.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is expected to hold urgent talks this week with the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, to find a formula to persuade all sides to keep faith with the process as the rift between unionists and republicans over IRA disarmament deepens.

The peace process was thrown into a serious crisis on Saturday when Mr Trimble pledged to block Sinn Fein from attending the special cross-border ministerial council until the IRA lived up to its commitment to place its weapons "completely and verifiably beyond use".

The move, which saw off a challenge from unionist hardliners opposed to Mr Trimble, infuriated Sinn Fein which said it would attend the next meeting of the cross-border body in Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, on Friday.

Sinn Fein regards the cross-border body as one of the most important elements of the Good Friday agreement because republicans can claim that the body is an embryonic united Ireland. Cross-party support is needed for a minister to attend any north-south council meeting.

Speaking to party activists in Co Louth, Mr Adams said: "Does Mr Trimble think what he said is going to sort this out? Of course it isn't and everyone knows that.

"People don't react, whether they are unionists or republicans, to threat and to diktat and to the type of gesture politics we saw the other day."

Mr Adams also said the British and Irish governments must not pander to a "unionist veto", and must fulfil their commitments under the Good Friday agreement and provide effective political leadership. "Republicans have serious concerns about the focus and intent of Mr Blair and his colleagues," he added.

His remarks were condemned as a "hysterical over-reaction" by Michael McGimpsey, the Ulster Unionist arts minister in the Northern Ireland power-sharing executive.

There was relief in London and Dublin that Mr Trimble had succeeded in defeating hardliners at a meeting of the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday. A relieved Mr Trimble won by 54% to 46%, a one point increase since the last meeting in May.

Victory for the dissidents, led by the UUP MP Jeffrey Donaldson, would have dealt the peace process a potentially fatal blow because Mr Trimble would have been forced to abandon the power-sharing executive.

However, there were fears last night that Mr Trimble's victory came at a dangerously high price. Both London and Dublin are acutely aware that excluding Sinn Fein from the next meeting of the north-south ministerial council on Friday would harden the IRA's opposition to disarmament.

If a legal challenge to Mr Trimble, which is being considered by the SDLP, fails ministers may consider postponing Friday's meeting at which Sinn Fein's health minister, Bairbre de Brun, is due to set up a cross-border food standards agency with her southern Irish counterpart, Micheál Martin.

Beyond that, Mr Mandelson is expected to tell Mr Cowen that the IRA should live up to its pledge to press ahead with disarmament. Mr Cowen will make clear that threats from the unionists will guarantee that the IRA does not make any further gestures.

The tension between unionists and republicans came amid fears that the loyalist paramilitary feud could erupt again after the shooting of a 21-year-old man in north Belfast. The body of David Greer, a member of the Ulster Defence Association, was found with a gunshot wound to the chest on Saturday night. The Ulster Democratic party, the UDA's political wing, blamed the killing on the rival Ulster Volunteer Force.

fields.headline: Teacher hiring drive biggest yet
fields.standfirst:
Ads say 'Those who can, teach' as awards honour best

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will today launch its biggest teacher recruitment drive yet, after ministers last night paid tribute to the country's best teachers in an awards ceremony at the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
The government will today launch its biggest teacher recruitment drive yet, after ministers last night paid tribute to the country's best teachers in an awards ceremony at the Millennium Dome.

Just three years after Tony Blair personally backed a campaign slogan claiming No one Forgets a Good Teacher, the £7m recruitment drive will be unveiled with the message: Those who can, teach.

National press advertising starting this week is expected to be followed by cinema and TV promotion later in the year, backed by coordinated literature for would-be teachers. The campaign is designed to appeal to high quality recruits and will be targeted at graduates, postgraduates and those seeking to switch careers.

Teacher recruitment has become a hot political issue, with Labour and the Tories sharply at odds over the extent of the problem and the figures used to portray it.

Ministers admit they face a tough job attracting sufficient numbers to the profession, but claim that they inherited the problem from the Tories. They claim that performance-related pay and "training salaries" announced in March will make a difference.

They hope the national publicity generated by the so-called Teachers' Oscars - now a national event - will attract fresh interest in teaching.

Last night the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, paid tribute to teachers at the ceremony at the dome. The 14 national winners, selected from 150 regional winners in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, took away cheques for £20,000 for their schools.

Mr Blunkett, who presented the award for working with parents and the community in a secondary school to Lyn Reynolds of Byng Kenrick central school in Birmingham, said: "Teachers are crucial in shaping the generation to come. I am happy to join today in celebrating excellence throughout the education service."

But Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said of the coming campaign: "It is not going to deflect young people from judging teaching according to reality. The government has got to look at poor pay and working conditions, including difficulties with discipline; then the problem will solve itself."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said last night: "There is a real crisis in teaching. All we are getting from the government is complacency and there is a danger of all this degenerating into farce as we see campaign after campaign failing."

The Guardian sponsored the award for teacher of the year. The winner for the secondary school sector was Cathy Roberts, a music teacher at St Aidan's Church of England high school, Harrogate, who admits she was stunned when the singer Cleo Lane presented her award in front of 700 pupils last term. "It was the best moment of my life," Mrs Roberts said.

Last night's ceremony will be televised on BBC1 next Sunday.

Full details of the winners will appear in a supplement in tomorrow's Guardian Education.

fields.headline: Christmas gifts for sports fans
fields.standfirst: Keep in the warm, exert almost no energy and keep the sports fans in your life happy
fields.trailText: Keep in the warm, exert almost no energy and keep the sports fans in your life happy.
fields.body:
Rugby hats
With another obnoxious winter lurking menacingly around the corner, an England rugby beanie hat will almost certainly be a godsend. Featuring an embroidered English rose and the natty Nike swoosh, therugbystore.co.uk are selling it for £8.50. Alternatively, try the cap version (same rose, same swoosh) instead - yours for £9.35. Negotiating this large and slick site is a doddle, each product features a brief description and product shot, click on the image to view a larger version. Ordering is simple and secure, though there's a £5 delivery charge for orders under £150, and while they promise delivery asap, they advise you to allow 28 days.

Wimbledon in Pictures
The world's greatest tennis tournament captured through the lenses of one of the world's finest photographic agencies. Visions of Wimbledon features more than 200 Allsport images over 143 pages. Available at sportsbooksdirect.com for £13.99, £4 less than the rrp. Negotiating the site and purchasing are both rapid and foolproof, although the latter is not based on a secure server. Squashed images will have you squinting, and product information is kept to a disappointing minimum. Delivery is free in the UK and takes between two and five days.

Personalised golf balls
Tiger slaps his name on his, Monty favours his birth date. However you choose to personalise your golf balls, yourownballs.com should be your first port of call. They'll advise you on which ball suits which golfer, with their cheapest option - 15 Dunlop DDH balls with space for up to 60 characters - starting at £24.63 (including P+P). A cautionary word, however, if you want to splash profanity across your balls, you'll need to browse elsewhere. The site benefits from simple navigation (the search tools are clear) and concise information. The only criticism is that it falls down through slow loading. Allow 14 working days for delivery, 20 should you order 50 boxes or more.

Football shirts

The place to visit for football shirts. This site - kitbag.com - boasts what appears to be every domestic, national and retro shirt under the sun. Looking for the latest Man United jersey? No problem, they can offer 24 red-devilled variations. And for those with more exotic tastes, there's always the latest offerings from Guinea, the Ivory Coast and FC National Bucuresti. Covering all bases, you'll also discover a similarly extensive range of rugby and cricket shirts. The site is a cluttered, visually uninspired affair where text is minimal and loading times lengthy. The range, however, more than compensates. Season 2000-2001 shirts start from £39.99 with free delivery (UK orders only) promised in just 24 hours.

Golf accessories
Plastic and wood is so old hat, the more discerning golfer prefers a sexy solid silver tee, pitch repair and ball marker, presented in a leather case - available from www.waltonskues.com. The set, priced £49.50, is guaranteed to last and impress your fourball partners. Cheaper alternatives are available on other sites but you get what you pay for. Design-wise, the site is a few-frills affair where clear and large product visuals, a simple payment/checkout page and faster than average loading times impress. It suffers slightly, however, from a lack of product information. Orders delivered in between 3-5 days, add £2.95 P&P for UK orders.

Football stadium tour
In the company of an old pro, take an access (almost) all areas tour of one of Britain's finest football stadia. Walk out onto the pitch, discover what goes on behind the scenes and listen to tales of the stadium's history. Available from www.boots.co.uk and their high street stores, grounds included range from Manchester United and Leeds to Celtic and Rangers. The tour lasts approximately two hours and costs £80 for two people. Before you can purchase online, you'll need to register and provide a password. Once in, it's a soothing affair (think pastel shades) designed along the lines of a health and beauty magazine. Purchasing is a simple and swift process and delivery of products, normally taking five working days, is free.

A day at Twickenham
Former Bath, British Lions and England prop Gareth Chilcott wants to give you the guided tour of Twickenham. He wants to show you the changing rooms, the stands and the pitch. But he also wants to put you through your paces in a hi-octane training session. The question is, are you tough enough? Available priced £139 per person from redletterdays.co.uk. Under-16s must be accompanied by an adult. Their site's use of extremely narrow pages and small text can be forgiven as a creative use of red frames and text make for an impressively alluring site. Ordering is quick and simple, you fill out your name, address and any message required, they then call to confirm your payment details upon receipt.

Table football
For some indoors exercise this Christmas, visit the stylish www.boysstuff.com In amongst the standard blokey gadgetry - miniature Ferraris, hammocks, cybertools and the like - you'll find Garlando's table football. Priced £399, the Garlando model is manufactured in medium density fibreboard with sturdy metal legs and crafted, they promise, to the same standards as you'll find in pubs and bars the world over. Though variations are available on a number of other sites (room202.com for example) find the Garlando cheaper elsewhere and boysstuff will sell for 5% less than their rival's price. Navigating the site is simple and speedy, and the process is secure. Although delivery takes 14 days, your table will arrive fully assembled and ready for action. Add £6.94 for delivery.

Monaco grand prix weekend
Step into the millionaire's playground when the most exclusive grand prix on the formula one circuit rolls into Monaco. Taking place next May, the package includes flights from London to Nice, all transfers, three nights with b&b in a four star hotel, admission on both practice and race day and a natty little presentation wallet. firstcalltickets.com are offering the package for £1,290.83 per person. Ordering is a simple affair, although details of the package are spread thinly across several pages, and could, in the interest of speeding up the process, be lumped together. Tickets will be dispatched at least seven days before the event.

webTitle: Labour accuses Portillo over tax cut plans

fields.headline: Labour accuses Portillo over tax cut plans
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has accused the Conservative party of planning to privatise the NHS if it returns to office after the next general election.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has accused the Conservative party of planning to privatise the NHS if it returns to office after the next general election.

"It is now clearer than ever that the Tories' health policy is to force people to go private and pay for their own operations," Mr Milburn said.

"The Tories have never been more explicit in outlining their privatisation agenda for a two-tier health service."

His comments came in response to claims made this morning by Michael Portillo. The shadow chancellor promised that a Conservative government would offer £8bn worth of tax cuts if they win the next general election.

Writing in the Times, Mr Portillo denies Labour accusations that a future Tory government would cut £16bn from funding of public services.

He said that Labour's calculations "have no basis in reality" - and claims tax cuts could come alongside increases in on services.

"Some people seem to find it hard to understand that we can offer increases in public spending but reduce taxes," writes Mr Portillo.

"It is economic growth that makes this possible."

He added: "If we were to commit ourselves to raise public spending by £60bn instead of Mr [Chancellor Gordon Brown] Brown's £68bn, and to make £8bn of tax cuts, we would, without any effect on debt, still be committed to a huge programme of spending that would easily encompass our commitment to match Labour's planned spending on the NHS."

Meanwhile the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was expected to unveil a range of new financial incentives aimed at 350,000 more lone parents into work

He is expected to announce that he wants to increase the proportion of lone parents at work from 50% to the US level of 70% through training grants and extra help with childcare and housing costs

Both initiatives mark out the re-emergence of the tax and spend policies as one of the key battlegrounds of the next election.

Mr Portillo promises "more details" in the coming months.

A Labour spokesman said: "Michael Portillo has admitted that the Tories would make substantial spending cuts - but he still won't tell us where the cuts will fall.

"What we do know is that he is making no commitment to match Labour's spending plans for education, transport and policing, and that money will be diverted from the NHS to private health care.

"The Tory sums don't add up. Vital public services - schools, transport and policing - would all be cut under Tory plans."

Later today, Mr Portillo stressed that he was not dealing with exact figures at this stage. "I'm not committing myself to a particular figure.

"But I think it's important for people to understand that it is perfectly possible, with the economy growing, for us spend much more money on public services - including all the sums of money which the government wishes to spend on the health service - and still have room for tax cuts.

"It clearly is possible. This is a matter of choices, and you can have higher public spending, much higher public spending, and still have tax cuts."

Mr Portillo said that he would not be able to "unpick" the present government's spending plans for next year if the Tories were to win a May general election.

"We could only thereafter, I think, get down to increases which were sustainable in the long term," he BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"But I think it's important for people to understand that it is perfectly possible, with the economy growing, for us spend much more money on public services - including all the sums of money which the government wishes to spend on the health service - and still have room for tax cuts. fields.headline: The only show in town
fields.standfirst: Men like Max Stahl risk their lives to bring us images from the world's war zones. So why, asks  Maggie O'Kane , do broadcasters treat them like annoying door-to-door salesmen?
fields.trailText: Men like Max Stahl risk their lives to bring us images from the world's war zones. So why, asks Maggie O'Kane, do broadcasters treat them like annoying door-to-door salesmen?
fields.body:
Max Stahl cleaned up into a rather smart figure for an awards ceremony in London's Barbican Centre last week. For once the worn brown corduroys, hiking boots and Indiana Jones hat were replaced by a suit for dinner.

Stahl, 45, is a freelance cameraman. One of a breed who, when the going gets dangerously tough - in such places as Chechnya, East Timor and Kosovo - provide the only pictures we get of whatever contemporary hell they're still in. I've known four Max Stahls over the years - three of whom died. He has been kidnapped twice, seriously wounded twice and reported dead three times.

Stahl received the Rory Peck Award (named after a freelance cameraman killed in Moscow in 1993) on Thursday night for what may have been one of the most important pieces of television footage in the past decade. He arrived in East Timor as the results of the country's UN-sponsored first democratic elec tion were about to be announced in September 1999. Defying the Indonesian army by island-hopping on hired fishing boats, he got there just in time to record the fury and revenge unleashed by the army and militia in the wake of the elections. The people of East Timor, encouraged and supported by the UN, had dared to declare independence. The result was a bloody backlash and orders from New York for the UN staff to get out fast. Media teams were leaving as well. Within hours of the election result, some 600 journalists had been reduced to a handful, mainly freelancers, numbering around 20.

The three satellite dishes owned by the major news organisation were packed up, so any cameraman left behind had to ship out his pictures by hand. Stahl was in the UN compound in Dili when the people sheltering there heard they were to be abandoned. Stahl, Marie Colvin of the Sunday Times and two Dutch journalists were the only media personnel who stayed behind. The other 600, including myself, were left baying in Darwin. If ever a story needed to be covered by the international media it was East Timor - but we were all gone. Crucially, because he was the only cameraman there, Stahl stayed.

The reality of TV journalism today is that it is a soap opera, complete with star faces. A correspondent is in one country on a Monday and then a different war in a different country on a Wednesday. When things get really tough, the pictures usually come from the freelancers. "The TV companies treat it like stacking supermarket shelves - they have to fill the shelf, but they don't want to pay out the big money for insurance, or to put their own people at risk, so they do it in other ways by using people like us," says Stahl.

"You never get the money or time upfront from TV companies - maybe you can get an aid agency to give you some help, but the backing is not there from the big corporations. The only way to do real investigative journalism for TV now is to step outside of the system - inside they don't even know what you are talking about any more. They don't see that their own soap opera of star correspondents is delivering nothing of any real substance because they are too busy hopping from one country to another."

Stahl has been interested in Timor for 20 years, and has covered earlier massacres, so he had both the contacts and the commitment to stay on when the UN abandoned the people in its compound. He wrote afterwards: "Informed only hours before the planned pullout, and fearing immediate death, hundreds of refugees fled under the wire and up the steep rocky hill behind a cover of darkness . . . I joined them with a small infrared-capable DV camera."

Stahl's pictures of women and children stumbling up the hill in the darkness, faces frozen in shock and fear, were the only images of the Timor tragedy. They were played again and again around the world.

According to one of the judges of Rory Peck Award, Stahl's pictures had a huge political influence. "It was very important material in terms of its impact on the UN Security Council - these pictures shocked them and forced them to act."

Nik Gowing, a BBC World presenter and former diplomatic editor of Channel 4 News, says: "To stay in Dili when everyone else had left, and to go outside the UN compound to tell the whole story was very brave indeed . . . to leave it and spend time with the people in the hills is fabulous."

Stahl undoubtedly saved lives, but his pictures also helped force the hand of the UN into direct intervention in East Timor - finally burying its shattering failure in Somalia and giving it the confidence to support difficult peace missions in countries such as Sierre Leone.

Earlier this year, another freelance cameraman - the 1998 winner of the Rory Peck Award, Miguel Gil Moreno - was killed in Sierre Leone. Before his death, his last major trip had been to Chechnya, where he spent three weeks. His pictures of human beings living like terrified rats under the city were - like Stahl's Timor pictures - the only show in town.

So hundreds of TV companies around the world depended on two men - freelancers who funded themselves - to bring the biggest international stories of the year into our living rooms. It was the same in Kosovo: the only pictures that made it out came from three freelance cameramen who crawled through Serb positions during the bombing.

Yet the media industry treats these heroes like the most irritating of door-to-door salesmen. Vaughan Smith, who runs Frontline News - co-founded by Rory Peck - says freelancers such as Stahl and Moreno are in danger of becoming extinct. Their market has been taken over by news agencies such as AP and Reuters, who pay locals to supply footage. In Grozny last year another small agency was giving teenagers $400 to go onto the streets to gather pictures - a Russian roulette for television. In a survey of six past winners of the Rory Peck Award, Smith found that most said the major TV companies were exploiting them.

A Russian cameraman who died in Chechnya left behind a widow and family who did not receive a penny in compensation because the small Russian TV station he worked for folded. The Rory Peck Fund is helping to support his family. "It's a lottery, and who you are working for dictates how you are treated," says Tina Carr, who runs the fund. "One man dies and his family get nothing. Gil Moreno was working for AP when he died, so there was some back-up."

According to Smith, the TV companies are becoming less and less receptive to the most valuable and often the most daring of the news-gatherers. "Restructuring seems to have made broadcasting corporations less flexible and, with a few notable exceptions such as the Channel 4 Independence Fund, they seem less receptive. When they do need us we outlive our usefulness the day the story ends."

Many freelancers are forced to fund their own trips. One I know returned from Chechnya and got on the phone to the BBC at Heathrow. At that time, in December 1999, it was virtually impossible to get inside the country. He had escaped kidnapping and attack by helicopter gunship and returned with pictures of refugees being bombed by Russian helicopters, and rare footage of fundamentalist fighters in action.

First the desk editor said he was too busy to talk, asked him to call back, and when he did said: "We already have someone there." The BBC team, like thousands of other media personnel, was then unable to get past the Russians into Chechnya - yet this freelancer could hardly get anyone to take his calls.

Warning against using non-professionals, Smith points to a phenomenon that was already exemplified by the teenage image-hunters in Grozny. "Some of them will do brilliantly, but they will be vulnerable and there will be a tendency towards a kind of war porn and pictures un-associated with journalistic investigation."

In May, the death in an ambush of Moreno and Kurt Schork, an American war correspondent, rocked the industry. Experience was no protection. News chiefs have become more and more cautious - rightly trying to protect their people. But someone will tell the story and usually it is men such as Max Stahl, Miguel Gil Moreno or Rory Peck. They are incredibly valuable members of our trade. They are the elite: Stahl helped change history and saved lives; and Gil Moreno was prepared to live in Grozny when none of the top-flight correspondents wanted to or were allowed to.

It's time we started treating them as they deserve - because where would our business be without them?

webTitle: Barak rules out concessions to Palestinians

fields.headline: Barak rules out concessions to Palestinians
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak said today that he would make no concessions to the Palestinians, as the 33-day uprising claimed another life.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak said today that he would make no concessions to the Palestinians, as the 33-day uprising claimed another life.

In traditionally Arab east Jerusalem, an Israeli security guard posted in the entrance hall of the National Insurance institute was killed by a shot to the head.

It is the first time in the current fighting that an Israeli has been killed in Jerusalem. His colleague was critically wounded in the chest.

Mr Barak, who has won a reprieve for his minority government without recourse to a coalition with hardliner Ariel Sharon, opened parliament's winter session saying that, although his hand was stretched out in peace, there should be no reward for violence.

"In the name of the people of Israel, I turn to Chairman Arafat - know that violence won't achieve anything," he said.

In 33 days of fighting, 143 people - most of them Palestinians - have been killed.

In the West Bank, a 20-year-old Palestinian man was found shot dead in an olive grove, the scene of clashes the night before. The man's brother was also killed in confrontation with Israeli troops.

Two rock-throwing clashes in Gaza left more than 30 Palestinians injured after Israeli troops opened fire.

The ultra-Orthodox Shas party, Israel's third-largest, has said that it will support Mr Barak for the next month. Opposition leader Ariel Sharon says he still has not given up on the idea of joining an emergency coalition.

However, Mr Barak faced hecklers from the opposition who accused him of being too conciliatory, and from the Arab legislators who complain that Israel has used excessive force against the Palestinians.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, speaking in Gaza City, gave no sign that he would rein in the gunmen who have been opening fire on Jewish settlements and Israeli army posts.

Asked what his message to his people was, Mr Arafat said: "Until Jerusalem, until Jerusalem, until Jerusalem is the capital of our independent Palestinian state."

fields.headline: Thirty years of Hertha
fields.standfirst: European round-up. The Berlin club returned to the top of the Bundesliga for the first time since 1970.
fields.trailText: Hertha Berlin won 1-0 at 1860 Munich on Sunday to return to the top of the Bundesliga for the first time since 1970.
fields.body:
Hertha Berlin won 1-0 at 1860 Munich on Sunday to return to the top of the Bundesliga for the first time since 1970.

Thirty years of hurt: Hertha, probably the only top-class football team to be named after a boat, have spent most of their more recent history listing, becalmed or holed below the water line. They have never won the Bundesliga - their best finish is third place - and they have spent all too many seasons in the second division and the Berliner Regionalliga.

For too long the club resembled its stadium: anachronistic and ill-maintained, with a vast untapped capacity. But a more ambitious and resourceful administration has helped turn the club around. They won promotion four years ago, qualified for the Champions League last year and advanced from the same group as Chelsea to the second group stage.

They showed resilience on Sunday, holding out in Munich with the considerable help of their Hungarian goalkeeper Gabor Kiraly, then stealing victory in the second minute of injury time when their Icelandic defender Eyjoelfur Sverrisson headed in a free-kick from Stefan Beinlich, the former Aston Villa midfielder.

"It was a lucky victory," said Sverrisson. "We executed our concept terribly."

Hertha took over at the top from Bayern Munich, who drew 1-1 in Bremen on Saturday. In other Bundesliga action over the weekend, Cologne climbed off the bottom with a 3-2 win over VfB Stuttgart, Unterhaching came back from a goal down to upset Hamburg 2-1 and Kaiserslautern gained their third successive victory under their new coach Andreas Brehme, 2-1 at Borussia Dortmund.

But Rudi Voller, the new coach at Bayer Leverkusen, failed to gain a third successive victory. Bayer held on for a 0-0 draw in Gelsenkirchen against Schalke 04.

Voller's predecessor, Christoph Daum, is hiding out in Orlando, protesting his innocence and apparently contemplating taking another drugs test today."Christoph believes that some powerful people manipulated his hair analysis. He doesn't trust anyone," said Reiner Calmund, Leverkusen's general manager.

"This thing isn't over," Daum told Bild am Sonntag. "I have my tactics. I'll be there at high noon."

Daum was fired by Leverkusen and dropped as Germany's future national coach after he failed the hair analysis test designed to disprove Bild's claim that he was in the habit of holding cocaine-fuelled sex parties with prostitutes. Police with sniffer dogs searched Daum's home and office on Friday.

While the Bundesliga and most other European leagues are only just beginning to take shape, the season is nearly at an end in more northerly countries.

Sunday was cup final day in Norway. And Odd Grenland lifted the trophy for the first time since 1931 after extra-time at the Ulleval. The Danish substitute Christian Flindt Bjerg scored from close range to give the Odd boys a 2-1 win over Viking Stavanger.

Halmstad clinched their second Swedish League title in four years with a 2-0 win over Elfsborg in Boras. That stretched their lead over AIK Solna, the defending champions, to eight points with only one game to go.

Spartak Moscow look certain to win the Russian title for the fifth successive year after a 2-1 win over Zenit in St Petersburg. Artyom Bezrodny scored a dramatic winner late in injury time to give Spartak a five-point lead over their Muscovite rivals Lokomotiv with two matches remaining.

Elsewhere in Europe ... Feyenoord lost their 100% record in the Netherlands when they were held 1-1 by Utrecht. Club Brugge maintained their 100% record in Belgium with a 2-0 win at Westerlo. Paris St-Germain went down to their first home defeat of the season when Bordeaux overcame the loss of their French international striker Christophe Dugarry to win 2-1 at the Parc des Princes with two goals from their Portuguese international forward Pauleta. And in Portugal, Sporting Lisbon ended a run of three successive defeats with a 1-0 over Beira Mar.

webTitle: Britain hit by worst storms for 13 years

fields.headline: Britain hit by worst storms for 13 years
fields.standfirst:
 Three dead
 Tornado hits Sussex town
 25 severe storm warnings
 Transport chaos
 Environment agency flood helpline: 0845 988 1188
fields.trailText:
 Three dead
 Tornado hits Sussex town
 25 severe storm warnings
 Transport chaos
 Environment agency flood helpline: 0845 988 1188
fields.body:
The worst storms in 13 years have lashed southern Britain, leaving a trail of death, carnage and transport chaos.

At least three people have been killed, and hundreds injured as the storms flooded homes, towns and roads.

The 450ft high Millennium Wheel was closed after being damaged by the storms. Trips on the London Eye were suspended after six of the 32 capsules suffered glass damage as horrific winds lashed at them across the Thames.

Gusts approaching 100mph upended trees and tens of thousands of homes have been left without power in the worst weather since the great hurricane in 1987.

A man in his 50s was killed and two people, thought to be a married couple, were seriously injured when a tree fell on two vehicles on the A3, near Hindhead, Surrey, yesterday evening.

Another man died last night when his car hit surface water and skidded into a parked car and then a bus in Sutton, south London.

A tube train driver on the London Underground was badly injured when his train hit a tree on the Piccadilly Line.

And another man was reportedly killed when his motorbike was believed to have a hit a tree on the A387 at Wrantage, near Taunton, Somerset.

This morning, a tornado swept through Selsey in West Sussex, tossing caravans into the air, leaving two people injured from flying glass and a trail of wreckage. The tornado hit West Sands Caravan Park less than 48 hours after a similar incident in nearby Bognor Regis.

At sea, the 33-year-old captain of a Dutch ship was killed last night as he was swept off balance and thrown down 30ft into the hold of his ship, anchored off Torbay.

Sailings were cancelled from Dover and ferries were unable to dock, leavinf 6,000 passengers on vessels forced to shelter from force eight gales.

The port of Fowey, near St Austell, was cut off by fallen trees blocking the roads, and a 20,000-tonne vessel ran aground in rough seas and force nine gales off Cornwall overnight.

Train services into London were reduced to a trickle as weary commuters, already battered by recent rail delays, suffered again.

Among the casualties were all services operated by Thames Trains, Wales & West, First Great Western, Central Trains, South West Trains, Midland Mainline, Valley Lines and Connex.

Additionally, all Virgin west coast services were suspended between Euston and Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester, Glasgow and Carlisle.

On the roads, large sections of the M25 around London were closed as drainage channels failed to cope with the sheer volume of water, while other main arteries were reduced to a crawl.

The high winds brought chaos to air schedules with dozens of flights cancelled. By mid morning, British Airways had cancelled 66 flights from Heathrow and 22 from Stansted.

More than 21,000 homes were left without electricity in the south east, according to power firm Seeboard. Power cuts also spread as far north as Cheshire.

The west country was one of the worst affected regions. Avon and Somerset Police closed all roads into flood-hit Taunton to everything but emergency traffic.

The Environment Agency said its staff were coping but warned that householders had to take more responsibility as climate change threatened to make such storms more likely.

The number of severe flood warnings across the country, currently 25, could rise later this afternoon, he said. Up to 80mm of rain fell in 24 hours.

Green lobby groups were today urging politicians to act now over wild weather conditions. The gales and storms battering Britain "are just a taste of things to come" according to Friends of the Earth.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the environment minister, Michael Meacher, are preparing for major international climate change talks in the Hague next month.

However, Mr Meacher, said: "It would be wrong, every time there is a climatic impact, to assume that it is climate change, global warming."

He did, however, acknowledge that the gales "almost certainly have climate change as a contributory cause".

webTitle: Labour accuses Portillo over tax cut plans

fields.headline: Labour accuses Portillo over tax cut plans
fields.trailText:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has
                                                                  accused the Conservative party of
                                                                  planning to privatise the NHS if it returns
                                                                  to office after the next general election.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has accused the Conservative party of planning to privatise the NHS if it returns to office after the next general election.

"It is now clearer than ever that the Tories' health policy is to force people to go private and pay for their own operations," Mr Milburn said.

"The Tories have never been more explicit in outlining their privatisation agenda for a two-tier health service."

His comments came in response to claims made this morning by Michael Portillo. The shadow chancellor promised that a Conservative government would offer £8bn worth of tax cuts if they win the next general election.

Writing in the Times, Mr Portillo denies Labour accusations that a future Tory government would cut £16bn from funding of public services.

He said that Labour's calculations "have no basis in reality" - and claims tax cuts could come alongside increases in on services.

"Some people seem to find it hard to understand that we can offer increases in public spending but reduce taxes," writes Mr Portillo.

"It is economic growth that makes this possible."

He added: "If we were to commit ourselves to raise public spending by £60bn instead of Mr [Chancellor Gordon Brown] Brown's £68bn, and to make £8bn of tax cuts, we would, without any effect on debt, still be committed to a huge programme of spending that would easily encompass our commitment to match Labour's planned spending on the NHS."

Meanwhile the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was expected to unveil a range of new financial incentives aimed at 350,000 more lone parents into work

He is expected to announce that he wants to increase the proportion of lone parents at work from 50% to the US level of 70% through training grants and extra help with childcare and housing costs

Both initiatives mark out the re-emergence of the tax and spend policies as one of the key battlegrounds of the next election.

Mr Portillo promises "more details" in the coming months.

A Labour spokesman said: "Michael Portillo has admitted that the Tories would make substantial spending cuts - but he still won't tell us where the cuts will fall.

"What we do know is that he is making no commitment to match Labour's spending plans for education, transport and policing, and that money will be diverted from the NHS to private health care.

"The Tory sums don't add up. Vital public services - schools, transport and policing - would all be cut under Tory plans."

Later today, Mr Portillo stressed that he was not dealing with exact figures at this stage. "I'm not committing myself to a particular figure.

"But I think it's important for people to understand that it is perfectly possible, with the economy growing, for us spend much more money on public services - including all the sums of money which the government wishes to spend on the health service - and still have room for tax cuts.

"It clearly is possible. This is a matter of choices, and you can have higher public spending, much higher public spending, and still have tax cuts."

Mr Portillo said that he would not be able to "unpick" the present government's spending plans for next year if the Tories were to win a May general election.

"We could only thereafter, I think, get down to increases which were sustainable in the long term," he BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

fields.headline: More pain in Spain
fields.trailText: It's been an emotional week in Spain: Gaizka Mendieta abused 40,000 Valencian mothers, Steve McManaman became the object of a love-in at the Bernabéu (again), an angry Javier Clemente was sacked - and the fall-out from the Barcelona v Madrid derbi continued.
fields.body:
It's been an emotional week in Spain: Gaizka Mendieta abused 40,000 Valencian mothers, Steve McManaman became the object of a love-in at the Bernabéu (again), an angry Javier Clemente was sacked - and the fall-out from the Barcelona v Madrid derbi continued.

Following the abuse Luis Figo received last week, Portugal pulled out of a friendly against the Catalan national side in protest, and Barcelona were fined a less-than-crippling 1.5m pesetas (under £6,000) by the Spanish FA for the behaviour of their fans. Meanwhile Roberto Carlos revealed that he had been scared of "not getting home alive" - words which were to prove horribly prophetic.

On Tuesday an already emotional night in Leeds led to tragedy when a Barcelona supporter was shot dead in the small town of Chinchilla by 57-year-old Real Madrid fan Manuel Gabaldón. The madridista took to the streets with a box of fireworks to celebrate his rivals' defeat at Elland Road. Or so he thought. When Barça fan and local baker Francisco Javier Jiménez kindly revealed that Rivaldo had saved the day a huge argument blew up. Gabaldón returned home, collected his hunting rifle and returned to settle the dispute. The Madrid fan has been described by locals as a "conflictive personality" (ie. a nutter) and the town's mayor confirmed that the two had been "involved in fights before". Even so, no one foresaw such a terrible end.

Emotions have also been running high in Valencia. Mendieta has been far from happy, as he showed with his tetchy response to scoring the winner against Zaragoza last week. Abused by a section of his own fans, Valencia's captain barely celebrated the strike. Instead an indignant "hijos de puta" (sons of bitches) was clearly visible to anyone with the most elementary of lip-reading skills.

Then on Wednesday the club acted to avoid similar scenes to those witnessed at the Camp Nou by leaving the former Olympiakos midfielder Zlatko Zahovic out of their squad for the trip to Athens. It was probably a wise move: messages left on Zahovic's website declaring that "the Slovenians will have to come to Athens to collect the bones of their idol" hardly boded well.

Perhaps temperatures within the Valencia squad had cooled down too much by Sunday, as over in Pamplona Héctor Cúper's side were unable to muster up any passion against newly promoted Osasuna. The league leaders fell behind to a Mateo strike inside six minutes, but got out of jail when Cruchaga scored an own goal 12 minutes later. Valencia managed only one shot on target in the whole of the second half and victory hardly looked on the cards, until John Carew scored with just five minutes remaining to keep them top of the Liga.

Emotions were also running high in San Sebastián, where Javier Clemente was sacked as manager of Real Sociedad on Monday. Never one to smile when a frown will do, the ex-national coach was adamant that the blame lay with press, players and fans. Oh, and there was a sinister plot against him, too: "I'm not the problem," Clemente claimed. "Someone [at the club] was interested in creating a bad atmosphere". Like Spanish supporters after the 98 World Cup, Real fans won't exactly be sorry to see him go.

But Clemente's departure didn't help the struggling Sociedad side. This weekend it was Real Madrid's turn to fill their boots in San Sebastián - just what their caretaker boss Salva Iriarte needed. Madrid - whose fans gave rapturous receptions to returning heroes Morientes and McManaman (long time, no see) at the Bernabéu in midweek - ran out comfortable winners. Guti and Savio were the key men, grabbing one each in a 4-1 victory. Figo and Hierro completed the scoring in a game all too easy for Madrid. So easy, in fact, that the Spanish league's worst player, Geremi, even managed to hit the post from Figo's corner. Nice to see uncle Vicente is letting him take them again.

Rivaldo, another player not entirely happy with life, was even more downcast on Saturday night. Barcelona were totally outclassed during their visit to Mallorca, where their defence was torn apart by Samuel Eto'o and Alberto Luque. That said, even the Neville brothers would have fancied their chances against the goalkeeper Dutruel and defender Sergi, who combined hilariously to gift the islanders both goals in a 2-0 win. Twice Dutruel failed to hold pretty tame efforts from Luque. Twice Sergi stood and watched. And twice Mallorca punished them, Eto'o finishing off the first and Ibagaza the second. Dutruel, the latest in a long line of dreadful Camp Nou keepers, scandalously claimed afterwards that he "didn't feel guilty".

That classic symbol of Spanish discontent - the hanky wave ("pañolada") - was the order of the day in Soria, where Numancia hosted Deportivo La Coruna. The referee Daudén Ibáñez was the object of the Numancia fans' wrath, failing to award a penalty in the 93rd minute after a clear foul by the Deportivo defender Helder. That would have levelled the score at 2-2 after a spirited Numancia comeback. As it is Depor stay in touch at the top, two points behind Valencia.

Elsewhere this weekend Villarreal and Athletic Bilbao (0-0) and Málaga and Zaragoza (1-1) drew, while there were 2-1 home wins for Las Palmas against Racing Santander and Celta Vigo against Valladolid. Rayo Vallecano missed the chance to stay ahead of their city rivals Real Madrid, losing at home to last year's surprise package Alavés. The Vitoria side look set to defy the odds once again - they lie third.

Finally, a little quiz for the medical staff at Rangers. Who was this weekend's goalscoring man of the match when Espanyol pulled themselves out of the relegation zone with a 2-0 win over Oviedo? Here's a little clue, boys - "if he plays again he could wreck his whole career".

fields.headline: Guide to newspaper mergers
fields.standfirst: Baffled by the ramifications of a Mail bid for the Express? MediaGuardian.co.uk offers you a print-out-and-keep guide to DTI newspaper merger rules.
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Baffled by the ramifications of a Mail bid for the Express? MediaGuardian.co.uk offers you a print-out-and-keep guide to DTI newspaper merger rules.
fields.body:
Q: What are the regulations governing newspaper takeovers?
A: Newspaper owners must obtain "prior consent" from the government to buy a newspaper which would take the joint circulation over 500,000.

Q: What happens if The Mail goes ahead with a formal bid?
A: The bid will be referred to the competition commission, which will investigate whether the move is against the public interest.

Q. What does the law guard against?
A. The 1973 Fair Trading Act protects against "the increasing concentration of newspaper ownership which could threaten the freedom and variety of expression of opinion and perhaps even the unbiased presentation of news".

Q: How would this apply in the case of the Mail and the Express?
A. The competition commission would look at the newspapers' share of the market and look for any unfair competition it would create through domination of the mid-market. It would also assess the threat to jobs at the title and investigate whether the buyer will run its new publication efficiently. If concerns on any of these issues are raised, then the commission could decide the takevoer threatens free expression of opinion.

Q. Is there any way the Mail could bypass the public interest test?
A. Yes. By proving the paper was going to close down unless it intervened. This is the so-called "financial urgency" clause of the Act.

Q. Has this rule ever been invoked before?
A. Yes. Rupert Murdoch swooped on the Times in 1980 a year after he had brazenly said he "would never buy the Times because it would be a highly irresponsible thing to do to your shareholders".

Q. How did Murdoch prove The Times was in dire straits?
A. Easy. Owner Roy Thomson said if would close the paper down before March 1981 if he didn't receive a bid.

Q.Has the financial urgency clause been invoked since?
A. Yes. You've guessed it - by Rupert Murdoch. When he bought the Today newspaper in 1987, the full colour tabloid founded by Eddie Shah and owned by Lonrho at the time. He bought it for £38m cash after delivering an ultimatum to Lord Young, the secretary of state for trade and industry. Murdoch warned if his the bid wasn't approved within 24 hours he would withdraw his offer.

Q. Will the Mail use this clause to get around the public interest test?
A. It might try to argue the Express is a going concern, but it is unlikely to be a successful tack to take with the government. Besides it will only work if the newspaper, not its parent group, has no cash in the bank and its backers have given a specific date for withdrawal of funds or closure of the title.

fields.headline: Defenders,  Demands, and  Destinations
fields.trailText: POOM DOOM
fields.body:
POOM DOOM

With November just a gusty gale away, things aren't looking good for Derby's Jim Smith. So far his team have yet to win a Premiership match or keep a clean sheet. Which isn't good news when Christmas is approaching and your new autobiography Jim Smith (by Jim Smith) isn't selling - although at a hefty £17.99, perhaps that's not a surprise. But at least, thought the Fiver as it loitered around Pride Park today, the Bald Eagle's side is united. United behind Jim's canny "let's change our formation for every game" policy, and united in the hope Derby's luck will soon change.

But then we bumped into Melancholy Mart Poom. "We are not good enough," he wailed, as he put his Best of the Smiths CD back in the case. "In some games we haven't matched the quality of the other teams. It's as simple as that. We are not good enough." The Fiver patted him on the back, but just as Doomy Poomy was calming down, we happened to mumble something about bad luck and he was off again. "You can say that over three or four games you might not have had the luck and that you did not deserve to get beat," he stated mournfully. "Now we have now played 11 Premiership games and we are bottom - and the table doesn't lie. We are simply not good enough."

Worried that "we are not good enough" was becoming Marty's mantra, the Fiver reminded him of all those sterling Derby comebacks. To no avail. "We gave up too easily against Liverpool and if you do that teams will hammer you. We have to show more pride," he pun-tastically claimed. And before he left to get his hair styled into a Morrissey-esque quiff, there was just time for him to have a go at the Bald Eagle too. "We still haven't got a clean sheet and I think it would help our cause if we had a stable back line," he sniped. "We seem to change the formation at the back and the personnel. We have to get some stability there and don't change things every game," he continued, hurling Jim Smith (by Jim Smith) into the bin alongside the gladioli he had been keeping in his back pocket.

JUST DON'T DO IT

Manchester United look lovely in their tonal knitted shirts, don't they? After all, what could possibly be more aesthetically pleasing than the sight of warm phlegm spilling from Phil Neville's permanently open mouth and on to his red sportswool top with lateral mesh panels inserted for improved breathability? But fast forward a couple of years: how attractive would you still find the sexy defender if his shirt was now stitched together by the trembling hands of an exploited child?

Michael Crick wouldn't be stirred by such a picture, that's for sure. The vice chair of pressure group Shareholders United today called on the Old Trafford giants to reconsider their reported new kit deal with Nike after everybody's favourite sportswear capitalists were once again accused of using child labour. "Manchester United plc opposes the exploitation of child labour. No orders will be placed from suppliers employing child labour under the age allowed in the country concerned," Crick quoted from article 1.6 of United's club charter.

"There have been serious allegations over the years about Nike's use of child labour, most recently in a Panorama programme earlier this month," he continued, getting nicely bolshie. "Shareholders United urge that Manchester United should not conclude any deal with Nike until totally satisfied that they are 100% clean on the issue." There was a time when the Fiver would have had a pop at United for being pompous enough to create a "charter", but as it may do some good, we can only praise them for taking a principled stance. Unless they choose to ignore Mr Crick and go for the dollar instead ... but they wouldn't do that, would they?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Actually, we are going to try and do the treble, although I'm not sure that is possible" - Russell Latapy sets his sights high. But if Manchester United can do it, why can't Hibernian?

THE NEW KOOG

Leicester City may not be the first choice for the turncoat offspring of former England-internationals-cum-television-presenters, but the Foxes must have a certain something. The team lies fourth in the Premiership. The FA has asked the manager to choose the England team for the game against Italy. And now it seems as though the world and his wife want to perform with an orange fox in a blue circle upon their chest.

For example, midfielder Jody Morris, who does not play for Chelsea, today announced his desire to play for Peter Taylor's side. Speaking in the Daily Mail, his agent Jonathan Barnett said: "Jody is close to Taylor. If a chance came to move to Leicester he wouldn't say no." Meanwhile, semi-popular Ipswich striker James Scowcroft is also reportedly interested in a move to the Midlands - Taylor was given an encouraging response from Town boss George Burley when he asked whether Scowcroft would be available.

Real Madrid midfielder Ivan Helguera has played down rumours linking him with Manchester United. "I'm not planning on going anywhere," he insisted. "If it is true, then it's always nice that a big club asks about you, but I'm happy at Real Madrid and I'm not thinking about a move anywhere."

Norwegian U-21 international Ragnvald Soma will play a trial match for West Ham tomorrow - and, if he impresses, the Bryne player will complete a £1.6m move to Upton Park.

Steve Coppell is favourite to become Huddersfield's next manager.

Arsenal's George Graham, manager of Tottenham, has been given a vote of confidence by Sir Alan Sugar, despite Saturday's 3-0 defeat at Chelsea. "George Graham's past history makes him one of the best managers in the Premier League," said Sugar. "We are building for the future and must take a patient and cautious approach. There is no question of George Graham being asked to leave Tottenham."

Milan will not face any punishment after playing Brazilian goalkeeper Nelson Dida in Big Cup this season. A Uefa spokesman said: "The player was registered as a Brazilian player for Uefa competitions. If there is any debate as to his citizenship, that is a matter for the Italian authorities."

Paraguayan international goalkeeper Jose Luis Chilavert is set to sign for struggling French first division side Strasbourg for £1.5m.

Goals by Kelly Smith and Karen Walker helped England's women football team to a 2-1 away win against Ukraine this afternoon, in a qualification play-off for the European Women's Championship finals.

Weak football, if you're starting.

Which isn't good news when Christmas is approaching and your new autobiography Jim Smith (by Jim Smith) isn't selling - although at a hefty £17.99, perhaps that's not a surprise. But at least, thought the Fiver as it loitered around Pride Park today, the Bald Eagle's side is united. United behind Jim's canny "let's change our formation for every game" policy, and united in the hope Derby's luck will soon change. But then we bumped into Melancholy Mart Poom. "We are not good enough," he wailed, as he put his Best of the Smiths CD back in the case. "In some games we haven't matched the quality of the other teams. It's as simple as that. We are not good enough." The Fiver patted him on the back, but just as Doomy Poomy was calming down, we happened to mumble something about bad luck and he was off again. "You can say that over three or four games you might not have had the luck and that you did not deserve to get beat," he stated mournfully. Worried that "we are not good enough" was becoming Marty's mantra, the Fiver reminded him of all those sterling Derby comebacks. To no avail. "We gave up too easily against Liverpool and if you do that teams will hammer you. We have to show more pride," he pun-tastically claimed. webTitle: Barak's political life on knife edge again

fields.headline: Barak's political life on knife edge again
fields.standfirst: Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has the support of only a quarter of his parliament but, as Derek Brown writes, all is not lost - yet
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has the support of only a quarter of his parliament but, as Derek Brown writes, all is not lost - yet
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak is battling for political survival. His hopes of forming an emergency government of national unity are fading, and he is now supported by just 30 members in the 120-seat Knesset (parliament).

On the face of it, Barak is doomed. But in Israel nothing is clear-cut. The orthodox religious party, Shas, has indicated that it will not vote to bring down the government at a time of national crisis. That declaration, and the likely support of some minor leftist factions, could buoy up the beleaguered government for a time yet.

Crucial to its survival, however, is the attitude of the 10 Arab MKs (Members of the Knesset). Right now, they are furious with the government for, as they see it, presiding over the draconian response to this month's rioting in Arab areas of Israel.

Hours before today's opening of the Knesset winter session after a recess of three months, the Arab MKs called for a minute's silence for the 13 'martyrs' who were killed in the disturbances. That proposal enraged rightwing members, who proposed that the Arab lawmakers be obliged to take an oath of loyalty to the 'Jewish democratic state of Israel'.

The nakedly racist suggestion was slapped down, but not before it had outraged the Arab MKs. They, like the vast majority of Israel's million-strong Arab minority, identify closely with the Palestinians of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, but believe that the Arabs within Israel proper should be treated as any other citizens.

They, like the Palestinians, are appalled that Barak should now be negotiating to recruit Israel's leading hawk, Ariel Sharon, into his government. Sharon is loathed by most Arabs in the region, who hold him responsible for triggering the latest intifada (uprising) by insisting on visiting Islamic holy sites in Jerusalem.

But as the MKs brace themselves for what will surely be, even by their rowdy standards, a memorably bad-tempered session, all the signs are that Sharon will not be joining the government - yet.

He has publicly demanded as the price of his cooperation that Barak, in effect, tear up the seven-year-old peace accord with the Palestinians.

The prime minister, however, has declared that he remains fully committed to the peace process. And there are signs that, even as the ghastly bloodletting goes on, he is preparing for new contacts with Palestinian president Yasser Arafat.

The first approach will be made by veteran negotiator and former prime minister Shimon Peres, one of the few Israeli leaders whom Arafat trusts. The meeting could be held in Egypt this week, but with gunfire still crackling along Israel's boundaries with the occupied territories, the prospects are not bright.

fields.headline: Press Association reshuffles sports division
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: The Press Association's sports division, PA Sport, has promoted key editorial staff in an expansion of its news services, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Chris Buckley, director of sports services for the Press Association, has been promoted to managing director of the division as part of a management restructuring.

As part of the reorganisation, PA sports editor Andy Elliott has been promoted to editorial director of PA Sport; while sports data editor Jim Donnelley is to become racing and betting director as part of a drive to beef up the agency's services in this area.

Mr Buckley has been with PA since 1996. He joined the PA News Board in 1998 and was made director of sports services earlier this year.

Mr Elliott joined the news agency in 1997 as sports editor from the Sun, where he was assistant sports editor; while Mr Donnelley has been with PA for 12 years and oversaw the relocation of PA Sport from London to Leeds in 1993.

PA Sport has 95 full-time journalists based in its Leeds HQ and around the country, as well as 500 casuals and correspondents. The outfit has been expanding recently in the area real-time sports information and data.

Mr Buckley said: "We have become the leading supplier and our management reorganisation will help us keep at the forefront. The business is growing all the time, not just through our comprehensive wire services which serves all the major print media and broadcasters in the UK, but also from new media organisations."

PA chief executive Paul Potts added: "This represents a significant expansion of PA Sport that not only recognises the growth and changes in sports coverage but also the ambition to continue to strengthen our sports services for all our customers."

webTitle: Inzamam leads Pakistan to series win

fields.headline: Inzamam leads Pakistan to series win
fields.standfirst:
England 158 (42.5 overs)
Pakistan 161 for 4 (43.3 overs)
Pakistan won by 6 wkts
fields.trailText: Pakistan innings
fields.body:
Pakistan innings

Pakistan have won the third one-day international against England at Rawalpindi and with it the series, by two games to one. They reached their target of 159 with more than six overs to spare and for the loss of just four wickets. After their hammering in Karachi, Pakistan have reasserted themselves brilliantly.

A careful fourth-wicket stand of 77 in almost 25 overs between Inzamam-ul-Haq and Yousuf Youhana came to an end the ball after Youhana had showed some rare aggression, flicking Craig White through square-leg for four. He then heaved wildly, missed and the ball cannoned into the base of off stump. Youhana had made 31 off 90 balls - not usually enough to win a one-day international, but England's batting effort meant Pakistan were never hurried.

At 128 for 4, Pakistan were virtually home and dry, and Inzamam moved to his half-century, from 96 deliveries, before Adur Razzaq, whose 75* at Karachi was quickly forgotten after Flintoff's fireworks, launched Andy Caddick over mid-off for four. He creamed the next ball through the covers.

Inzamam was badly missed by Ashley Giles at mid-off in the next over and should have been run out with seven needed after a characteristic mix-up, but Pakistan knocked off the remaining runs with ease. Inzamam finished unbeaten on 60, and Razzaq cracked a nine-ball 17.

England now have to work out how to play the spinners before the Test series starts in Lahore on November 15.

35-over update

Inzamam-ul-Haq and Yousuf Youhana had extended their fourth-wicket partnership to 54 after 35 overs of Pakistan's reply to England's 158. At that point Pakistan were 105 for 3, and on course for a comfortable, if dull victory in the one-day series.

England's bowlers were doing a good containing job - just 54 runs had come from the previous 20 overs - but Pakistan never needed to score at much more than three an over, and you always felt they would move up a gear if they had to.

Mark Ealham (5-0-9-0) took the pace off the ball on a slow pitch that offered turn, while Ashley Giles (8-0-24-1) at least offered some hope for the Test series ahead by finding bounce and maintaining an accurate line.

But England were unable to make the breakthrough they needed, and when the 100 came up in the 35th over, a baying crowd was already celebrating. Inzamam brought up the 50 stand by pulling Darren Gough's slower ball over midwicket for four, and England were left needing something special.

25-over update

Pakistan should go on to win the third one-day international at Rawalpindi - and with it the series - but England's bowlers are making them work hard for the 159 they need. After 25 overs they had crawled to 72 for 3, having scored just 21 runs in their last 10. Inzamam-ul-Haq was not out 24 from 52 balls, while Yousuf Youhana had 6 from 37.

The bowlers who put on the brakes were Craig White and Ashley Giles. White made good use of the slower ball to complete an outstanding first spell of 6-2-9-0 - four of those runs came when Inzamam top-edged a slower ball just in front of Alec Stewart and away to the boundary.

Giles was almost as parsimonious, and found a good line and length to restrict the batsmen to pushed singles on the legside. Inzamam did crash the final ball of his sixth over to the cover boundary, but Giles's figures still read 6-0-16-1.

But for all England's thrift, they still needed wickets. And while Inzamam was still there, Pakistan were red-hot favourites.

15-over update

Pakistan reached 51 for 3 after 15 overs, and needed a further 108 to clinch the one-day series against England. Andy Caddick took two early wickets to bring England back into the game, and they almost picked up a third when Graeme Hick just failed to cling on to a tough chance, diving to his right at second slip after Darren Gough had found the outside edge of Salim Elahi's bat. That would have made it 17 for 3.

Instead Elahi and Inzamam-ul-Haq progressed steadily against some tight bowling. Gough bowled consecutive maidens, and England were outstanding in the field. One stop by Nasser Hussain, diving full stretch at gully to stop a fierce drive from Elahi, was as good as anything Jonty Rhodes could do.

Elahi did find the boundary in the 13th over though, following a gorgeous square-drive off Caddick for four with a straight-driven thump two balls later.

Hussain threw the ball to Ashley Giles in the 15th over - and England snared their third wicket. The ball after Pakistan had moved to 50, Elahi nibbled at one outside off stump that turned and bounced and Hussain held on at slip to make it 51 for 3. Elahi had made 23 and England were back in it.

3-over update

Andy Caddick struck twice in two balls to give England an outside chance in the crucial third one-day international against Pakistan at Rawalpindi. With the final ball of his first over he found some extra bounce outside off stump and Imran Nazir could only edge to Graeme Hick who dived to his left at second slip. 0 for 1.

Shahid Afridi fought back in the next over, driving and pulling Darren Gough for consecutive boundaries, but he soon became Caddick's second victim. Aiming to drive the first ball of Caddick's second over, he picked out Nasser Hussain at point to make it 9 for 2.

Inzamam-ul-Haq survived the hat-trick ball, but England were in with a shout.

England innings

End-of-innings update

England were dismissed for 158 in the third and deciding one-dayer by Pakistan at Rawalpindi after another dismal performance against the spinners. There were still 43 balls remaining when the latest chapter in The Andy Caddick Guide to Hairbrained Singles was written and Graham Thorpe was run out for 39 with both batsmen stuck at the same end. It was a fitting end to a farcical innings, which was twice interrupted by tear gas drifting onto the field.

A steady seventh-wicket stand of 47 between Thorpe and Mark Ealham (who should be ahead of Craig White in the order) came to an end when Abdur Razzaq got one to nip back between Ealham's bat and pad and hit the top of middle and off. It was Razzaq's 100th one-day international wicket, and it left England 133 for 7 in the 37th over.

The 150 came up in the 40th, and the tear gas struck again before Saqlain Mushtaq won a leg-before shout against Ashley Giles. The ball went straight on and hit Giles on the back leg, although there must have been some doubt as to whether it would have gone on to hit leg. It may not have been Saqlain's doosra, but Giles looked mystified nonetheless and left the field for 11 to make it 156 for 8.

Two balls later it was 156 for 9: Darren Gough tried to sweep Saqlain but the ball ricocheted back onto his stumps. It was Saqlain's fifth wicket - for just 20 runs - and the 15th England have lost in the series to spin - as against seven to seam. Thorpe had hung on gamely for 71 balls, but fell victim to Caddick's cock-up.

Pakistan surely won't blow it from here.

35-over update

Graham Thorpe and Mark Ealham were at least giving England a total to defend after the top-order had again made a mess of playing Pakistan's spinners in the deciding one-dayer at Rawalpindi. After 35 overs, England had stumbled to 128 for 6, with the seventh-wicket partnership worth 42.

England lost their sixth wicket in the 24th over, at which stage their only aim was to bat out their 50 overs. Runs came at a trickle, and the 100 arrived in the 29th over when Ealham swept a Shahid Afridi no-ball for four. It was England's first boundary for nine overs.

Two overs later Ealham used his feet to biff Afridi over mid-on for four more. Thorpe, who passed 2000 runs in one-day internationals earlier in his innings, was content with ones and twos. England will need more than that if they're going to set Pakistan an even remotely challenging total.

25-over update

England were heading for a big defeat in the deciding one-dayer against Pakistan at Rawalpindi. After 25 overs they had slumped to 91 for 6 after another limp display against Pakistan's spinners. It could be a long tour.

Andy Flintoff and Graham Thorpe had demonstrated for a while what can be achieved with straight hitting and good footwork. When Mushtaq Ahmed dropped short, Flintoff stood up, and hit him along the ground back past him for four. And in the next over Thorpe thumped his Surrey colleague Saqlain Mushtaq over his head for four more - an unusual shot for a man who rarely hits it in the air unless he's playing the hook or the pull.

Runs came easily for a couple of overs, but England lost their fifth wicket in Shahid Afridi's first over as Flintoff propped forward at a ball that turned slightly and edged a catch to Ahzar Mahmood at slip for 10 to make it 85 for 5.

In the next over Craig White played a shot he will want to forget. Saqlain delivered a rare full toss, White's eyes lit up and he hoicked it in the direction of the square-leg boundary - and straight towards Mushtaq Ahmed who completed a good catch diving forward. Saqlain smiled, White winced. His scores in this one-day series have been 0*, 0 and 0. At No. 7 in the order, White is a place too high.

England's challenge now was to bat out their 50 overs.

16-over update

England lost two wickets to Saqlain Mushtaq in the 16th over and were reeling at 64 for 4 after a decent start. In Lahore, Alec Stewart fell to the first ball from Mushtaq Ahmed, trying to disrupt him from the start. Now Graeme Hick was dismissed by Saqlain Mushtaq's first delivery, again to an attacking shot. The ball pitched outside off, Hick aimed a big drive and the ball spun back sharply through the gate. It was the sort of delivery with which Muttiah Muralitharan tormented England at The Oval in 1998. Hick departed for 3, and England were 63 for 3.

Worse was to follow. Four balls later, Marcus Trescothick went back and tried to work a ball through the legside. But he missed and it hit the top of off. Saqlain's celebrations were muted - you sensed he didn't regard dismissing top-order English batsmen as much of a challenge. Trescothick had made 36, and England were up against it.

15-over update

England made fitful progress in the third and deciding one-day international against Pakistan at Rawalpindi, and had reached 63 for 2 after 15 overs. Pakistan won the toss for the third consecutive match and opted to try to exploit any early movement in the wicket. The ploy worked well as Abdur Razzaq maintained a tight line outside off, and Wasim Akram troubled the right-handers as the ball slanted across.

The bowlers dropped short occasionally, and England duly cashed in: in the fifth over, Marcus Trescothick pulled Wasim backward of square for four, and three overs later Alec Stewart slashed a Razzaq long hop through the covers.

Moments later something happened that may be unique: tear gas stopped play. It had drifted onto the pitch from outside the stadium, and reduced Trescothick and Stewart to lachrymose wrecks - the Pakistanis seemed less troubled.
