fields.bodyText: Pakistan innings Pakistan have won the third one-day international against England at Rawalpindi and with it the series, by two games to one. They reached their target of 159 with more than six overs to spare and for the loss of just four wickets. After their hammering in Karachi, Pakistan have reasserted themselves brilliantly. A careful fourth-wicket stand of 77 in almost 25 overs between Inzamam-ul-Haq and Yousuf Youhana came to an end the ball after Youhana had showed some rare aggression, flicking Craig White through square-leg for four. He then heaved wildly, missed and the ball cannoned into the base of off stump. Youhana had made 31 off 90 balls - not usually enough to win a one-day international, but England's batting effort meant Pakistan were never hurried. At 128 for 4, Pakistan were virtually home and dry, and Inzamam moved to his half-century, from 96 deliveries, before Adur Razzaq, whose 75* at Karachi was quickly forgotten after Flintoff's fireworks, launched Andy Caddick over mid-off for four. He creamed the next ball through the covers. Inzamam was badly missed by Ashley Giles at mid-off in the next over and should have been run out with seven needed after a characteristic mix-up, but Pakistan knocked off the remaining runs with ease. Inzamam finished unbeaten on 60, and Razzaq cracked a nine-ball 17. England now have to work out how to play the spinners before the Test series starts in Lahore on November 15. 35-over update Inzamam-ul-Haq and Yousuf Youhana had extended their fourth-wicket partnership to 54 after 35 overs of Pakistan's reply to England's 158. At that point Pakistan were 105 for 3, and on course for a comfortable, if dull victory in the one-day series. England's bowlers were doing a good containing job - just 54 runs had come from the previous 20 overs - but Pakistan never needed to score at much more than three an over, and you always felt they would move up a gear if they had to. Mark Ealham (5-0-9-0) took the pace off the ball on a slow pitch that offered turn, while Ashley Giles (8-0-24-1) at least offered some hope for the Test series ahead by finding bounce and maintaining an accurate line. But England were unable to make the breakthrough they needed, and when the 100 came up in the 35th over, a baying crowd was already celebrating. Inzamam brought up the 50 stand by pulling Darren Gough's slower ball over midwicket for four, and England were left needing something special. 25-over update Pakistan should go on to win the third one-day international at Rawalpindi - and with it the series - but England's bowlers are making them work hard for the 159 they need. After 25 overs they had crawled to 72 for 3, having scored just 21 runs in their last 10. Inzamam-ul-Haq was not out 24 from 52 balls, while Yousuf Youhana had 6 from 37. The bowlers who put on the brakes were Craig White and Ashley Giles. White made good use of the slower ball to complete an outstanding first spell of 6-2-9-0 - four of those runs came when Inzamam top-edged a slower ball just in front of Alec Stewart and away to the boundary. Giles was almost as parsimonious, and found a good line and length to restrict the batsmen to pushed singles on the legside. Inzamam did crash the final ball of his sixth over to the cover boundary, but Giles's figures still read 6-0-16-1. But for all England's thrift, they still needed wickets. And while Inzamam was still there, Pakistan were red-hot favourites. 15-over update Pakistan reached 51 for 3 after 15 overs, and needed a further 108 to clinch the one-day series against England. Andy Caddick took two early wickets to bring England back into the game, and they almost picked up a third when Graeme Hick just failed to cling on to a tough chance, diving to his right at second slip after Darren Gough had found the outside edge of Salim Elahi's bat. That would have made it 17 for 3. Instead Elahi and Inzamam-ul-Haq progressed steadily against some tight bowling. Gough bowled consecutive maidens, and England were outstanding in the field. One stop by Nasser Hussain, diving full stretch at gully to stop a fierce drive from Elahi, was as good as anything Jonty Rhodes could do. Elahi did find the boundary in the 13th over though, following a gorgeous square-drive off Caddick for four with a straight-driven thump two balls later. Hussain threw the ball to Ashley Giles in the 15th over - and England snared their third wicket. The ball after Pakistan had moved to 50, Elahi nibbled at one outside off stump that turned and bounced and Hussain held on at slip to make it 51 for 3. Elahi had made 23 and England were back in it. 3-over update Andy Caddick struck twice in two balls to give England an outside chance in the crucial third one-day international against Pakistan at Rawalpindi. With the final ball of his first over he found some extra bounce outside off stump and Imran Nazir could only edge to Graeme Hick who dived to his left at second slip. 0 for 1. Shahid Afridi fought back in the next over, driving and pulling Darren Gough for consecutive boundaries, but he soon became Caddick's second victim. Aiming to drive the first ball of Caddick's second over, he picked out Nasser Hussain at point to make it 9 for 2. Inzamam-ul-Haq survived the hat-trick ball, but England were in with a shout. England innings End-of-innings update England were dismissed for 158 in the third and deciding one-dayer by Pakistan at Rawalpindi after another dismal performance against the spinners. There were still 43 balls remaining when the latest chapter in The Andy Caddick Guide to Hairbrained Singles was written and Graham Thorpe was run out for 39 with both batsmen stuck at the same end. It was a fitting end to a farcical innings, which was twice interrupted by tear gas drifting onto the field. webTitle: Gore and Clinton stay just in front

fields.headline: Gore and Clinton stay just in front
fields.standfirst: With the American elections elections just over a week away, Derek Brown looks at how the New York press is viewing the situation
fields.trailText: With the American elections elections just over a week away, Derek Brown looks at how the New York press is viewing the situation.
fields.body:
With little more than a week to go, America's third best-known candidate is running neck to neck with her opponent in New York state.

Hillary Rodham Clinton, the first lady, is eight points clear of Rick Lazio, according to a poll in this morning's New York Times.

But another reputable polling organisation, working for the Times's raucous rival the New York Post, puts Lazio two points ahead.

Newspapers in the state agree that turn out will be crucial to Clinton's attempt to launch her own political career in the US Senate.

The New York Times, which has endorsed Al Gore in the main national race, points out the paradox that Clinton could be undermined by the apparently unassailable campaign by the Democrat presidential candidate.

The paper says that, "if it appears that vice president Al Gore is going to win New York easily - this poll suggests that he is 21 points ahead of George W Bush in New York, 52 percent to 31 percent - then Democrats may not bother to turn out in the numbers Mrs Clinton needs to win the race."

The Times also slyly points out that Lazio may have scored an own goal by launching his most trenchant criticism of Clinton, over her role in health care legislation, during the sensational baseball World Series, featuring the New York Yankees and the New York Mets.

Nobody in the city, it seems, was paying much attention to politics last week.

The New York Post rather underscores the point.

Its lead story is the celebratory tickertape parade by the victorious Yankees. Inside, it runs an editorial acid attack on Democrat vice-presidential candidate Joe Lieberman, who is also running for the Senate in Connecticut.

It starts: "Does Joe Lieberman know something that nobody else does? Or is he just trying to have it both ways?"

It goes on to question Lieberman's apparently radical shift of views towards Al Gore's liberal line, and concludes: "So maybe it's not all that surprising that Lieberman decided to maintain a Connecticut bolt-hole. It's all about what's best for Joe, no?"

The Post also gives prominence to the nasty tale of the Republican telephone campaign to discredit Hillary Clinton by linking her to the terror bombing of the US Navy destroyer Dole in Yemen a few weeks ago.

The party has wisely dropped the outrageous message, which was relayed to thousands of non-Jewish voters and accused Clinton of accepting money from an Arab organisation that "openly brags about its support for a Mideast terrorism group, the same kind of terrorism that killed our sailors on the USS Cole."

The equally strident New York Daily News - one of its main news stories is headed "Judge could nix slay rap" - wastes little time on political analysis.

But it does approve of Chelsea Clinton. In a long piece, the paper notes how she is helping her mother's campaign.

"Much about Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton's marriage remains a mystery, but they have indisputably raised a fine daughter - by all accounts, down to earth and spectacularly normal, but equipped with an extraordinary inner strength to endure when her family's private matters came under the harshest of public spotlights.

"It's a reason why Chelsea, a 20-year-old college student, has become such an asset to her mother's Senate campaign - and also a stand-in for the First Lady in her father's waning days in the White House."

It is, as Americans say, a given that, while New York city remains solidly Democrat, the rest of the sprawling state tilts towards the Republicans.

That is reflected in the Poughkeepsie Journal, which restricts is coverage of the senatorial race to a glowing account of a Lazio fundraising dinner.

The Albany Times Union believes the Lazio campaign is faltering in the traditional conservative parts of the state.

The paper highlights the crucial importance of the black vote: "US Senator Chuck Schumer won his 1998 race against incumbent Alfonse D'Amato, a Republican, with 87 per cent of the black vote.

"This year, African-Americans support Clinton over Lazio by a ratio of 93-3, according to a recent Quinnipiac University poll."

The paper also notes that the Clinton campaign too has had its up and down moments: "In Ithaca, she was greeted by an enthusiastic crowd - and a man shouting, 'Mrs Clinton, who did your husband rape today'?"

The Schenectady Daily Gazette reports Al Gore's latest barnstorming tour of California, to shore up his sagging support in a state where many had assumed his victory to be assured.

The paper notes his shift to negative attacks on George W Bush's lack of experience

"Late Saturday night, Gore signalled the shift in focus in commenting on his endorsement by The New York Times, which said Bush's knowledge and resume were lacking. 'My already high estimation of The New York Times has risen even further,' Gore told reporters aboard Air Force Two."

fields.headline: Dixons poaches Barclays adman
fields.trailText: 4pm: Dixons has poached John Laidlaw from Barclays Bank as its new advertising director, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Dixons Stores has poached John Laidlaw from Barclays Bank as its new advertising director.

Mr Laidlaw will oversee the advertising for all the brands in the Dixons group, which includes Currys, PC World and The Link, as well as Dixons.

Dixons Stores is one of the UK's biggest advertisers, having spent £20m on advertising for the Dixons chain alone last year.

Mr Laidlaw will report to Dixons' group marketing services director, Elizabeth Fagan.

Ms Fagan said: "I am delighted to announce John's appointment. He brings a wealth of blue-chip brand development, marketing and advertising experience. I am confident that he will be a valued addition to our marketing services team."

webTitle: DTI to investigate BAT smuggling claims

fields.headline: DTI to investigate BAT smuggling claims
fields.trailText: The Department of Trade and Industry is to launch an investigation into allegations that tobacco giant British American Tobacco is implicated in smuggling, it said today.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry is to launch an investigation into allegations that tobacco giant British American Tobacco is implicated in smuggling, it said today.

Secretary of State Stephen Byers said that he had appointed investigators to look into the allegations in response to a Health Select Committee report on the tobacco industry.

He said: "I have given careful consideration to the unanimous recommendation of the select committee that the DTI should investigate the allegations of BAT's involvement in smuggling.

"I have decided to appoint investigators to look into this and to report back to me as soon as possible.

"I will then decide what further steps I must take and whether the facts support a reference to other authorities."

BAT said in a statement that it was "naturally disappointed" at the move by Mr Byers.

"We will, of course, cooperate fully with the investigators, but will be making no further comments during the course of their work," it said.

A spokeswoman for Conservative former chancellor Kenneth Clarke said that Mr Clarke, as deputy chairman for BAT, had no comment to make.

"Mr Clarke is not making a statement. The company has done so," she said.

In February, Mr Clarke sought to rebut accusations that BAT was involved in large-scale cigarette smuggling and that it indirectly encouraged drug runners' money laundering operations.

The accusations stemmed from research conducted by the charity Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) and investigative journalist Duncan Campbell.

The allegations have also been aired by Channel 4 News. It was claimed that BAT's own internal documentation demonstrated that the company was involved in orchestrating, managing and controlling cigarette smuggling in Asia and Latin America in the early 1990s, with BAT exercising control over illegal distribution channels through intermediaries.

But Mr Clarke, a former health secretary as well as chancellor, told the House of Commons select committee on health that the accusations were unfounded.

Mr Clarke acknowledged that cigarettes were smuggled into markets such as Colombia, but insisted that BAT was not involved in that process.

"There is no evidence I have ever seen that BAT is a participant in this smuggling. We seek to minimise it and avoid it," Mr Clarke told the committee.

Mr Clarke insisted that BAT was "a company of integrity and a good corporate citizen", which observed not only the requirements of the law in the countries in which it operated, but also "good ethical standards".

BAT chairman Martin Broughton also denied, before the committee's February hearing, any wrongdoing on his company's part.

Asked if he refuted the accusations that the company was involved in managing cigarette smuggling and money laundering, he insisted: "I refute those (accusations) completely."

In what was often a heated session, at one point Mr Broughton demonstrated his feelings about Mr Campbell's research by tearing up one document that the journalist presented as part of his efforts to substantiate his claims.

In his evidence to the committee, Mr Campbell explained that South American-based drug runners raise huge sums by smuggling narcotics such as cocaine and heroin into the United States, then "launder" the dollars generated by using them to buy cigarettes, which are smuggled back into their own countries.

Mr Campbell claimed that BAT "assiduously" and "deliberately" supported the cigarette smuggling market.

In June, in a report it published on the impact of smoking, the committee called for an inquiry into the allegations.

Director of Ash Clive Bates said: "We think the evidence that BAT has been controlling and facilitating tobacco smuggling is overwhelming.

"We are just delighted that the DTI is going to hold them to account. I think this will be a turning point in the fight against tobacco smuggling, because the authorities will have the evidence that the tobacco industry itself is a major player in global smuggling.

"The tobacco industry will no longer be seen as friends but somebody working hand-in-glove with organised crime.

"While not doing the smuggling themselves, they are doing everything necessary to make sure smuggling happens in their commercial interests and on a very large scale," he said.

fields.headline: Coney Island baby
fields.standfirst: Darren Aronofsky was invited to make the new Batman movie. Instead he filmed addicts in Brooklyn. Danny Leigh reports
fields.trailText: Darren Aronofsky was invited to make the new Batman movie. Instead he filmed addicts in Brooklyn.
fields.body:
For the hip American director under 30, there's a certain way of doing things. You pull in some favours, you scrape together a budget (a few thousand dollars on a credit card), you make your movie. Make it startle, make it in raw, attention-grabbing black and white and, with luck, it'll make you a star: Hollywood awaits. Which is precisely how life was shaping up for Darren Aronofsky after his 1998 debut, the paranoid, iconoclastic Pi. Two years later, the Brooklyn-born Aronofsky has hit paydirt, with a lucrative deal to write and direct his own contribution to the Batman franchise.

Except it wasn't as straightforward as that: following the acclaim that greeted Pi, Tinseltown and its caped crusaders were kept on hold a while longer. Edging still further from the mainstream, the then 28-year-old Aronofsky decided to work with Hubert Selby Jr, veteran gutter chronicler and author of Last Exit to Brooklyn. The result is Requiem for a Dream, a brutally seductive adaptation of Selby's 1978 novella, set against the faded funhouses of Coney Island, New York (a stone's throw from where both men grew up). The bleak, nerveless story of three twentysomething junkies, the middle-aged, diet-pill addicted mother of one, and - in Aronofsky's words - "the lengths we go to escape reality", it's one of the most harrowing films in years.

It's also one of the best, with a dazzling visual swagger and a slew of split screens and rapid-fire cuts - "hip-hop montage" is how Aronofsky describes it. "Stylistically," he explains, "I try be an expressionist, to use the camera to push the emotion of the scene. That's the goal, to marry style with performance. And there'll be some people who can't hang with that, because it's a young style. It's designed for people who grew up with a lot of visual stimulus."

He's not wrong. The danger, of course, is that among daintier critics such a freewheeling aesthetic could be dismissed as MTV film-making. "Well, that's the biggest insult that could be levelled at me," he says. "Because MTV is style without substance, and we discipline ourselves so that every stylistic choice we make has a solid narrative reason behind it." And, in fact, what that decision-making produces is a pure cinematic language that recalls a time before indie movies talked themselves into oblivion. Dealing with such potentially cumbersome material as heroin and self-help, Requiem says more with a single shot than a thousand lines of addled dialogue.

"The subject matter is so intense, and so dark, that if you made it like a Dogme movie it would basically be unwatchable," says Aronofsky. "The pyrotechnics make the film more accessible. This way, the narrative sneaks up on you emotionally."

Given the unflinching nature of the piece, "sneaks" is the wrong word: "mangles" might be more appropriate. But there is more to Requiem than visual gimcracks, not least the inspired performances Aronofsky elicits from his cast, in particularEllen Burstyn. Still best known as Linda Blair's mother in The Exorcist, here she is cast as Sara Goldfarb, a Brooklyn widow desperate to lose weight for a TV appearance.

"The thing about Ellen is that because of Hollywood's ageism and sexism, she really hasn't had a lead role since the 1970s. So, even though I was a big fan of her films back then, I really wasn't sure what she could do. But she showed the world. I mean, she certainly showed me." Equally, Burstyn's tour de force opens up the story beyond the confines (remarkable though they are) of the film's parallel storyline, in which Jared Leto (as Sara's dope-fiend son Harry), Marlon Wayans and Jennifer Connelly sacrifice everything for the "pound of pure" that will, in theory, put them on Easy Street.

"But the thing is," Aronofsky says, "I never wanted to make that film. For me, the most interesting part of the movie was always Sara, because of the counterpoint she offers. People have seen the junkie movie before, you know, but Sara elevated this film into a story of how we all struggle with addiction."

Heroin, to Aronofsky, is the least of it. "When you're chasing after a future you're never going to get, you create a hole in the present. You use anything to fill that hole, whether that's drugs, or the dream of a better life. And what happens is, the hole keeps growing until it engulfs you." Presumably that also goes for a film-maker as obsessive as Aronofsky? "Oh, definitely. Completely. Work fills the hole. Sure."

As, of course, do happy endings, Hollywood's holy grail, longed for but never found in Requiem for a Dream. With Batman in the bag ("I'll do it if they let me do it the way I want"), you might think Aronofsky was finally adjusting to the studios' value system. Then again, it may be some time before he's wheeling out soft, cuddly Hollywood product.

"Eighty per cent of ticket sales across the world go to Hollywood movies," he points out, "and because of that, people are almost brainwashed into expecting a catharsis. But anyone who's been on the planet long enough knows that, in the end, things seldom work out OK. That's what tragedy is about. And tragedy is an art form that's been killed by Hollywood. I mean, with Requiem, the catharsis is really there for the audience the day after they've seen the movie."

Slowly, he clears his throat. "Because, you know, it's certainly not happening on screen."

 Requiem for a Dream is screened as part of the London film festival on Saturday and November 6. Box office: 020-7928 3232. It will be released on January 19.

webTitle: Disaster archive to be launched online

fields.headline: Disaster archive to be launched online
fields.standfirst: Edge Hill college is to create a resource for both academics and those most closely connected with some of the country's most traumatic events
fields.trailText: Edge Hill college is to create a resource for both academics and those most closely connected with some of the countrys most traumatic events.
fields.body:
Hillsborough, Lockerbie, Dunblane - the grim rollcall of disasters has generated millions of words as emergency services, relatives, lawyers and politicians struggled to make sense of tragedy and prevent history repeating itself.

Material from these, and other disasters, is now to be gathered in a national archive at Edge Hill college of higher education which intends to make much of its non-sensitive material available online.

Director Phil Scraton wants relatives' groups and individuals to benefit as well as academic researchers: "What we want is to create an archive that is easily accessible and useful not only to academics and professionals but also to campaign groups and individuals. It is a way of supporting individuals to establish their rights, and supporting bereaved families and survivors of these disasters."

Howard Davis, senior research fellow, said disasters often highlighted more general problems for bereaved families such as the treatment of body parts and could have wider lessons. All people interviewed by researchers at the centre are assured that nothing will be revealed without their permission.

The Edge Hill centre at Ormskirk, Lancashire, worked on the Hillsborough disaster, initially funded by Liverpool City Council, producing two reports as well as Professor Scraton's own 1999 book, Hillsborough: The Truth.

Home Office funding also enabled the centre to widen its remit to include concerns relating to the treatment of the bereaved and survivors of other disasters particularly Lockerbie/Flight 103 and the sinking of the Marchioness. The findings of this two-year inquiry called for a charter for the bereaved in tragic circumstances.

A £9,300 award from the Nuffield foundation is to employ a part-time researcher to collect archive material, including documents relating to the Piper Alpha oil platform explosion in 1988 and the murders committed by Frederick and Rosemary West.

The collection will hold academic publications, media coverage and centre research. Civil and criminal legal material relating to the disasters, such as transcripts of court cases and reports and evidence given to inquiries and inquests, will also be included.

The archive is available at the centre for studies in crime and social justice

webTitle: Are storms the result of global warming?

fields.headline: Are storms the result of global warming?
fields.standfirst: As Britain recovers from the latest storms to cause chaos, environment correspondent Paul Brown looks at what has triggered such violent weather
fields.trailText: As Britain recovers from the latest storms to cause chaos, environment correspondent Paul Brown looks at what has triggered such violent weather.
fields.body:
Ten years ago, climate change was a worry far away on the horizon, more of concern to grandchildren, a problem that, as responsible citizens, we should tackle soon.

This week, as the south east of England was battered by the latest in a series of storms the threat seemed much more immediate - once in 30 years floods had come twice in a month to places in Kent and Sussex.

While all the international political focus has been on reducing carbon dioxide emissions to avert future global warming, an equally important second area of work has been progressing on local adaptation to its effects, which are soon to be.

In the UK there have been, so far largely unheeded warnings about not building on flood plains, plus unreported changes to building regulations so that tall buildings can withstand higher wind speeds.

The response to the danger of ever increasing sea levels has been to add another few feet to the height of sea walls around property on the coast and abandon some poorer quality agricultural land to the sea as no longer worth the expense of protecting.

It is the small beginning of a new era in a Britain and the rest of Europe that is used to a benign climate.

Extremes were always regarded as rare and generally happened somewhere else - the United States being a prime example.

Scientists are still reluctant to say that what is happening to the British climate can be blamed on global warming.

While they say that this is the sort of weather we could expect as a result of global warming, they say that current events have not been going on long enough to be sure.

But the evidence of climate change is building all the time.

On average, British birds nest two weeks earlier than 30 years ago. Insect species - including bees and termites - that need warmer weather to survive are moving north.

Some have already crossed the Channel from France. It is now warm enough for malaria mosquitoes to survive and breed in Sussex.

Glaciers in Europe are in retreat, particular in the Alps and Iceland. Icecaps throughout the world are getting smaller - even the North Pole was ice free for part of this summer.

Extremes of weather are driven by heat, together with the contrast between the hot tropics and the cold poles.

The warmer the sea the more intense the storms - and the average wave height in the Atlantic has increased - making the damage that a rise in sea level can do to the coast even greater.

If this is not climate change then it is a pretty good example of what to expect from now on. It seems the British fascination with the weather is set to continue.

webTitle: Mobile critters come to call in time for Christmas

fields.headline: Mobile critters come to call in time for Christmas
fields.standfirst:
Third generation technology is expected to trigger a boom in the multi-million wireless entertainment market
Net news
fields.trailText: Third generation technology is expected to trigger a boom in the multi-million wireless entertainment market
fields.body:
The internet revolution promised many things, but very few people predicted that it could turn your mobile phone into a virtual pet. By Christmas, a Scottish internet entrepreneur hopes to be offering users everything from cats and dogs to turtles and dinosaurs. The concept is not new. The Japanese came up with the idea of nurturing pets for entertainment, but Dumfermline-based Digital Bridges are the first to bring the critters to mobile phones.

Created by Kevin Bradshaw, a 31-year-old science graduate, Digital Bridges seems to have tapped a rich vein. The company has raised more than £10m and will double in size from 35 employees to 70 over the coming months. The focus is to develop games for mobiles that can be played for short bursts throughout the day.

Mr Bradshaw came up with the mobile idea about three years ago when he was completely immobile - stuck in a traffic jam on the M25 near Guildford. In the car he decided two things.

"The first thing I decided was to move back to Scotland and second, wouldn't it be good if I could build something that would actually allow me to have some fun in that dead time when I am sitting in my car. What if I could play chess against my brother or something like that. The best part of three years on and I've just about achieved them," the physics and computer science graduate says.

Customers already include Vodafone, One 2 One and France Telecom.

The company's founder aims to attract users like himself - cash-rich, time-poor. Mr Bradshaw spends so much of his time travelling that he only has about three days a month at his home in Scotland. He only eats sandwiches while on the run and says having a personal life is tricky.

At the moment the company has only published simple games such as Hangman and board games like noughts and crosses. But, as well as virtual pets, it is working on a wide range of games, including a fantasy football league without any famous players, so that everyone doesn't pick Manchester United's David Beckham, the company says.

Ahead of the game

"Right now, I think most people would say we are probably the market leader in this space," Mr Bradshaw says.

Other bigger players are waiting in the wings, however. Sci Entertainment Group, the London-based computer games publisher, is launching games such as Thunderbirds, Find A Blind Date, which matches romantics with their perfect partners, and Football Manager, that will use the mobile phone's text messaging system - SMS.

Mark Knutton, chief operating officer of Sci's mobile media, said: "The market is going to expand. It's not a question of if, it's when."

Mr Knutton thinks the development of technology - especially third generation mobile phones which will allow video images to be transmitted on mobile phones - will cause the market to take off.

Bigger guns have also made their presence felt. Nokia, one of the globe's biggest phone-makers, wants to develop games as a way of encouraging customers to spend more time on their mobile phones.

The company will tomorrow launch Nokia Game. This role-playing game is open to all mobile phone users across 18 European countries.

According to Nokia it will allow users "to step into the shoes of the main character in a fictional story. You will experience life from his point of view, along the way, encountering a series of problems that you'll have to solve on his - or her - behalf."

"Messages and clues will reach you via every imaginable media (Internet, TV, radio, voicemail, SMS, magazines and newspapers)".

For Nokia the attraction is obvious. Not only does the user have to follow the leads and stay connected by visiting Nokia web sites, it will keep players busy for a month. All this will mean more people using more mobiles.

Nokia is also giving old classic games a new lease of life - the new Nokia phone features Space Impact, essentially a a retread of space invaders.

It's a boom area. Forecasts suggest by 2005 there will be 198m mobile phone users playing wireless games in Western Europe and the US - generating $6bn.

Many analysts are wary. Peter Joseph, an analyst at Peel Hunt stockbrokers accepts that it is potentially a huge area, but believes it is too early to say what will happen to the sector and who the big winners and losers will be.

"The mobile games industry is at the earliest stage it could be", Mr Joseph said.

Miles Saltiel, head of research at West L B Panmure, is also sceptical. He believes the sector will grow, but points to the limitations of small screens - which make games hard to play.

So how do companies aim to make money? Digital Bridges claims that it will recoup investors cash with a "pay per play" model.

Mr Bradshaw claims that between 3,000 and 4,000 of its games are played every day and thinks there will be a worldwide audience of 1bn people in the next three or four years.

In the fantasy football world that Mr Bradshaw's company is working on, users choose and train their teams and get a result and commentary on the match after it has been played overnight on the server. As people register they are placed into leagues and they can be promoted, relegated, and there are also inter-league transfers. Eventually inter-league tournaments, internationals and world cup events will be arranged and attended by the best teams in the world.

This community side of things, where people compete against other people and can email each other, Digital Bridges believes, will keep users coming back.

As for Mr Bradshaw, who has a DPhil in Computer Sciences from Oxford University and plays games on his phone four or five times a day, he keeps working so that he can turn his vision of running a highly profitable company into a reality. He hopes he will have achieved his dream in the next five years. He will then, he thinks, have time to drive his classic Alfa Spider car, dabble in other people's business' and spend a lot of time on a hot beach.

fields.headline: Guardian launches public sector website
fields.trailText: 2.30pm The Guardian is expanding its online operation with the launch of SocietyGuardian.co.uk, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Guardian is expanding its online operation with the launch of SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

The site, which launches next month, will provide news and information and job advertising for the public and voluntary sectors. It will be aimed at those working in the health, social care, regeneration, housing, local government and charity fields.

Carolyn McCall, managing director of GNL, said: "Over 21 years the Guardian has built a strong reputation as a national platform for all areas of the public sector. The new site will build on that reputation and provide new commercial opportunities for GNL.

"As well as carrying the most jobs and the most extensive quality editorial for this sector, the site will provide a place for communities to thrive by sharing experiences and information on its talkboards."

Sue Tollerfield, public sector manager at the Guardian's classified department, becomes general manager responsible for commercial development.

Marianne Curphey, launch editor of GNL's personal finance website, Money Unlimited, becomes executive editor.
fields.bodyText: The Guardian is expanding its online operation with the launch of SocietyGuardian.co.uk. The site, which launches next month, will provide news and information and job advertising for the public and voluntary sectors. It will be aimed at those working in the health, social care, regeneration, housing, local government and charity fields. Sue Tollerfield, public sector manager at the Guardian's classified department, becomes general manager responsible for commercial development. Marianne Curphey, launch editor of GNL's personal finance website, Money Unlimited, becomes executive editor.

fields.headline: The last of the romantic poets
fields.standfirst: The poet RS Thomas, who died earlier this year, was a passionate advocate of Welsh independence. In 1996 Michael March, poet and director of the Prague Writers' Festival, talked to him about the cost of freedom, the secret of poetry and his hatred of the 18th century
fields.trailText: The poet RS Thomas, who died earlier this year, was a passionate advocate of Welsh independence. In 1996 Michael March, poet and director of the Prague Writers' Festival, talked to him about the cost of freedom, the secret of poetry and his hatred of the 18th century
fields.body:
Michael March: For 50 years you have devoted yourself to poetry and religion. What have you seen, what have you felt, what has moved you the most in this life?

RS Thomas: The open air. I was never an academic. I don't despise scholarship, but it's not for me. The hours that I could have spent improving my mind or widening my knowledge have been spent in open air. I never went anything better than the natural world. I am guilty of what the scholastic world has called "the worship of created things". You are supposed only to worship God. But I have approached life through creative things, especially the beauty of the Earth.

MM: Has not the earth become clouded over, even more so then in the past?

RST: Well, man is domesticating earth. This is what I deplore. You know Yeats's turn about John O'Leary: "Romantic Ireland's dead and gone. It's with John O'Leary in the grave." Romantic Wales is gone. Has it ever existed? Has romantic Ireland ever existed? My young person's romantic view - rather like Coleridge in his dejection - has been explored. I can see that there is no such thing for me any longer as a romantic world, and this is why I turned to birdwatching - because birds were the only creatures that have preserved their natural, traditional way of life, without being impinged on by the machine and commerce and all these other things.

MM: How do you envision a romantic world populated by man? How would man behave in such a world?

RST: This is the artist's dilemma. To me, time is of the essence, although I have wasted so much of it. Nevertheless, one needs time, and the romantic view of life would be one in which man earned his livelihood with his hands, made his clothes, constructed his living quarters and lived a traditional life preserving a folk tradition. But that needs time. So unless you are going to have a male-dominated society where the woman does all these things and leaves the man free to pursue his own heart - life, whether in music or in painting or in literature - it's not possible, there isn't enough time.

MM: We return to time and I perceive that poetry is closely allied to time.

RST: Time is a mercurial thing. If there is such a thing as a next world, one presumes that it will be timeless because time has a connection with memory and to be conscious of time is to be restless and unfulfilled. We look before and after and pine for what is not. I know that probably some of my sweetest moments have been when time has not existed - when you are on an island with the sea whispering around and the wind suddenly falls still and the sun breaks through and, just for a moment, time ceases.

MM: Poetry has a slower metabolism than the business world, the everyday world. One must take time to digest words, words which come from different periods of history. There's an archaeology, an alchemy in words. To digest words is almost a forbidden act, because today one must be ruthlessly efficient, ruthlessly pursuing business rather than focusing on time or trying to understand our life and death.

RST: I have felt for a very long time that we are paying for our conquest of space by losing touch with time. Time is seemingly meaningless now. You think that with the machine doing so much for you that there would be more time, but the irony is that there is less. I like to think that poetry is a mature art. In our English-speaking tradition you don't get much great poetry from young people; it needs time to mature. Nevertheless, in some strange way there have been people in the past who have died young and who have produced an enormous amount of poetry. I was talking about this once with a professor of English. I said that I tended to waste my time; I used bags of time. He said I probably knew instinctively that I was going to live a long time, whereas someone like Keats instinctively realised that he was going to live a short time.

MM: What is the place of poetry in our present civilisation?

RST: I don't know if that can be decided at any one instant. We're obviously living at the end of a millennium; we would like to think that things are in the crucible and that the new millennium will bring forth new things. It would be cheering to think that this question is going to be decided in the coming century, but I think the great battle for poetry is with the machine, as I have tried to say in some of my poetry. The machine dehumanises. Wordsworth, as we know, said: "Thanks to this human heart by which we live /Things that can move him deeper than tears/ All because of our human heart." Well, we're already becoming familiar with the possibility of an artificial heart. The whole thing seems to land you in nonsense.

It used to be pig-headed, now it's pig-hearted. Perhaps lion-hearted man will return us to another time, another place, through natural sex.

RST: We must turn everything in. We are too outward. When I have a thought, I must turn it in. We're living in a superficial age, when everything is on the surface. Sex is one of the things which 20th-century western man has become obsessed with, and the result is shallowness. I'd like to think that man was more passionate in the past. Some of the great works, especially in music, or like the Divine Comedy of Dante, are works of passion. This is something that we have lost, as Frost would say, by being too 'out'. We're too outward.

MM: Sitting in Prague, in central Europe, reading Milan Kundera's new novel Slowness, I have a longing to return to the coy sexuality of the 18th century. To return to the chase, the retrieve, the approach, a playful conversation which seems lost today.

RST: I hate the 18th century, speaking generally. I would go back to earlier periods, as I suggested, with Dante. My father was a sailor. I had leanings towards the sea, but he'd been through the hard days of an apprenticeship in sailing ships and seen what a hard life it could be. To me, there is nothing more beautiful than a full-rigged ship. That's the romantic picture; the realities are something different. If you're going to praise, say, the 14th century, you also must remember that there was blood, there was violence, life was short. It must have been out of this tension that people's emotions and sensibilities became sharpened. It was the same thing during the last war - once people are under pressure their instincts and responses become sharpened. It is possible that a work of art is more likely to be born out of that situation.

MM: What do you have against the 18th century?

RST: It's the rationalist century. I mean, Pope and Dryden and people like that are a disaster. They are academic fodder. All the professors and lecturers love Pope and Dryden because somebody else has written about them so they can write about what somebody else has written about them. It was also the rationalist period. I don't know if I am getting my dates quite right but Locke and people like that - I dislike the whole approach.

Skipping the revolution, do things change?

RST: How much is really new? How much is really new that matters? I mean, the aeroplane is new. The computer is new. I don't know of what importance they are. They are of no importance to me at all. I think that we'd be much better off if the people of the world had never discovered each other. If they had led their own lives, with large areas of water between them.

MM: What about politics?

RST: Party politics are eternal, of course. The Greek were concerned with politics as a discipline, an area of knowledge - the right construction and management of the state, the good of the state and its people. And we've been through dictatorships in countries like Germany and Russia and Italy. We're also saddled with the myth of democracy. All these things are a mixture of personal ambition and greed and cleverness and the manipulation of language. Whereas truth is manipulable in the interests not of the state, but of the individual or the party. This is the "treason of the clerks" that Pindar spoke of. If we feel as I feel, we should fight the battle and not put up with this bunch of party politicians. But then each one of us has got his own axe to grind. I would have never written my poetry if I had chosen to fight on the political field.

MM: What was your reaction to the communist states?

RST: It's the question of pacifism. If you're a member of a small nation, as I am - the Welsh nation has no real power, material power - the ultimate battle would have been a personal one. If Hitler had won and national socialism had taken over, we would have had to stand and resist in Wales, but we wouldn't have resisted as a nation. Each one would have had to fight his own personal battle. And, of course, materially you lose every time. It's a matter of whether you can keep the spirit alive in such circumstances.

MM: Convenience is often more alive than bravery.

RST: I am very conscious of this as a member of the Welsh nation. Those of us who have the good of the Welsh nation at heart want people to make the sacrifice. If we gain independence from England, life will become more expensive. You can't have these things unless you pay for them. You either pay with blood, which in the Welsh case is hardly possible, or you pay with money. Independence would cut the individual Welshman much more, because it is true to say to some extent that Wales is subsidised by England. This is England's great boast. It's the fleshpots of Egypt, isn't it? When they led the children of Israel towards freedom, they regretted the time when they had the fleshpots. Many people in Wales would regret the time when they felt materially better off under England, once they were living in a free Wales.

MM: Where is the crosssover between materialism, spirituality and freedom? This seems pertinent with respect to present-day China.

RST: We've just got far too many people in the world. The progressives, the materialistic, the scientists, they all say: "Oh, we could feed many more people than we already have." But even if it is possible you've got the other problem of distribution. To my mind, the best thing is to cut down. In a small country like Wales, I don't think that it would be necessary to cut down the population but to redistribute it. We're too heavy: we've got over half the population of Wales in the south, in the old industrial belt. If it could be redistributed we'd be fine. But with countries like China, Russia, India, countries in southeast Asia, they've just got far too many people.

MM: Why not achieve independence for Wales by promoting a cultural revolution in England? At least half the people would starve to death.

RST: (laughter) One has to employ draconian methods. But then, who's going to employ them?

MM: Our present government is doing the reverse - they're putting everyone in jail. But that's not a solution.

RST: They have no solution. The old Greek idea of nemesis is still applicable. You get rewarded in accordance with your policies, your way of thinking. I don't know how long it can be postponed, but the whole ethos of the west is heading towards nemesis.

MM: To where do you turn? Do you see poetry as a form of prayer?

RST: No, I see it almost entirely as language-centred. Every poet of any quality loves words. They are what he works with, just as a painter works with paint and texture, a musician works with notes - so a poet works with words. It's a kind of ongoing struggle as to who is to be master. You begin by being, more or less, dominated by the words. You gradually attain a certain mastery, and then you realise it's a bit like touch-typing - you reach a state when you can half be mastered and half dominate. Out of that subtle association, the better works of poetry are born. To have reached a stage of development where you can give yourself to the language and let it carry you along. And yet, all the while, you've also got a hand on the reins to see that it doesn't run completely away with you.

MM: What stage is silence?

RST: Well, I can't really be silent. I was never any good at meditation. When I was at theological college, we were expected to meditate; once a week there was a certain period set aside. I can never meditate because my mind is not silent - it's full of words chasing each other. I'm fascinated by rhythms and the possibilities of words. You go chasing after new thoughts all the time. I would never set myself up as one of these sages sitting and contemplating his navel in complete silence.

webTitle: Searching for the cuts behind Portillo's plans

fields.headline: Searching for the cuts behind Portillo's plans
fields.standfirst: After Michael Portillo suggested that the Tories could maintain public spending at the same time as cutting taxes, Julian Glover tries to work out just how the shadow chancellor is doing his sums
fields.trailText: After Michael Portillo suggested that the Tories could maintain public spending at the same time as cutting taxes, Julian Glover tries to work out just how the shadow chancellor is doing his sums.
fields.body:
"Some people," claims Michael Portillo, "find it hard to understand that we can offer increases in public spending but reduce taxes".

They sure do. The shadow chancellor's promise in today's Times that, if elected, he would spend just as much as Labour on key services such as the NHS, but also cut taxes by £8bn sounds too good to be true.

Nonetheless, it may prove an astute political move. So how does it all work?

First the tax cut. At £8bn, this is enough to take 4p off income tax - or cut petrol taxes by double the 3p a litre reduction the Tories promised last month.

From a party that is fond of reminding Britain that there is no such thing as a something-for-nothing society, this sounds like generosity indeed.

But it comes with a sting in the tail. Gordon Brown has committed the government to vast increases in public spending over the next few years - Michael Portillo says the total is £68bn, though the figures vary depending on how they are calculated.

Although this money has not yet been spent, much of it has been allocated on projects such as new hospitals and rebuilding the rail network.

According to Mr Brown, all this extra money can be found without putting up taxes - but without cutting them either.

Some of it is available now, since the Treasury already earns far more from taxes than it is spending at the moment. The rest of the cash, the chancellor hopes, will come from economic growth.

Mr Portillo agrees about the economic growth - and about the need to spend more on key services. But he only wants to spend £60bn extra - leaving £8bn to fund tax cuts.

So on some things, a Conservative government would spend less than a Labour one.

Whether you describe the difference between £60bn and £68bn as a spending cut or merely a smaller spending increase, obviously depends on your political viewpoint.

The government certainly sees it as a cut, and is pressuring the opposition to explain which areas of public spending would miss out on the expected extra money.

So far, the shadow chancellor has been unwilling to say, beyond vague promises to save £2bn from "government waste" and reduce social security spending. But his article in the Times offers a few clues.

Among them are plans to establish endowment funds for universities, and allow young people to use their National Insurance contributions to fund their private pension schemes.

Add this to the existing Conservative proposal to allow people to partly fund their healthcare, and you have an agenda for transforming the welfare state by drawing on private funds. The logical outcome is that less public money would be required: making taxes cuts a possibility.

But the plans ought to be packaged with a bundle of 'ifs'. The biggest if of all is that both the Labour and Conservative plans rely on the economy continuing to grow.

If it does not, then both spending increases and tax cuts will be rapidly wiped off the agenda.

On top of this, the shadow chancellor is hoping that the public will find the trade-off between lower taxes and less well-funded public services attractive.

This, too, is far from clear. Labour will certainly use scare stories about Tory cuts to win back votes at the general election.

Still, however hazy the details are at present, Mr Portillo's statement has helped define a key difference between the government and the opposition as the election nears.

The government believes that public spending should rise as a share of national income, provided it can be afforded. The opposition believes it should fall, provided it can be achieved without too much pain.

Soon, the electorate will decide which vision it prefers.

fields.headline: C4 horror a cut above
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Channel 4's Film Fear horror movie season got off to a suitably grisly start at the weekend, with The Texas Chainsaw Massacre spicing up the channel's late-night ratings. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's Film Fear horror movie season got off to a suitably grisly start at the weekend, with the UK terrestrial premiere of seminal 1970s slasher movie The Texas Chainsaw Massacre spicing up the channel's late-night ratings on Saturday.

The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, in which the de rigeur group of screaming American teenagers fall prey to a family of inbred cannibals, averaged 1.8m and a whopping 22% share on Channel 4 from 11.45pm to 1am.

Prior to that, Channel 4 had kicked off its Film Fear season at 10.35pm with Scream and Scream Again, a history of the slasher movie. The documentary scored 1.8m and a 12% share.

On Sunday night, the broadcaster got good ratings mileage out of another horror film, Scream. Wes Craven's ironic 1996 updating of the slasher genre averaged 2.9m - a 24% share - from 10.10pm-12.15am.

Channel 4's latest Top Ten also enjoyed a successful outing on Saturday night, with the Phil Jupitus-presented look back at 1977 pulling an audience of 2.9m and a 13% share from 9.05-10.35pm.

But on the same evening David Beckham's appearance on Parkinson failed to deliver a ratings victory for the BBC1 chat show over ITV. Parkinson averaged 7m viewers and a 30% share from 8.55-9.55pm, while ITV drama The Knock had 7.9m - a 36% share - from 9.05-10.35pm.

BBC1's new post 9pm Friday night line-up continued to struggle against the regular ITV tactic of scheduling a movie repeat. Have I Got News for You and a repeated Vicar of Dibley both had 6.2m, the Ten O'Clock News averaged 4.1m, and new sitcom Too Much Sun dipped further to 2.5m after its dismal opening last week.

Meanwhile, over on ITV from 9pm, Bruce Willis action movie Die Hard 2 was averaging 7.2m.

Average audiences for the Ten O'Clock News were down by nearly 1m in the show's second week. The new BBC1 10pm bulletin averaged 4.3m across the week, after 5.2m the week before.

webTitle: Ananova pushes parent company into profit

fields.headline: Virtual newsreader alive and well
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: The world is set for a population boom in virtual people, according to the creators of the Ananova newsreader service, writes Dan Milmo .
fields.body:
The world is set for a population boom in virtual people, according to the animation company which designed Ananova, the digital newsreader.

Digital Animations, which designs digital humans, or avatars, said it had earned £0.6m from Ananova, which is owned by mobile phone operator Orange.

The Glasgow-based company added that pre-tax profits for the first half of the year were £1.03m, against a loss of £0.4m last year.

Michael Hambly, chief executive of Digital said: "We strongly believe that the worldwide market for Avatars is set to grow significantly. Typical uses could include intelligent agents, virtual secretaries, virtual receptionist, advertising, sales agent and call centres."

Mr Hambly added that avatars could set up their home in almost any device, including mobile phones, PCs and palm pilots.

Ananova remains the big money-spinner for the company, however, with the company set to earn £2.4m from its lucrative contract with Orange over the next two years. The service was originally produced for the Press Association, but it was snapped up by Orange earlier this year.

Digital Animations is working on projects with computer games manufacturers Infogrames and Electronic Arts, and is attempting to give its creations more human characteristics, such as the ability to "see" the user.

fields.headline: Storms
fields.standfirst: After a weekend of storms, Sussex is sodden, Devon is drenched, and the Pennines are parky. Here's our guide to the best sites on the atrocious weather
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: After a weekend of storms, Sussex is sodden, Devon is drenched, and the Pennines are parky. Here's our guide to the best sites on the atrocious weather.
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. As you may have noticed, we have just had a rotten weekend. The Met Office says it is all about low air pressure. As opposed to the high blood pressure of would-be travellers trying to use Britain's clapped-out railways.

2. There is widespread gale damage in the south, snow on the Pennines, and flood warnings all over the place. The forecast is better, but there is more rain to come.

3. West Sussex has been particularly battered, with mini tornadoes in Bognor Regis and Selsey.

4. Some people are fascinated by tornadoes. They even go on expensive storm-chasing holidays.

5. We are not alone in having extreme weather just now. It's cascading in Canada, squelching in Queensland, and persisting down in the Philippines.

6. Are we doomed? There is no shortage of alarm about global warming. Even the dear old Department of the Environment has noticed that the weather is changing. The Home Office is also concerned.

7. Apart from the Met Office, any number of boffins are charting the changes.

8. Some believe that our main threat is posed not by the rain coming down, but by the sea level going up.

9. Rather percipiently, the Environment Agency organised a flood awareness campaign only last month. Interestingly, the lead item on its What's New? web page is about a conference next year on groundwater protection.

10. Weather is good on the web. You can follow all the latest news, and even take a live peek at the latest conditions in the Scillies, which is roughly where the weather is coming from. But you're probably more interested in a quick update on the traffic in London.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: BIG RON: RIGHT OR WRONG?
fields.body:
BIG RON: RIGHT OR WRONG?

In his column on Friday, Ron Atkinson rubbished the claims of Roy Hodgson - the Sun readers' choice to be the next England manager - in one pithy sentence. "If I were to choose an Englishman I would sooner go for Peter Reid, John Gregory or in particular Bryan Robson," Big Ron opined.

And the whole nation gawped in stunned disbelief. Or did it?

"I absolutely agree with Ron Atkinson," wrote Peter Forrester. "Roy Hodgson is not the man for England. I speak from bitter experience: he took Blackburn from a solid side to a team in decline. His man management, tactics and media relations, particularly with local media, were abysmal.

"A number of national papers are trying to apologise for Hodgson's failure at Blackburn. As far as I am concerned he was the architect of his own downfall. He had money and backing and failed to use this. He should be keep well away from Lancaster Gate"

Elsewhere, most readers tended to agree that Big Ron's criticisms of Hodgson may have been valid - but then went on to say that he rather undermined his arguments by insisting that Bryan Robson was his England manager of choice.

"I have my question marks over Roy Hodgson's record - everyone knows he tarnished it at Blackburn - and if Ron thinks that this is enough in his opinion to rule out England then so be it," says Bernie Regan. "But if I hear the words Bryan Robson or Peter Reid again, then I will know that true despair has set into the heart of English football.

"Bad signings, wasted cash, bad handling of individuals, booze culture - Bryan Robson has the done the lot. Never, never, should this man be England manager - he's not even going to be Boro's manager for much longer, if we're to believe what the press says. If Kevin Keegan was considered a retrograde step, Bryan Robson would be a foetal mistake."

Boom boom. And Bernie's not the only critic. "Bryan Robson a candidate as England manager???!!!!" says an exasperated Jake Pollard. "And he talks about Roy Hodgson's record? Please."

JAMES RICHARDSON'S COLUMN: A VIEW FROM MILAN

There's been more praise for James Richardson's article on the racist leanings of Lazio, including one email from Giorgio Adamo from Milan.

"I just finished reading Mr Richardson's article. It is all correct: Lazio are supported by a virulent far right bunch of tifosi," he says. "But this doesn't apply to supporters of many other Italian teams, such as Inter or Parma, where black people have always been treated like kings and loved by supporters."

fields.headline: Union slams £7m teacher recruitment campaign
fields.trailText: 1pm update: The new £7m teacher recruitment ad campaign has been attacked by a teachers' union leader as 'another triumph of image over substance', writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of teachers' union the NASUWT, has attacked the Teacher Training Agency's new advertising campaign as "another triumph of image over substance".

The campaign, launched today by schools standards minister Estelle Morris, aims to attract the country's brightest graduates into teaching. It was created by McCann-Erickson in Manchester and is the most intensive recruitment campaign for years.

Ms Morris said: "Teaching is one of the most important jobs in the country and we need to recruit more graduates into the profession.

"There has never been a better time for them to join - for the first time training salaries of £6,000 are available, with extra incentives of £4,000 for those who train in and go to teach shortage subjects."

But Mr de Gruchy said the campaign was full of ambiguous gimmicks.

He said: "The NASUWT will not be distracted from the real issues of bureaucracy, workload, pay, professional autonomy and pupil behaviour. These will determine the ability of teaching to recruit and retain able young people."

In March the Teacher Training Agency feared a potential drop in graduate applications of up to 20%. The TTA claims the new salaries have prevented that decline.

The government is also introducing performance-related pay for teachers and new career structures enabling classroom teachers to earn up to £30,000 a year. A fast track programme will offer the best graduates the chance to progress more rapidly into leadership and management positions.

fields.headline: Mail confirms bid for Express
fields.trailText: 3.15pm update: The Daily Mail's owner is to make a dramatic £100m-plus swoop for Express newspapers, according to a source close to the bidder. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The owner of the Daily Mail is to make a dramatic £100m-plus swoop for the Express newspaper group, according to a source close to the bidder.

The Daily Mail & General Trust is entering the fray following weekend press reports that it would join David Montgomery, former Mirror newspaper group chief executive, and the Hinduja Group in bidding for the Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star.

The source refused to give details of the timing or size of the bid, though it is expected to top the ill-fated £75m offer from the Barclays twins, which collapsed earlier this month.

The Express newspaper titles are owned by United News & Media, which is undergoing a massive restructuring following the sale of its ITV franchises to Granada Media earlier this year.

Lord Hollick, owner of United, is to relaunch the company as a business communications player.

Analysts said a bid for the Express titles by the Daily Mail made sense, as it would consolidate the group's domination of the middle-ground tabloid market.

The Express, once a feared voice of the right, has seen its sales figures decline steadily from 4m a day to 1m over 36 years, while the Mail towers above it with a daily circulation of 2.3m.

Anthony de Larrinaga, analyst at SG Securities, said: "The Daily Mail has done everything that the Express has not. It has created a stable market and has been consistent about maintaining it. The Mail will give the Express the investment and promotion it needs."

The bid will have to undergo regulatory scrutiny, however, and would have to be referred immediately to watchdogs amid claims that a takeover could be against the public interest.

Under the Department of Trade & Industry procedures for handling mergers, newspapers can bypass the competition commission if the move can be proved to be "a financial urgency" because the paper being taken over was "not an economic going concern".

Industry sources say the process should take three months.

webTitle: Astronauts lift off to build on a dream in space

fields.headline: Astronauts lift off to build on a dream in space
fields.standfirst: Special report: Space Exploration
fields.trailText: Two Russians and an American will blast off from Baikonur in Kazakhstan tomorrow to set up camp at the most demanding construction site ever known. They will be the first permanent residents of the International Space Station - a $30bn complex of hotel, power station and laboratories the size of a football field, orbiting the earth every 90 minutes at an altitude of 220 miles.
fields.body:
Two Russians and an American will blast off from Baikonur in Kazakhstan tomorrow to set up camp at the most demanding construction site ever known. They will be the first permanent residents of the International Space Station - a $30bn complex of hotel, power station and laboratories the size of a football field, orbiting the earth every 90 minutes at an altitude of 220 miles.

The completion of this tall order will take more than 40 trips by spacecraft, and more than 160 "spacewalks" by the construction workers.

Seven flights of the space shuttle and Proton rocket have already delivered the first bolt-together modules and temporary living accommodation. Now three experienced space hands are about to begin the laborious and dangerous job of taking delivery of, and assembling, the rest.

Sixteen nations - but not Britain - are involved in the space station, the culmination of a dream as old as the space age itself.

Zero gravity

During the heady days of Apollo, space scientists and engineers drew up plans for vast orbiting colonies that could be home to up to 10,000 people, growing their own food and refining valuable minerals from asteroids and comets for export back to earth, or human settlements on the moon.

The ISS has been scaled down again and again in the past two decades, and will be home to only seven men and women, staying for up to six months at a time, when it is finally completed in 2005.

To make that happen Bill Shepherd, 51, Yuri Gidzenko, 38, and Sergei Krikalev, 42, have to begin handling tools and moving building materials in the most hostile environment of all.

They will have to work in zero gravity, where Newton's laws of motion create special problems for people not used to weightlessness. In space, when an astronaut turns a spanner, the bolt is likely to stay still while he turns.

There are other difficulties. A spacecraft operates at the same atmospheric pressure as earth, and its crew breathe normal air. Once in spacesuits, the astronauts operate at a much lower pressure and breathe oxygen, so the new team will have to spend time "washing out" the nitrogen in their bodies to avoid the "bends" before they can begin work.

Once out of the spacecraft there are other problems. When an astronaut works on the sunny side, the temperature can be well above boiling point. When he works in the shade, it can fall to well below minus 100C. So he has to have a space suit that contains heating and cooling equipment, a helmet that won't mist from his own breath, an air supply - and even tiny heaters in his gloves.

He has to work with specially designed tools: no-one dare risk handing an astronaut a screwdriver or chisel with a sharp edge that might tear a hole in a spacesuit.

The great terror is of becoming detached from the spaceship, and not being able to get back. So each man will wear a tiny jetpack to puff him gently back to safety if he gets too far away.

They will be assisted by a robot crane, and astronauts will be able to call on a spare pair of eyes in a little free-flying television camera embedded in a sphere a little bigger than a football, controlled by the crew in the space station.

The help may be sophisticated - but over the next five years successive teams of men and women workers face shifts of six hours at a time, doing the loneliest job in the world.

Night and day

They will have to cope with weariness - and even fear of falling. They will experience night and day every 90 minutes. They will see the world turning up to 250 miles below them. And they will not dare relax, even for a second.

"It is very hard to work against the spacesuit, particularly because of fatigue of the fingers and hands. In order to manipulate any kinds of objects you have to put a lot of force on your hands," says William Paloski, one of Nasa's medical experts.

"Some crew members in the past have had trouble with being outside the payload bay. There are some perceptual illusions that sometimes occur - people get a sensation of falling that is very difficult to overcome."

Who's on board and what they'll be doing

William Shepherd Commander of Expedition-1, which moves into the International Space Station this week, is also a captain in the US navy, a frogman, an underwater demolition expert and a former Seal, a member of the navy's crack combat group. He has spent 440 hours in space.

Lt Col Yuri Gidzenko Second in command and commander of the Soyuz rocket which takes the trio to the space station and then serves as a lifeboat for the return journey. Gidzenko has served six months as commander of a mission to Mir, the Russian space station.

Sergei Krikalev The best known and by far the most experienced of the trio is the flight engineer. He was the cosmonaut who went up to Mir in 1991 as an officer of the Soviet Union, played host to the British astronaut Helen Sharman and came back to Earth in 1992 as a Russian citizen after the dramatic collapse of the USSR.

He was an aerobatics champion for the USSR and Russia. He holds one title of Hero of the Soviet Union and one as Hero of Russia, and has the Order of Lenin and the French Légion d'Honneur.

Microgravity

The astronauts will look at microgravity. Nasa argues that if scientists can study how crystals form, without distortion from gravity, they might find out how to make more effective drugs, create more powerful computer chips, or confect stronger, lighter alloys.

Radiation

They will be able to study the long-term effects of radiation on living tissue. One early set of visitors to the space station will be billions of bacteria collected by the British Antarctic Survey from the hostile dry valleys of Antarctica. How they fare in space might help biologists to answer basic questions about life itself.

Human physiology

Medical scientists want to know more about human physiology under unusual conditions. Space could serve as a laboratory for the study of accelerated senility.

The costs

Critics say the costs of the 400-tonne station could reach $100bn, making it the most expensive object ever built, and that most of the scientific challenges could be met on Earth or from satellite studies.

Gidzenko has served six months as commander of a mission to Mir, the Russian space station. Sergei Krikalev The best known and by far the most experienced of the trio is the flight engineer. He was the cosmonaut who went up to Mir in 1991 as an officer of the Soviet Union, played host to the British astronaut Helen Sharman and came back to Earth in 1992 as a Russian citizen after the dramatic collapse of the USSR. He was an aerobatics champion for the USSR and Russia. He holds one title of Hero of the Soviet Union and one as Hero of Russia, and has the Order of Lenin and the French Légion d'Honneur. Microgravity The astronauts will look at microgravity. Nasa argues that if scientists can study how crystals form, without distortion from gravity, they might find out how to make more effective drugs, create more powerful computer chips, or confect stronger, lighter alloys. Radiation They will be able to study the long-term effects of radiation on living tissue. One early set of visitors to the space station will be billions of bacteria collected by the British Antarctic Survey from the hostile dry valleys of Antarctica. How they fare in space might help biologists to answer basic questions about life itself. Human physiology Medical scientists want to know more about human physiology under unusual conditions. Space could serve as a laboratory for the study of accelerated senility. The costs Critics say the costs of the 400-tonne station could reach $100bn, making it the most expensive object ever built, and that most of the scientific challenges could be met on Earth or from satellite studies.

webTitle: Cliched England floored by spin and umpire

fields.headline: Cliched England floored by spin and umpire
fields.trailText: England have only been in Pakistan two minutes, yet they are already repeating themselves. One of the worst cliches in the Fleet Street sports-desk book of headlines is England in a spin. It was trotted out several times on Friday and Saturday, and it will be seen again today and tomorrow.
fields.body:
England have only been in Pakistan two minutes, yet they are already repeating themselves. One of the worst cliches in the Fleet Street sports-desk book of headlines is England in a spin. It was trotted out several times on Friday and Saturday, and it will be seen again today and tomorrow.

The depressing thing is, it's true. England are in a spin. On Friday they allowed Shahid Afridi, a legspinner who barely turns the ball, to record the best figures for Pakistan against England in a one-day international -­ five for 40. The record stood for a full three days before being broken today by Saqlain Mushtaq (5 for 20), who does turn his legbreaks, even though he is an offspinner. If Moin Khan hadn't mysteriously removed him from the attack after six overs (3 for 15), Saqlain might have threatened Muralitharan's even-newer record for the best bowling ever in a one-day international (7 for 30 against India on Sunday). And England might well have been all out for 100.

Three things can be said in their defence. First, Saqlain is an outstanding bowler in the one-day game. (Though not often in Tests, where his bowling average this year is 45.) Secondly, both of England's collapses today started with tear gas. Whether the Pakistan police have found the right way to disperse their own countrymen is debatable, but it certainly works on passing Englishmen. When the first whiff reached the batsmen's eyes, England were comfortably placed at 35 for none. Alec Stewart then got an eyeful of it, and when he emerged from behind his hankie, he walked straight into a simple trap set by Abdur Razzaq, a man 17 years his junior. The headline writers traditionally call him Smart Alec. Today it was more a case of Smarting Alec.

Then came the third thing. Wasim Akram bowled a slower ball, a Phil-Tufnell-in-defensive-mode special, turning into the right-hander from over the wicket. It pitched well outside leg, and therefore could not possibly have been lbw. Hussain missed it and was struck on the pad. Wasim appealed, perhaps under the impression that he was still bowling to Marcus Trescothick. The correct thing for Mian Mohammad Aslam to do was to report Wasim to Moin and the match referee, for appealing when he knew the batsman wasn't out (a form of gamesmanship explicitly banned in the new Laws). Instead he gave Hussain out, and thus snatched the lead in the Worst Decision of the Tour Contest from Riazuddin when he skewered Stewart in Karachi. Akram should be ashamed of himself for appealing. Aslam should resign.

But that was no excuse for the procession that followed. Hick was thick, slogging at Saqlain's first ball. Those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it and Hick managed two repetitions in one ­ departing needlessly for virtually nothing, as he himself did in Lahore, and lunging fatally at a spinner's first ball, as Stewart had to Mushtaq Ahmed, also in Lahore.

Flintoff reverted to propping forward without thinking and White holed out a la England in Nairobi. Of the top seven, only Hussain and the two left-handers were blameless. Trescothick and Thorpe made more than half of England's runs from the bat, and Thorpe might have got a few more if he hadn't had to run with Andy Caddick, the Inzy of the western world.

Caddick redeemed himself with two early wickets to give England a faint chance of winning the match and the series. But all Pakistan had to do was see him off. As so often in one-day cricket overseas, England were waiting for a miracle.
