webTitle: In brief: Myers to 'direct' Heche and Hunt

fields.headline: Myers to 'direct' Heche and Hunt
fields.trailText: Plus: Goebbels mistress Baarová dies, Parker weighs up crime and punishment for his next film, Fiennes and Richardson lured into Cronenberg's web and midget Crowe taken to task by Bruckheimer
fields.body:
 Austin Powers star Mike Myers is close to signing up to star alongside Anne Heche and Helen Hunt in a new comedy, Timepiece. The $20m film would see Myers as a TV director making a documentary about a woman (Heche) who lives in a quiet rural community and is constantly fighting against the tyrannical rule of a nearby big city. Filming is slated to start next February.

 Czech-born actress Lída Baarová, who starred in many pre-war German films and who had a high profile affair with Nazi propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels, has died at the age of 86. The actress became famous after the release of her first film Barcarole in 1935; but when the scandal of her affair with the supposedly model family man Goebbels broke, her public image was left in tatters and she was ordered to leave Germany by Hitler. She first fled to Prague, then to Rome, where she continued her acting career. After her disappearance from the screen in 1956, German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder gave her a part in his 1975 film The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant.

 Director Alan Parker, who last directed Angela's Ashes, is close to signing up for The Life of David Gale as his next project. The drama is about a professor sentenced to death after being wrongly convicted of murdering a fellow capital punishment opponent. The screenplay has been written by Charles Randolph, a professor of philosophy and film theory in Vienna. Parker has apparently had his eye on the film for a while and he hopes to start production in March

 Ralph Fiennes and Miranda Richardson are set to co-star in the new David Cronenberg project Spider, according to Screendaily. The $12m psychological thriller is set to start shooting later this year in London.

 According to IMDb News, Russell Crowe wears special elevator shoes to make him look taller. New Zealander Crowe, currently seeing the statuesque Meg Ryan, apparently took his shoes off at a recent party at producer Jerry Bruckheimer's house. Bruckheimer was apparently so concerned at Crowe's sudden lack of inches that he told him to: "Put your shoes back on, you're blowing your image."

fields.headline: UN backs AltaVista against cybersquatter
fields.trailText: 12.15am: UN arbitrators ruled that a cybersquatting firm must hand over 43 domain names that are variations of AltaVista, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
United Nations arbitrators have ruled that a cybersquatting firm must hand over 43 domain names that are variations of the name of leading internet search engine AltaVista.

Geneva-based UN body, the World Intellectual Property Organisation, which runs an arbitration system to evict cybersquatters, said the 43 website addresses registered by Grandtotalfinances Limited were confusingly similar to the AltaVista trademark.

A WIPO panel ruled that sites ranging from actavista.com and aliavista.com to autavista.com and antavista.com had been registered in bad faith by Grandtotalfinances, which has offices in Panama and Latvia.

The ruling in favour of California-based AltaVista follows a similar case in August when WIPO ordered cybersquatters to give up 40 addresses that were variations of US internet media giant Yahoo's site name.

The fast-track arbitration system of WIPO, which specialises in UN copyright and intellectual property issues, allows firms and individuals to avoid costly lawsuits in cases when mischief is the obvious motive or serious money is at stake.

webTitle: US actors resume work after marathon strike

fields.headline: US actors resume work after marathon strike
fields.trailText: American actors were all set to return to work today as the six-month strike by the Screen Actors Guild finally reached an end
fields.body:
American actors were all set to return to work today as the six-month strike by the Screen Actors Guild finally reached an end.

The strike action, in protest against residual payments paid for commercials, was the longest strike in Hollywood history and wreaked havoc within the industry.

Yahoo! News report that the actor's union issued a statement on Saturday, recommending that members accept an agreement reached with advertisers last week

Under the new contracts, advertisers agreed to continue paying residuals to actors for commercials airing on network television. The advertising industry also agreed to recognize the unions' jurisdiction over internet ads.

Union officials estimated that the strike cost members more than $2m a day in session fees and residuals. High-profile actors such as Kevin Spacey and Susan Sarandon donated large amounts to the actors' relief fund.

The strike also saw British actress Elizabeth Hurley struck off the union membership list as she filmed an Estee Lauder advert during the strike and was booed and jeered by placard-waving protesters at the premiere of her latest film Bedazzled. She has since apologised and made a donation to the union.

fields.headline: DfEE launches £7m teacher recruitment drive
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The DfEE is launching a £7m ad campaign to attract graduates into teaching, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Department for Education & Employment is spending £7m on its most intensive recruitment campaign for years to attract the country's brightest graduates into teaching.

The schools standards minister, Estelle Morris, launches the TV, cinema and national press campaign today, created by McCann Erickson in Manchester.

Ms Morris said: "Teaching is one of the most important jobs in the country and we need to recruit more graduates into the profession.

"There has never been a better time for them to join - for the first time training salaries of £6,000 are available, with extra incentives of £4,000 for those who train in and go to teach shortage subjects."

In March the Teacher Training Agency feared a potential drop in graduate applications of up to 20%. The TTA claims the new salaries have prevented that decline.

The government is also introducing performance-related pay for teachers and new career structures enabling classroom teachers to earn up to £30,000 a year. A Fast Track programme will offer the best graduates the chance to progress more rapidly in teaching and into leadership and management positions.

webTitle: Researchers urged to focus on the question

fields.headline: Researchers urged to focus on the question
fields.trailText: Britain's trend towards government by focus group and consumer survey does not work because the public is too bored, wily or dim, academics claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's trend towards government by focus group and consumer survey does not work because the public is too bored, wily or dim, academics claimed yesterday.

Thousands of well-meant questionnaires on policy or spending priorities come up with duff or misleading information, according to statisticians, because of "hopelessly poor" methods of picking ordinary people's brains.

"We all know the saying about 'lies, damned lies and statistics'," said Keith Meadows of Hull University, where polling analysts from across the democratic world gather to debate the issue next month.

"But we now need to get to grips with the 'sorry, I didn't understand the question' phenomenon, or the many and various ways people have of getting rid of a survey pollster as quickly as they can."

The conference on what really happens when authority consults the man in the street has been prompted by the belief that "there may be a chasm between what people think they are being asked in surveys by official bodies, and what they are really being asked".

Many issues, said Dr Meadows, make far more taxing intellectual demands on respondents than their organisers realise, and the answers can easily stray towards the meaningless or trite.

"People have a natural tendency to give well-meant generalisations which those who actually have to make a decision cannot do," he said. "Or they could be deceiving themselves, as can happen in health checks when a GP asks how many glasses of wine or beer you drink per week."

The gathering coincides with a forthcoming circular to local councils and other decision-making authorities from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, emphasising the need for best practice in consultation.

Schemes such as a pilot in Lincolnshire, where council tax rebates are being offered as an incentive to fill in council service questionnaires, have raised concern that polling methods should be more sophisticated than the "do you like this sample of chocolate" model.

The conference, on Cognitive Aspects of Survey Methodology, will draw particularly on experience in the United States, where polling and focus groups have been part of the political and business marketing scene for longer than elsewhere.

The conference findings are expected to help the framing of the next census, the biggest of all the government's dialogues with its citizens.

webTitle: Meet the Parents holds on strong at top

fields.headline: Meet the Parents holds on strong at top
fields.trailText: The Robert De Niro comedy Meet the Parents has remained top of the US box office for the fourth week in a row, holding off the Blair Witch sequel Book of Shadows to take another $15m over the weekend
fields.body:
The Robert De Niro comedy Meet the Parents has remained top of the US box office for the fourth week in a row. Even the release of the Blair Witch sequel, Book of Shadows, could not topple the film, which took another $15m over this weekend.

The comedy, about the disastrous relationship between a future son and father-in-law, also starring Ben Stiller, has earned a total of $100m dollars since its release on October 6.

Meanwhile, the much-anticipated sequel to the low-budget The Blair Witch Project took a disappointing $13.1m, but still secured the number two position. In third place was the Denzel Washington thriller Remember the Titans which took $8m, while the Elizabeth Hurley comedy Bedazzled took $7.7m. Kevin Spacey-Helen Hunt heartwringer Pay it Forward came in at number five.

Meanwhile in Britain, early figures suggest that the Harrison Ford-Michelle Pfeiffer horror film What Lies Beneath has held on to the number one spot, with half-term favourite Dinosaur at number two.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: The hair of today's transfer talk has been tousled by the wind
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor has got rid of one bad-boy striker, and now he wants another one. According to the Mirror, he's chasing Benfica's Pierre Van Hooijdonk. "I've made some calls about Pierre. I know about his history at Forest but it is a two-way thing," the Leicester manager admits. "There was his reputation off the field, but also his reputation on it for being a quality striker who could score goals at the highest level."
fields.body:
Peter Taylor has got rid of one bad-boy striker, and now he wants another one. According to the Mirror, he's chasing Benfica's Pierre Van Hooijdonk. "I've made some calls about Pierre. I know about his history at Forest but it is a two-way thing," the Leicester manager admits. "There was his reputation off the field, but also his reputation on it for being a quality striker who could score goals at the highest level."

But Van Hooijdonk seems less than enamoured with Taylor's approach, claiming: "I'm very flattered to hear about Leicester's interest but I can't see myself coming back to England at the moment. I don't want to join them."

Chelsea midfielder Jody Morris is also a target for Leicester, reports the Daily Mail. Morris's agent Jonathan Barnett said: "Jody is close to Peter Taylor. If a chance came to move to Leicester he wouldn't say no."

Norwegian U-21 international Ragnvald Soma will play a trial match for West Ham tomorrow - and, if he impresses, the Bryne player will complete a £1.6m move to Upton Park, claims Planet Football.

Steve Coppell is favourite to become Huddersfield's next manager, reports Teamtalk.

webTitle: Strip Railtrack of safety duties, say crash relatives

fields.headline: Strip Railtrack of safety duties, say crash relatives
fields.trailText: Relatives of the victims of the Paddington and Southall rail crashes today demanded a new, totally independent watchdog to supervise all elements of rail safety.
fields.body:
Relatives of the victims of the Paddington and Southall rail crashes today demanded a new, totally independent watchdog to supervise all elements of rail safety.

They said Railtrack should be stripped of its safety role and its board should resign in the wake of the Hatfield crash two weeks ago in which four people died when an express train was derailed by a suspected damaged rail.

Louise Christian, of the Southall and Ladbroke Grove Solicitors Group, said Railtrack could no longer be trusted after the latest disaster.

Speaking at a press conference before the start of the second phase of the Ladbroke Grove (Paddington) rail inquiry, she said: "This has been a very traumatic few weeks for the bereaved and injured. The last thing we wanted to see was this dreadful crash."

Ms Christian said that prior to the Southall, Ladbroke Grove and Hatfield crashes "the public were not told about the wholly unacceptable risk on the railways".

She went on: "Railtrack knew that Signal 109 had been passed at danger [the cause of the Paddington crash] and they had meetings to discuss it for over five years.

"They were warned before the Paddington crash that the last thing they should do was to do nothing. There was nothing wrong with the technical expertise given to Railtrack. They simply did nothing.

"We believe that the same failure to act is what caused Hatfield to crash. Railtrack knew of the danger to the travelling public. They had meetings about it and were advised about it but they did not act.

"There has been complete secrecy and it's not good enough for them to blame the structure of the industry."

The Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett offered to resign in the wake of the Hatfield crash, but the board refused to accept. He later complained about the fragmentation of the rail network after privatisation.

The first half of the Ladbroke Grove inquiry, which ended on September 28, investigated the causes of the Paddington smash in October 1999. Thirty-one people died when a Thames Trains commuter service went through a red light and ploughed into a First Great Western express.

But the second part of the inquiry, chaired by Lord Cullen, will look at "how the rail industry handles accidents", the new structure of the rail industry and government policy on increasing rail use. It is expected to last around two months and will consider a selection of derailments and SPADs (signals passed at danger) at Newton Junction in 1991 and 1998, Watford in 1996, Bexley in 1997 as well as the Southall and Paddington crashes.

Reports on the inquiry as a whole, however, are not expected to be published until some time in 2001.

The Southall disaster in September 1997 killed seven people when another First Great Western train smashed into an empty freight train.

fields.headline: Pacino will play Napoleon
fields.trailText: Al Pacino is set to play the diminutive French emperor Napoleon Bonaparte in Betsy and the Emperor, a drama based loosely on the French emperor's exile on St Helena after his fall from grace
fields.body:
Al Pacino is set to play the diminutive French emperor Napoleon Bonaparte in a new film.

The equally pint-sized Pacino, last seen starring alongside Russell Crowe in the award-winning The Insider, will star in Betsy and the Emperor, a drama based loosely on the French emperor's exile on St Helena after his fall from grace, according to Yahoo! News.

French director Patrice Chereau will direct the picture from an unpublished manuscript by novelist Staton Rabin. Screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière, best known for The Unbearable Lightness of Being, has adapted the script. It will fictionalise the true story of Bonaparte's relationship with the young daughter of his jailer on the island

Pacino is reported to have become involved with the project after actress Colleen Camp handed him a copy of Carrière's script.

Production is not thought to start until next year, as Pacino is currently shooting Simone for director Andrew Niccol. It features Pacino as a film producer who can't find his ideal leading lady and so has one digitally made.

webTitle: Wheels: the new Toyota sports utility vehicle

fields.headline: Look, it cuts the grass
fields.standfirst: Giles Smith  puts the new Toyota 'sports utility' vehicle to the ultimate test: buying a lawnmower from Homebase
fields.trailText: Giles Smith puts the new Toyota 'sports utility' vehicle to the ultimate test: buying a lawnmower from Homebase.
fields.body:
Car design works in reverse. The more a vehicle is made to look rugged and ready for that all-night, cross-mountain trek over gravel, ice and the carcasses of dead sheep, the more likely it is to earn a strictly urban cachet and be unlikely to be called upon for so much as a hill-start. This certainly seems to be the story with the sports utility vehicle, or SUV.

The snazzier models are what today's ram raider or rap star is wearing uptown at the weekend. The ones with the quieter boom boxes are for urban or suburban people who have families but want to insist that this hasn't entirely exhausted their appetite for life. In either form, the SUV has dealt a blow to the pride of the hatchback, which used to do well by both these social groups but which these days looks timid and grey-complexioned beside these pumped-up, rounded-off bundles of energy.

Sports utility - it's a boldly yoked concept. What "sports" means in these circumstances is surprisingly fast engines, stiff suspensions and the ability to get airborne at speed bumps. What "utility" seems to mean, however, is, actually, "inutility", in the sense that the cars tend to come generously decked with features for which the average urban owner will have little or no use, such as chunky anti-rhino bars, rear storage spaces the size of horse boxes, and four-wheel drives.

But what, then, are we to make of the compact SUV? Regular SUVs are, generally, the kind of car you can walk into without ducking and they appeal to the consumer whose desire is to own an extremely large lump of metal. The idea, then, of a deliberately compact one is necessarily hedged about with contradictions, but the vehicle must presumably be aimed at people who want to own an extremely large lump of metal but who don't quite have the heart or the driveway to carry it through.

The Toyota RAV4 is a compact SUV. Toyota pretty much invented this concept-within-a-concept six years ago, with the original RAV4, and are now revisiting it. The new model is tall and roomy and fairly big, as lumps of metal go, but is a complete pussycat next to its muscled-up brothers, the Land Cruiser Colorado and the Land Cruiser Amazon, whose bumpers reach up to your eyebrows. It comes in two models - a cute and snubby three-door version, and, for rappers with larger entourages, a five-door version.

The five-door was the model I drove, and it was also, naturally, a five-wheel car, in the sense that there was a fifth wheel stuck prominently to the outside of the back door. Conspicuous tyre display is, for some reason, the staple of the SUV, the size and prominence of the spare being almost the measure of the car. All that canny work that designers once did, creating underfloor crannies to hide the spare, is ritually mocked by the SUV.

In publicity photographs, the RAV4 is poised, not on somebody's drive or outside a childrens' shoe shop, but on the lip of a gushing waterfall. One gets the impression that the target RAV4 owner would have to miss an awful lot of road signs before life got as wild as that.

Still, even in the suburbs, there are tough jobs to be done by tough men in tough vehicles, and last week I did such a job in a Toyota RAV4. Throwing caution to the wind, I gunned the two-litre engine and drove to Sainsbury's Homebase to buy a lawnmower.

Funny time of the year to be buying a lawnmower, I concede. But then, this year time does seem to have gone funny - the leaves still sticking to the trees, the grass still growing. Anyway, I needed a new machine for a final, pre-winter cut - and I had a RAV4 on hand to help me score one.

I was there in no time, because the RAV4 is extremely fast. Toyota claim it offers the best power-to-weight ratio in its class. I could perhaps have done with some more weight, finding the steering wispy and the car faintly frail-feeling. I wouldn't fancy it over mountains or down waterfalls, but I have to say it managed with aplomb the rumble strips on the Homebase car park feeder road.

It also nipped easily into a parking space. Regular SUVs tend to need two. The Flymo Turbo Compact 330 I eventually selected was quite a handful - both in boxed form and also, as I later discovered, as an electric mayhem-maker, out there on the lawn - but thanks to the RAV4's dual-position luggage cover, it slotted without complaint into the boot. (And without me having to remove the back seats - though I could have done, had I for some reason been buying several lawnmowers.)

I found reverse, eased my spare tyre out into the exit lane and headed smoothly for the one-way system. And then I drove home, very fast, to mow the lawn.

So there you have it: usefulness and sportiness in the same concise, affordable package. But enough about the Flymo. The Toyota RAV4? It's a mixed-up kid. But someone's going to love it.

The lowdown

Toyota RAV4

Price: from £13,495

Top speed: 115 mph (2.0, manual)

Acceleration: 0-62 in 10.6 secs

Consumption: 32.1 mpg (combined)

On the stereo: Puff Daddy

At the wheel: Puff Daddy's daddy

En route for: downtown Stevenage

fields.headline: Humphrys welcomes BBC move
fields.standfirst: R4 returns to central London
fields.trailText:
Monday 6pm: Today presenter John Humphrys welcomed the move back to the centre of London after two years in the concrete wilderness of west London, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
R4 returns to central London
fields.body:
Today presenter John Humphrys welcomed the move back to the centre of London after two years in the concrete wilderness of west London.

But the 56-year-old host said it would make little difference to him by the time the builders and BBC bureaucrats had finished with the restructuring.

He said: "I am somewhat detached from this because I don't expect to be trundling into the Today studios when I am 99 or whatever age I will be when they are finished.

"But it it will be good for the Today programme. We have said so many times over the years and right from the beginning that if you are producing a daily current affairs programme you need to be where it is happening and that is in the middle of London.

"White City is only a few miles away, but it has made a difference to the number of politicians that have been willing to come into the studio for a face to face interview."

Senior journalists on other shows reacted with weariness to the decision.

One said: "What is going to happy to Tony Hall now? How can he possibly survive this? If Liz Forgan's figures are correct, this has cost licence payers £41m."

Last week Ms Forgan, the former managing director of BBC network radio, said she never believed the figures presented by Mr Hall when the move from Broadcasting House was first mooted five years ago.

He claimed it would have saved the corporation more than £10m a year.

webTitle: R4's Today programme returns to central London

fields.headline: R4's Today programme returns to central London
fields.standfirst: John Humphrys welcomes move
fields.trailText:
Monday 5.30pm update:BBC Radio 4's Today team are moving back to Broadcasting House along with the corporation's other network radio journalists, writes Jason Deans.
John Humphrys welcomes move
fields.body:
The BBC Radio 4 Today programme team will be moving back to Broadcasting House along with the corporation's other network radio journalists, the corporation confirmed today.

The BBC's network TV journalists, who have never been based in central London before, will also be making the move from Television Centre in west London to Broadcasting House.

They will be joined by BBC World Service staff from Bush House in the Strand.

But the move back to Broadcasting House will not begin for at least six years and is expected to take up to eight to complete. Before that the Portland Place site will be redeveloped to house the 4,000 or so BBC network TV, radio and World Service journalists.

Architects MacCormac Jamieson Prichard have been appointed to design the new Broadcasting House complex, incorporating the existing BBC HQ building - which dates back to 1932 and is a Grade II listed building - and a new extension.

Two adjacent BBC offices built in the 1960s, Egton House - former home of Radio 1 - and 16 Langham Street, will be knocked down and redeveloped.

The announcement marks a U-turn for BBC bosses, who moved the Today staff and other radio journalists out of Broadcasting House just two years ago.

The move was part of BBC director of news Tony Hall's drive to create a bi-media TV and radio news operation and was bitterly opposed at the time by high profile journalists such as John Humphrys.

BBC network radio boss Liz Forgan also protested against the move and ultimately quit the corporation. She broke her silence about her resignation for the first time last week, branding the £41m move to west London a waste of licence-payers' money.

Ms Forgan's stance has now been vindicated with BBC bosses abandoning the bi-media offices as unworkable. Mr Hall also had to drop plans to move World Service staff to Stage Six, because of a lack of space.

Today journalists have claimed their concerns about not being able to attract such high calibre political interviewees to come to west London have been borne out. Many politicians are now interviewed from remote studios in central London, which critics believe means they are able to get off more lightly than if they were in a face-to-face interview in the Today studio.

Mr Hall said: "It has long been an ambition to bring BBC News together with World Service journalists. The redevelopment of Broadcasting House will provide an opportunity to realise that ambition to produce a global force in broadcasting unmatched anywhere else in the world."

The revamped Broadcasting House site will cover around 50,000 square foot of publicly accessible space, including a piazza with a bigger audience handling area for the BBC Radio Theatre.

The redevelopment is to be funded through the joint venture the BBC is in the process of establishing with a commercial partner to manage its property portfolio. Two consortia, Foresite and Insight, were shortlisted for the joint venture earlier this month and the deal is expected to be completed by spring 2001.

The BBC will have to negotiate a three year extension to its Bush House lease, which runs out in 2005, in ensure World Service staff can stay there until their new Broadcasting House accommodation is completed. TV Centre's Stage Six area will be inherited by BBC network TV production staff when BBC News moves out.

fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: Tired of meaningless statistics? With The Edge from IQ Sports, you get the numbers that count, so you can see precisely where a match was won and lost
fields.trailText: ARSENAL 5 - 0 MANCHESTER CITY
fields.body:
ARSENAL 5 - 0 MANCHESTER CITY

Key man: Ashley Cole won all 14 tackling attempts and scored the crucial opening goal.

Weak link: Only 1 attempt on goal for City all day.

The edge: Adams and Keown succeeded in 31 of 33 tackles as the Gunners won 83 of 90. Arsenal's control - 55% of net possession - was never in doubt.

ASTON VILLA 2 - 1 CHARLTON

Key man: Paul Merson with 7 effective crosses, 42 effective passes and the decisive goal.

Weak link: Despite his team-mates' 28 attempted crosses (of which 13 were effective), Dion Dublin managed only 3 attempts on goal - all off target.

The edge: Charlton attempted more tackles (213 to 139) and had slight edge in net possession (52%), but inaccurate crossing (3 of 20) saved Villa from much trouble.

CHELSEA 3 - 0 TOTTENHAM

Key man: Mario Melchiot completed 13 of 15 tackles and 57 of 70 passes to be the leading passer on the pitch.

Weak link: Vega's unnecessary hand ball gave Chelsea an early penalty and halted Spurs' momentum - the visitors had 3 shots on target in the opening 10 minutes.

The edge: Hasselbaink's accuracy overcame Spurs' early supremacy. Chelsea were the keener chasers, attempting 143 tackles to Tottenham's 103.

IPSWICH 2 - 1 MIDDLESBOROUGH

Key man: Mark Venus scored and was successful on 7 of 8 crosses, 48 passes and 7 of 10 tackles.

Weak link: Boro substituted all three starting strikers - but Job, Marinelli and Whelan could not produce a single shot at goal.

The edge: Ipswich got to work early, creating 6 attempts in first 20 minutes, and 2 goals by the half-hour. Ipswich had 60% of net possession and had 20 good crosses, while Boro had only 2.

LEICESTER 2 - 1 DERBY

Key man: Leicester's 6 second-half attempts came from 6 different players.

Weak link: After being Leicester's equals in first half - the teams had 4 attempts each - Derby were held to only 2 second half attempts, one from 35 yards out.

The edge: Leicester are taking their few chances - 5 of 9 attempts were on target - and playing it safe in defence, using the offside trap only once.

MANCHESTER UNITED 5 - 0 SOUTHAMPTON

Key man: Wes Brown won 15 of 16 tackles, Denis Irwin all 13 - and for once the United defence was not embarrassed by the Saints.

Weak link: Southampton's tackling was no challenge to United's ball control. The visitors were successful in less than 50% of their tackles, compared to United's 86%. The edge: United tackled deep, with Giggs, Butt and Scholes winning 25 of 27 tackles. Butt and Scholes completed 100 of 111 passes as United enjoyed 58% of net possession.

SUNDERLAND 1 - 0 COVENTRY

Key man: Chris Makin won 9 of 12 tackles and moved forward comfortably, completing 8 of 10 passes in forward 1/3.

Weak link: A clumsy 68% passing accuracy for both teams did not contribute to entertainment.

The edge: Sunderland had 56% of net possession, but Coventry did well to limit the Phillips-Quinn combo to 1 attempt on target. Paul Williams and Gary Breen won 35 of 36 tackles for Coventry, but Chris Kirklnad in goal passed 22 times to opposition.

WEST HAM 1 - 0 NEWCASTLE

Key man: Shaka Hilsop rescued the outplayed Hammers with 8 saves.

Weak link: West Ham's midfield England hopefuls Lampard (18), Carrick (11) and Cole (8) managed only 37 effective passes for the match.

The edge: Luck. Nolberto Solano was the most threatening player on the pitch with 11 effective crosses, 55 effective passes and 3 shots on target. Newcastle led 9 to 2 in shots on target.

LEICESTER 2 - 1 DERBY Key man: Leicester's 6 second-half attempts came from 6 different players. Weak link: After being Leicester's equals in first half - the teams had 4 attempts each - Derby were held to only 2 second half attempts, one from 35 yards out. Weak link: Southampton's tackling was no challenge to United's ball control. The visitors were successful in less than 50% of their tackles, compared to United's 86%. The edge: United tackled deep, with Giggs, Butt and Scholes winning 25 of 27 tackles. Butt and Scholes completed 100 of 111 passes as United enjoyed 58% of net possession. SUNDERLAND 1 - 0 COVENTRY Key man: Chris Makin won 9 of 12 tackles and moved forward comfortably, completing 8 of 10 passes in forward 1/3. Weak link: A clumsy 68% passing accuracy for both teams did not contribute to entertainment. The edge: Sunderland had 56% of net possession, but Coventry did well to limit the Phillips-Quinn combo to 1 attempt on target. Paul Williams and Gary Breen won 35 of 36 tackles for Coventry, but Chris Kirklnad in goal passed 22 times to opposition. WEST HAM 1 - 0 NEWCASTLE Key man: Shaka Hilsop rescued the outplayed Hammers with 8 saves. Weak link: West Ham's midfield England hopefuls Lampard (18), Carrick (11) and Cole (8) managed only 37 effective passes for the match. The edge: Luck. Nolberto Solano was the most threatening player on the pitch with 11 effective crosses, 55 effective passes and 3 shots on target. Newcastle led 9 to 2 in shots on target.

webTitle: Hatfield disaster a one-off, says Railtrack chief

fields.headline: Hatfield disaster a one-off, says Railtrack chief
fields.trailText: The rail network is safe and the catastrophic failure which caused the Hatfield disaster appears to have been an isolated case, the Railtrack chief executive said today.
fields.body:
The rail network is safe and the catastrophic failure which caused the Hatfield disaster appears to have been an isolated case, the Railtrack chief executive said today.

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Gerald Corbett said that the massive rail inspection programme which brought chaos to train services over the weekend had proved reassuring from a safety point of view.

"The positive thing that has come out of the 1,500 sites we have now inspected is that we haven't actually found another rail in the condition of the Hatfield rail," he said. "We have done the bulk of the inspections. It is all right, the network is safe, and it does now look as though Hatfield was an isolated example."

In the largest checks on Britain's railway for a century, 20,000 workers repaired thousands of metres of track over the weekend after engineers found some 1,850 hairline cracks similar to those thought to have caused the Hatfield crash.

After visiting the site of the Hatfield rail crash yesterday, Mr Corbett said that the beleaguered network had "turned the corner" after the blitz of safety work.

However, rail commuters would have found cold comfort in his statement this morning as they faced delays of up to two hours on some services as atrocious weather scuppered any hopes for a rapid return to full services. The worst storm of the year lashed Britain with driving rain and gale-force winds killing at least one person and causing transport chaos as many train and subway services were suspended due to falling trees.

Meanwhile, the rail industry will come under close scrutiny in the second part of the Ladbroke Grove rail Inquiry, which opens in Westminster central hall in London today.

Chaired by Lord Cullen, it will examine safety on the network as a whole, taking in some seven major incidents since 1989. At a news conference scheduled for today, leading members of the survivors group are expected to give their reactions to the Hatfield crash and to the lessons they say Railtrack has to learn.

fields.headline: Author attacks Lyme Regis plan
fields.trailText: The author John Fowles has joined a campaign against a housing development in Lyme Regis, saying it threatened to turn the seaside idyll into "Surrey by the sea".
fields.body:
The author John Fowles has joined a campaign against a housing development in Lyme Regis, saying it threatened to turn the seaside idyll into "Surrey by the sea".

Residents fear the proposal would ruin the view from the Dorset town's harbour and its stone breakwater, the Cobb, that was made famous by the film of Fowles's novel, The French Lieutenant's Woman.

He has joined 20 other residents in objecting to an application to turn a hotel into five houses, seven flats and four two-storey homes, which would also mean felling a number of trees.

If approved by West Dorset council, the homes would sit on the highest land in the town, dominating its skyline, say the protesters.

In a letter to the local weekly, Fowles warns that Lyme Regis could fail in its attempt to become a world heritage site. "Lyme Regis is treasured by us who are lucky enough to live here but it is equally loved by visitors from around the world," he wrote. "Let's stop destroying it and turning into another little suburban town.

"These [trees] all give a wonderful skyline looking up from the Cobb and Marine Parade. Why allow these visible trees to be given over to car parking? I am sure West Dorset council is aware this coast is nominated to become a Unesco world heritage site, so to turn Lyme Regis into Surrey-by-the-sea may not help this cause which is so important to Dorset."

Fowles, who has lived in Dorset since 1966 and published his novel in 1969, told an interviewer this year: "I could not wake up and not hear the sounds of the waves."

webTitle: Eta blamed as Madrid car bomb kills three

fields.headline: Eta blamed as Madrid car bomb kills three
fields.trailText: Three people were killed and at least 30 others were seriously injured when a suspected Basque separatist car bomb rocked a residential area of Madrid during rush hour this morning, police said.
fields.body:
Three people were killed and at least 30 others were seriously injured when a suspected Basque separatist car bomb rocked a residential area of Madrid during rush hour this morning, police said.

A judge at Spain's Supreme Court was one of the three who were killed when the powerful bomb rocked a residential area of Madrid this morning, police said.

The bomb was blamed Basque separatist group Eta, a court source said, adding that the judge, Jose Francisco Querol, was responsible for military hearings at the court.

State radio said that the other two victims of the explosion in the Madrid suburb of Arturo Soria were the judge's driver and his bodyguard.

The blast occurred at 8.15am as people were going to work in the area and children were going to schools in Artura Soria area of north-east Madrid.

Although no group has so far claimed the blast, police and media immediately accused the Basque separatist group Eta, which has frequently used car bombs as part of its 32-year campaign for Basque independence.

The group is blamed for some 800 killings since 1968, including 16 so far this year. Its last attributed attack was October 22, when a prison officer was killed by a bomb that was attached to his car.

Today's blast also left one municipal transport bus completely burnt out. Several of the injured were caught in the vehicle.

Police cordoned off the area for fear that another bomb may be planted in the zone.

The explosion smashed windows and damaged several buildings, and police had to evacuate several people from their homes, Spanish National Radio said.

fields.headline: Disney ploughs millions into Go.com relaunch
fields.trailText: 8am: Go.com is ploughing £21m into an ad campaign promoting a radical revamp of the website, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Go.com is ploughing $30m (£20m) into an advertising campaign promoting a radical revamp of the website.

Go.com's parent, the Walt Disney Company, designed the site as an internet portal to compete with the likes of America Online, Microsoft's MSN and Yahoo.

Crucially, the Go network was supposed to link all the Disney online services, including ABCNews.com, Disney.com and ESPN.com.

When it became obvious that Go was incapable of competing effectively against the larger portals, executives who oversee Disney's internet operations - now called the Walt Disney Internet Group - decided to narrow its focus.

The site now serves as a search engine for men and women aged 18 to 49, finding them relevant information about activities including entertainment, sports and travel.

The campaign, created by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York, will include television, radio and press ads, which will run across the US and Europe presenting the site as "your guide to a better time". It adds: "There's fun stuff all around you. You just have to know where to look."

TV work features people engaged in everyday tasks such as weeding the garden, walking around a farm or killing time at work who are surprised by a sudden encounter with a circus, concert or sky-diving lesson.

Online advertising - created in-house and by two San Francisco specialty shops, Pop Media and Tonic 360 - will support the rebranding.

In addition, elaborate promotional campaigns are planned with Go.com partners including Carsmart.com and Travelocity.com and Disney-backed ventures such as Walt Disney World, "Good Morning America" and ESPN.

webTitle: Hearts and Bones spared the axe

fields.headline: Hearts and Bones 'too expensive to ditch'
fields.trailText: 12pm: BBC drama Hearts and Bones has been saved from the axe after BBC chiefs discovered it was too expensive to ditch, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC drama Hearts and Bones has been narrowly saved from the axe after BBC chiefs discovered it was too expensive to ditch.

Sources say BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey wanted to dump the high-profile drama after just one series but was told it would cost £500,000 to break the contract with the show's producer, United Productions.

The series, which starred Dervla Kirwan, Amanda Holden and Hugo Speer, mustered just 5m viewers when it was aired earlier this year.

However, it won critical acclaim and was recommissioned by recently departed BBC1 controller Peter Salmon.

It is understood that Ms Heggessey was not such a big fan and wanted to get rid of the show.

But she was told that contracts for a second series had been signed and the BBC would have had to pay out over £300,000 for the talent deals that were already in place.

A further sum of around £200,000 would have gone on production fees.

A BBC spokeswoman said that the contractual status of the show was always known and that Ms Heggessey had "looked at it and thought it had the potential for a second series".

She said the show had been in fact recommissioned by Ms Heggessey. However, reports as far back as June confirm that United had been commissioned to do a second series.

webTitle: Carlton and Sainsbury's name new venture

fields.headline: Carlton and Sainsbury's name new venture
fields.trailText: 10.30amCarlton Communications and Sainbury's are considering calling their new food-themed TV and internet joint venture Taste, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications and Sainbury's are considering calling their new food-themed TV and internet joint venture Taste.

The two companies are expected next month to unveil full details of the joint venture, which will bring together Carlton's pay-TV channel, Carlton Food Network, and SimplyFood.com website under a new generic brand name.

Taste is said to be the favoured option for the new name.

Carlton insiders believe earlier fears of redundancies will prove unfounded, with all former Carlton Digital staff who were working on CFN or SimplyFood moving into the new company or to jobs elsewhere at Carlton.

But CFN channel director Anne Gray has resigned. Ms Gray, who joined Carlton to run now-defunct entertainment channel Carlton Select and oversaw the launch of CFN in September 1996, said she would be leaving the company at the end of the year after overseeing the handover to the new joint venture.

Ms Gray has been working on Carlton's pay-TV channels for more than four years and said it was "time for a change".

Carlton and Sainsbury's originally announced they were forming a joint venture based around CFN and SimplyFood in May.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week eleven, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week eleven, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray dissects the latest bets
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.59, Sean Ingle = £103.12, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.89, Paul MacInnes = £61.59
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.59, Sean Ingle = £103.12, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.89, Paul MacInnes = £61.59

Scott Murray
Barnsley to beat Preston @ 4/1 - £5

Clearly the talent was always there but I like to think I have helped to bring it to the fore, moulding Mr Murray into a lean mean punting machine. Everything he touches turns to gold. While the likes of you and I would be more than happy with a strike rate of three out of ten for our four and five to one shots, Scott wins every week.

But before he clears his desk, ties his hankerchief to his stick and heads for the promised land of professional gambling I should make it clear that the streets are not, in fact, paved with gold. To win as often as Mr M is at the moment will always be as much luck as judgement. The point about value bets is that you're not trying to win every week (though you're hoping to), you're trying to win in the long run.

Scott has proved himself a good spotter of value, the most important thing now - the thing so many potentially good gamblers fall down on - is not to get carried away. Scott must keep doing the things that are winning him money, and avoid getting overambitious, thinking himself unbeatable. It's harder than it sounds, whether Mr M is up to it we'll find out soon enough.

Sean Ingle
£2 win double on Valencia to beat Osasuna @ 11/10 and Alaves to beat Rayo Vallecano @ 5/2. Also £5 single on Valencia to win and £3 single on Alaves to win. Total stake = £10.

"Joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance." So joy indeed that Mr Ingle, the wayward son for so long, is finally showing signs of listening to the gospel according to Patrick Murray.

There is no doubting the boy's knowledge of football but it is only now that we are seeing this knowledge put to good use. For once Mr I resisted the temptation for a big hit and concentrated on singles. Et voila - a winning week. It's also good to see Mr I continuing down the European road after last week's tentative but successful first steps. As I explained last week: Europe is where the value lies, where the clued-up, hardworking punter can get an edge on the lazy, uninformed bookmaker.

So Mr Ingle is back on track after a rocky couple of weeks but, like Scott, must avoid getting carried away. Keep doing the simple things right and the money will accumulate. Honest.

Punters Collective: Patrick Viner, a freelance worker from France
£5 win single: Sunderland v Coventry; Coventry to win @ 4/1

This was a valiant effort by Mr Viner. I've come to expect insane multiples from our guest punters as they seize their fifteen minutes of fame and go down all guns blazing, hence the rather unhealthy balance in the guest account.

Mr V, on the other hand, is clearly a team player, putting the collective good before his own stab at glory. The bet itself seems a reasonable one, though as Mr Viner himself concedes, the draw was a big runner so perhaps the Asian handicap was the better market to play on. More guest punters like this please, Mr Guardian.

Paul MacInnes
Liverpool v Everton, 0 or 1 goals @ 13/5 - £5

This is sad. I can hear the desperation in Mr MacInnes's voice and there is no room for desperation in gambling. And worse than that he slags off Asian handicaps, the cheeky blighter: "The Asian handicap is boring," he says.

Well, I never get bored with winning, Mr MacInnes. I have no particular qualms with the bet itself, I would have gone for no goalscorer myself but doubtless Paul finds that boring too.

Paul is having a bad run, it happens to us all. The important thing is not to panic. It could just be bad luck, you're taking the value but its yet to pay off, or it could be you're doing something fundamentally wrong. As long as you can review your betting patterns and ascertain which it is you should be alright.

You should always be looking back over your bets and objectively analysing them, remembering that a winner was not necessarily a good bet nor a loser a bad one. Some day, dear punter, if we just put in the work, and use analysis not instinct the likes of you and I may be as good as Scott Murray. Happy punting.

fields.headline: Wretched Rangers aid Celtic cause
fields.trailText: Celtic had to battle hard for a point in a 3-3 draw in a compelling match against Motherwell yesterday that restores a three-point cushion at the top. Much more significant is the gap of 13 points which has now opened up between the two Glasgow rivals after Rangers' shock 3-0 defeat at home to Kilmarnock on Saturday. It was their third successive league defeat and leaves manager Dick Advocaat having to fight his way out of the worst corner he has known in 20 years as a coach.

It was their third successive league defeat and leaves manager Dick Advocaat having to fight his way out of the worst corner he has known in 20 years as a coach.

But Celtic will feel aggrieved not to have secured an outright victory here after referee Hugh Dallas failed to spot a Johan Mjallby 'goal' which TV replays proved had crossed the line midway through the second half.

An ankle injury prevented Chris Sutton from taking part but even in his absence Celtic dominated the opening exchanges. The Motherwell goalkeeper Stephen Woods exhibited his vulnerability by failing to collect a 14th-minute corner which Larsson immediately headed back into a crowded area where Johan Mjallby was waiting to blast in from unmissable range.

Motherwell showed their mettle by forcing an equaliser within 10 minutes. Joos Valgaeren half cut out a through-ball, allowing John Spencer to put in a cross that Tom Boyd could only help up into the air and, when it came down, Derek Adams beat Valgaeren and headed into the net.

Eight minutes after half-time, Motherwell took the lead for the only time in the game. Brannan was the architect with a superb pass that sent Stuart Elliott heading menacingly for goal and, although he ended up with only a corner, it was enough to supply Lee McCulloch for a headed finish.

But that lead lasted just four minutes as Motherwell themselves failed to deal with a set-piece, a corner delivered by Thompson. Larsson nodded it down and Valgaeren smashed it in from close range.

Then came the frustration of Mjallby's disallowed goal, with replays showing it should have been allowed. As if aggrieved, Celtic took the lead in the 72nd minute through Jackie McNamara, who rolled the ball past Woods after Larsson set him up.

Yet Motherwell were not to be denied and Mjallby pushed the substitute Don Goodman over and Brannan made no mistake from the spot to win a precious point for his side.

Dick Advocaat must have looked on enviously at the endeavour and spirit shown by Celtic. His side can boast only one win, one draw and five defeats in the past seven matches. Rangers have not slumped like this in the Scottish Premier League in seven years and not for a further 10 had they lost three league games in a row. Rubbing salt into Ibrox wounds has come a further unexpected twist - a sudden turnaround of fortunes in the Champions League which had started so brightly but which now threatens to collapse against Monaco a week tomorrow.

In addition his Rangers squad is currently being crippled by injury. Advocaat, in paying his respects to Kilmarnock, exhibited a warming grace after this match, but no Rangers manager could withstand the temporary loss of Stefan Klos, Michael Mols, Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Jorg Albertz, Barry Ferguson and Claudio Reyna among six others. The heart of Advocaat's team has been gouged out.

Rumours persist that there is disharmony in the Rangers dressing room - at least according to one former alumnus, Ally McCoist. Advocaat also has a liability in his captain Lorenzo Amoruso, who on Saturday, not for the first time, indulged in a row with a team-mate on the pitch - this time Arthur Numan.

"It was another poor performance from us," said Advocaat. "We are lacking confidence right now, not just as a team, but individually as well. The players' confidence is low and it is my job to rebuild that. We need to get results. I don't like to make an excuse - but the truth is no manager could go without 10 injured first-team players as we are doing at the moment. If people are to judge me, let them do so when my team is playing, not when so many players are out."

fields.headline: Liverpool reign in Merseyside downpour
fields.standfirst: Ian Ross sees a turncoat ignite an explosive match at Anfield
fields.trailText: Before the dogs of war were unleashed in this Merseyside derby, the focal point for the ritualistic bloodletting was the young man who famously declared he couldn't understand what all the fuss was about when he swapped blue for red last summer.
fields.body:
Before the dogs of war were unleashed in this Merseyside derby, the focal point for the ritualistic bloodletting was the young man who famously declared he couldn't understand what all the fuss was about when he swapped blue for red last summer.

Nick Barmby's butter-wouldn't-melt features had a slightly grey hue to them as frightful, spiteful abuse rolled down from around a stadium which was so enveloped by emotion that, at times, it seemed fit to burst. He was, however, to have if not the day's final word then a major say in the outcome.

Barmby's opener was a curious goal, for while his flying header was beautifully executed, the manner of the ball's delivery into his path was fortuitous, Christian Ziege's shot clipping Abel Xavier and looping high into the slate-grey skies.

"He was very professional. It was a special day and it has not been easy for him," said the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier of his £6m man.

"As soon as his chance came I knew he would score, I just told him to keep focused."

All that was missing from this encounter was the kitchen sink and fittingly it was in the midst of a downpour that the tide was finally turned on Merseyside.

After emerging victorious from just one of their 12 previous league meetings with their neighbours, Liverpool fashioned a win which keeps them treading on the coat-tails of the Premiership's leading pair.

The home side played marginally better than they had three days earlier against the Czech minnows of Slovan Liberec, but that observation merely damns them with faint praise. There was an improvement, particularly as the afternoon wore on, but, in truth, the gap between Liverpool's performances and their potential is still frustratingly wide.

Either side of Barmby's opener, two of Everton's early chances fell not to Kevin Campbell or to Paul Gascoigne but to Mark Pembridge, a tenacious-enough midfielder but a man who has never really mastered the art of clinical finishing.

After five minutes Pembridge somehow contrived to lift the ball well wide of the far post when only the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld stood in his way. Then eight minutes later he inexplicably hooked wide.

But a sense of meaningful perspective was returned to the afternoon on 17 minutes when Everton's tidy football was finally rewarded, Campbell turning home from close range after David Weir had been allowed to turn an Idan Tal corner back across the face of goal.

That nicely worked goal was to represent the summit of Everton's achievement, for the limitations of what is a thin and depleted squad were particularly evident in a second half which Liverpool dominated with such ease that it made their first-half contribution all the more unpalatable.

Once Emile Heskey had claimed a sixth goal in four games - a powerful low drive which skipped off a sodden surface - Liverpool were all but home.

The frantically paced football which had sustained Everton began to slacken off, Dietmar Hamann finally began to match the superb Gascoigne in central midfield and the pendulum had swung, decisively so.

It got worse for Everton. With 13 minutes remaining, substitute Gary Naysmith failed to intercept Westerveld's long clearance and Vladimir Smicer's run on goal was only ended by Thomas Gravesen's illegal tackle. Gravesen, the best player on the pitch by some distance, was sent off and Patrik Berger rifled home the resultant penalty to end all the arguments.

Houllier viewed Heskey's goal as the game's turning point. "The lad is only 22 and I believe he can become a truly great goalscorer in the future," he beamed.

But the Everton manager Walter Smith was unhappy with his side's defeat.

"We started well, and in the first half we should have been in front. We created our best opportunities but we were unable to maintain that level throughout."

fields.headline: British Council PR junket criticised
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The British Council has come under fire for spending thousands of pounds on a week-long junket to Shanghai. By Claire Cozens
fields.body:
A government-funded body has come under fire today for spending thousands of pounds on taking a group of advertising and PR execs on a week-long junket to Shanghai.

The British Council is paying out an estimated £25,000 for a group of 12 senior players in the advertising, PR and internet industries to present their services to companies in China.

The government will foot more than half the bill for the trip through its export organisation, Trade Partners UK, with the remainder being paid for by the British Council - itself half-funded by the taxpayer.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth called the trip a waste of tax-payers money.

The delegates are all contributing to the cost of their trip, which takes place this week, but they will each receive a £600 grant from Trade Partners UK for travel, accommodation and food in China.

One of the most prominent delegates is Chris Powell, chairman of BMP DDB, the ad agency behind the Labour party's 1997 election campaign. Others include Robert Campbell, creative director of ad agency Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, Mark Cridge, managing director of the online media agency Glue Media, and Alison Clarke, president of the Institute of Public Relations.

Mr Ainsworth said: "I am a big fan of the ad industry, but I think they rank pretty low down the list of deserving causes. There's no doubt that British companies lead the world in advertising. We are very creative and have a great deal to offer China. But it beats me why the taxpayer should become involved in this."

Andrew Senior, head of creative industries for the British Council, said: "The council is increasingly moving across from promoting the arts towards areas such as architecture, film and design. Advertising and PR fit in very well with that. We are not seeking to be an export agency, but advertising is a very strong area for the UK and we recognise that people probably see more advertising than they do anything else."

Mr Senior added that the creative industries are currently one of the UK's biggest exporters, with 16% of their products being sold overseas.

"They have achieved that with no real government help, which begs the question of what they could do with some help," he said. "You wouldn't get such a diverse mixture of companies getting together for a trip that was funded by the industry."

The main focus of the trip is a one-day seminar entitled "Getting results from your communications", where Chinese companies will see presentations from senior members of the British marketing industry on advertising, PR and new media.

The British Council was set up in 1936 to counteract the negative effects of Nazi propaganda on the image of the nation. It is funded partly by the government and partly by income from commercial activities abroad, such as English language teaching.

webTitle: Roy Greenslade on: How the Mail could save the Express

fields.headline: How the Mail could save the Express
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade on why an unlikely-sounding deal could work.
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on why an unlikely-sounding deal could work.
fields.body:
If anyone can save the Daily Express, it's the Daily Mail. This has long been the view of the wiser press commentators, but it has usually been accompanied by shrugs and the shaking of heads. After all, it just wouldn't be plausible, would it?

The government would never wear it. The competition commission would outlaw it. The media ownership rules could not be stretched to accommodate it. The idea was out of the question. Now the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) has turned the notion from a hypothetical dream into reality. Its bid for its century-old rival is very serious indeed, and it has not allowed the news to slip into the public domain without having a strategy to overcome both the political and commercial hurdles.

Let's consider how Lord Rothermere's team will jump them, with a little help from a usually reliable DMGT source. First, the problem probably uppermost in the mind of Tony Blair and his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, not to mention Labour politicians up and down the land, is the danger of the Express adopting an aggressive rightwing stance similar to the Mail's.

It would, of course, be foolish for the Mail to publish a quasi-Mail. I understand that DMGT has been impressed with the response to its apolitical, non-ideological morning giveaway paper, the Metro, and would seek to transform the Express into a more neutral, less politically committed, paper.

Some Mail executives believe this reflects the times in which we live. The central argument over the economy has been settled in favour of free-market capitalism so the differences between parties are now largely matters of degree. Young readers, the ones most sought by all papers, are no longer interested in political arguments.

But the company would not change the Express instantly, giving a guarantee that its current political viewpoint, which is broadly pro-Labour, if occasionally critical, would be maintained up to at least the next general election. This would also mean that, if she wished, editor Rosie Boycott could remain in place with her senior team. She would therefore be in a position to assess whether she wished to stay on to oversee the paper's gradual transformation.

My DMGT source also stressed that, apart from the Daily Mail, the wider Associated Newspapers stable is not noted for running Tory-supporting, rightwing papers. Some of the provincial evenings, he suggested, even support Labour.

I raised my eyebrows at that, just as I did when he claimed that the Mail on Sunday "doesn't really have a rightwing agenda". In fairness, the London Evening Standard has often found itself lining up on the side of New Labour, and Metro has eschewed any political line. Associated's sprawling, pluralistic media operations also include Teletext which certainly has an ethos of impartiality.

It will be interesting to see whether Blair and Campbell accept this viewpoint, but it wouldn't surprise me if they did, because they will be pleased with the pledge about the Express's stance leading up to the election.

They will doubtless want to feel confident in the composition of the editorial board of independent directors which DMGT says it will appoint to ensure that its promises are kept. What then of the commercial argument? No one, even those of us who disparage the Daily Mail's social and political agenda, can deny that the paper is Fleet Street's most efficient and best-resourced editorial operation. Its investment in journalism and commitment to technical excellence have made it the best popular paper since Hugh Cudlipp's Daily Mirror of the 1950s and 60s.

So it comes as no surprise that DMGT will promise to invest £50m a year for five years in the Express titles. The company knows that ever since Lord Beaverbrook's demise in 1964 the titles have suffered from continual cuts which have eaten away at their ability to compete. Over the years I would estimate that DMGT spent £100m on the Mail on Sunday before it came into profit, and the Metro investment has been high too. It therefore has a track record of spending, it has the money and, more importantly, it has been given the will to succeed by the young Lord Rothermere and his editor-in-chief Paul Dacre.

Dacre - who joined the Express from university in the 70s and eventually became its US correspondent before the Mail poached him - has always believed that there is an audience for the paper and his sadness at its decline has been genuine. There is no question of the Mail doing to the Express what it did to the News Chronicle in 1960. In other words, this is not a ploy designed to kill off the Express by "merging" it with the Mail.

It would appear from its investment pledge that it is giving the Express at least five years to find its footing, which is about as good as it gets for a paper which is no longer turning a profit. Research by DMGT, especially among readers of the Metro, suggests there is a big untapped market among young people requiring crisp, impartial news. (I must register a cavil here since I don't believe any news is impartial, but it's their argument, not mine).

Then there is the Daily Star. Again, DMGT promises not to shut it but to expand and strengthen the paper. It is viewed as a fine platform from which to build a red-top targeted more purposefully at the Mirror and the Sun.

This, incidentally, is a very shrewd move for the Mail. The Star surprised its rivals by doing well in the first three years after its 1978 launch but lost its way. If it could be revived, the Sun and Mirror - which have both sought to move upmarket to confront the Mail - would have to watch their flanks.

There is, needless to say, a strong back-office argument in favour of the deal. Way back, when Lord Stevens was running the Express titles, his managing director, Andy Cameron, had a series of meetings with the then managing director of Associated Newspapers, Bert Hardy, to discuss ways of merging the titles' printing, distribution, newsprint-buying and, possibly, other facilities.

Both men realised there could be tremendous savings, but Rothermere and Stevens, for personal reasons which were never clear, eventually balked at the idea.

Since then, the Telegraph group has been running a 50-50 joint publishing operation with the Express's owners, United News & Media. fields.bodyText: If anyone can save the Daily Express, it's the Daily Mail. This has long been the view of the wiser press commentators, but it has usually been accompanied by shrugs and the shaking of heads. After all, it just wouldn't be plausible, would it? The government would never wear it. The competition commission would outlaw it. The media ownership rules could not be stretched to accommodate it. The idea was out of the question. Now the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) has turned the notion from a hypothetical dream into reality. Its bid for its century-old rival is very serious indeed, and it has not allowed the news to slip into the public domain without having a strategy to overcome both the political and commercial hurdles. Let's consider how Lord Rothermere's team will jump them, with a little help from a usually reliable DMGT source. First, the problem probably uppermost in the mind of Tony Blair and his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, not to mention Labour politicians up and down the land, is the danger of the Express adopting an aggressive rightwing stance similar to the Mail's. It would, of course, be foolish for the Mail to publish a quasi-Mail. I understand that DMGT has been impressed with the response to its apolitical, non-ideological morning giveaway paper, the Metro, and would seek to transform the Express into a more neutral, less politically committed, paper. Some Mail executives believe this reflects the times in which we live. The central argument over the economy has been settled in favour of free-market capitalism so the differences between parties are now largely matters of degree. Young readers, the ones most sought by all papers, are no longer interested in political arguments. But the company would not change the Express instantly, giving a guarantee that its current political viewpoint, which is broadly pro-Labour, if occasionally critical, would be maintained up to at least the next general election. This would also mean that, if she wished, editor Rosie Boycott could remain in place with her senior team. She would therefore be in a position to assess whether she wished to stay on to oversee the paper's gradual transformation. My DMGT source also stressed that, apart from the Daily Mail, the wider Associated Newspapers stable is not noted for running Tory-supporting, rightwing papers. Some of the provincial evenings, he suggested, even support Labour. I raised my eyebrows at that, just as I did when he claimed that the Mail on Sunday "doesn't really have a rightwing agenda". In fairness, the London Evening Standard has often found itself lining up on the side of New Labour, and Metro has eschewed any political line. Associated's sprawling, pluralistic media operations also include Teletext which certainly has an ethos of impartiality. It will be interesting to see whether Blair and Campbell accept this viewpoint, but it wouldn't surprise me if they did, because they will be pleased with the pledge about the Express's stance leading up to the election. They will doubtless want to feel confident in the composition of the editorial board of independent directors which DMGT says it will appoint to ensure that its promises are kept. What then of the commercial argument? No one, even those of us who disparage the Daily Mail's social and political agenda, can deny that the paper is Fleet Street's most efficient and best-resourced editorial operation. Its investment in journalism and commitment to technical excellence have made it the best popular paper since Hugh Cudlipp's Daily Mirror of the 1950s and 60s. So it comes as no surprise that DMGT will promise to invest £50m a year for five years in the Express titles. The company knows that ever since Lord Beaverbrook's demise in 1964 the titles have suffered from continual cuts which have eaten away at their ability to compete. Over the years I would estimate that DMGT spent £100m on the Mail on Sunday before it came into profit, and the Metro investment has been high too. It therefore has a track record of spending, it has the money and, more importantly, it has been given the will to succeed by the young Lord Rothermere and his editor-in-chief Paul Dacre. webTitle: The question is, what's in it for me?

fields.headline: The question is, what's in it for me?
fields.standfirst: View from Here by Tim Hayward.
fields.trailText: View from Here by Tim Hayward.
fields.body:
I've always been uncomfortable with the idea of "surfing". It always seems a perfectly adequate metaphor for 26-year-old American web kids, lean, bronzed and teetering with cat-like agility on the breaking edge of the technological tsunami. But I'm British. The idea of an Englishman "surfing" is inherently daft. I've always rather felt that "Pottering" was the proper term.

Unfortunately "searching" and "surfing" have become the two defining patterns for web use. Marketers fondly imagine web users are either diligently hunting for tiny nuggets of relevance or are richocheting wildly around a funhouse of weird, free content. So the strategy for a successful web operation is a) advertise hugely so they know what to search for and b) make the site "sticky" so they don't just surf off to some far more compelling site concerned with cheerleaders' underwear or pirate garage.

Marketers refer to these issues as "acquisition" and "retention" and the debate rages daily on how a budget is split between the two. Last week first-e, the internet bank, pulled its advertising campaign, quoting acquisition costs of up to £250 per customer. That is clearly too high, particularly in a sector where margins are being eroded so fast, but until now it's never seemed to be a problem for web companies who have historically chucked unbelievable amounts of investor cash at customer acquisition. According to management consultants McKinsey, 98.7% of visitors to a web site never return, regardless of whether or not they've made or attempted a purchase. First-e realised that getting customers in is only part of the story. It's quite another keeping them long enough to recoup that acquisition investment in a market characterised by "endemic consumer disloyalty".

For users, of course, neither searching nor surfing really answers their needs. Search engines are neither comprehensive nor accurate and surfing pretty soon bears out Bruce Springsteen's memorable observation - "57 channels and still nothing on". Five years ago, the MIT futurist Nicholas Negroponte was talking about the answer, in the form of "agent technology", software that the user briefs to deliver relevant content.

Personalisation has been offered as an interim solution but it doesn't come cheap for web site owners. Naturally, most want lots of personal details in exchange for relevant content delivery, which can be a problem. Registration is a chore and most people just can't be arsed. Customers also have a sneaking suspicion that they'll be carpet-bombed with irrelevant marketing junk if they divulge their email address. Sadly, they're usually right.

Several technology companies are currently punting enhancements to browsers which go out onto the web and get the stuff you've specifically requested, without you having to surf - check the usual raft of daft names, Octopus, PurpleYogi, Yodlee, Dodots, and a UK version, KeepUpdated. They are beginning to fulfil Negroponte's vision of a constant feed of blindingly relevant stuff he called the "Daily Me". KeepUpdated handily does this while retaining the user's anonymity, avoiding the need to register a name or an email address.

This might be permission marketing at its most elegant. If users can go to a web site just once, declare their interest through an anonymous profiling exercise, and then get only what they've asked for, they might get over their apathy.

If KeepUpdated tells me there's a two-bedroom flat in my price range which has just come on the market I might peek at the page on the host web site (anonymously) and decide to declare my interest if I make an appointment to view. Moreover.com users will be familiar with this concept for news. Choose your area and they'll serve up the stories you want to read as they're published on the web. Imagine this service applied to everything on the web and you're getting close to what these sites can do.

If I'm a website owner this is great news. There might just be another way of getting the sale which doesn't involve me reminding people to come back to my site. Let them decide what they want and only come back when they know what they're going to get. That way I won't have to worry about "stickiness", and I can stop generic web advertising for anything but awareness. The technology is free to both consumers and web site owners. Money is made from matching consumers with content they've already asked for. Neat.

This might be the end of web surfing and the hideous mental image of fat, pasty Brits falling off longboards, or it might just be an overdue break for frustrated marketers. Just one tiny shift in the right direction on that "98.7% of visitors never return" figure makes a huge difference to results and, given market sentiment right now, we all need all the help we can get.
