webTitle: Barak walks a tightrope as Likud talks collapse

fields.headline: Barak walks a tightrope as Likud talks collapse
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, walks bloodied and alone into a hostile parliament today, opposed by three-quarters of its members, after failing to forge an emergency government with the rightwing Likud party.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, walks bloodied and alone into a hostile parliament today, opposed by three-quarters of its members, after failing to forge an emergency government with the rightwing Likud party.

After days of negotiations conducted against a backdrop of continued killing in the West Bank and Gaza, Mr Barak and the hawkish Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, remained locked in disagreement yesterday. "I do not think there will be a new government," Mr Barak's spokesman, Gaddi Baltiansky, said .

That signals the countdown towards elections, only 17 months after Mr Barak swept to power promising to storm the citadels of peace.

Labour and Likud say their talks broke down over Mr Sharon's demand for a veto on security decisions and a commitment from Mr Barak to renounce the compromises offered at July's Camp David summit and prolong his suspension of negotiations with the Palestinians.

Efforts to form an emergency government will continue, however.

Mr Barak called a "time-out" from the peace process earlier this month, until the weeks of bloodshed that have killed 140 people subside.

But there was no sign of an end to the violence yesterday, when Israeli troops shot dead two Palestinians in the West Bank city of Nablus and tank commanders turned their machine-guns on protesters on the borders of Gaza, where another Palestinian died.

Elsewhere in Gaza, Palestinians set off a homemade bomb and opened fire on a bus carrying settlers. No one was hurt. Shots were also fired across Israel's border with Lebanon in the north.

Despite the horrific losses to his people the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, said the protests were far from at an end. "The blessed intifada of our people will continue," he said in a statement.

In public at least Mr Barak too shown no sign of softening. Yesterday he was bitterly criticised by two icons of peace: the former prime minister Shimon Peres and Leah Rabin, widow of the assassinated leader Yitzhak Rabin, for blocking efforts to open a channel to Mr Arafat.

But despite his harsh pronouncements against Mr Arafat, Mr Barak is quietly pursuing a two-track policy. In political circles there is a great expectation that both men could bow to pressure from President Clinton to visit Washington - possibly even before the US elections next week.

The prospect of such a visit is anathema to Mr Sharon, who has been egged on by the Likud's rumbustious rightwing to make the peace process hostage to the party joining an emergency government.

Although the numbers are against Mr Barak when parliament resumes today, he may be able to continue with the support of just 30 of the in the 120 members. The Likud and other opponents would be loath to bring him down at a time of crisis, for fear of being punished for their treachery by the electorate.

His government will be paralysed, but even that is preferable to left-leaning members of his party than the flirtation with Mr Sharon.

Several Labour members argue that bringing Mr Sharon into the government would destroy the last remnants of Palestinian trust in Mr Barak's commitment to peace, and inflict huge damage on Israel's international reputation.

Widely reviled in the Arab world, Mr Sharon ignited Palestinian frustrations by his visit to the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem on September 28, the act that provoked the unrest.

webTitle: Ministers reject proposal for EU-wide passport

fields.headline: Ministers reject proposal for EU-wide passport
fields.trailText: British ministers rejected draft proposals that could lead to the creation of a standardised EU-wide passport yesterday as European Commission officials in Brussels confirmed the move was one of several options under consideration.
fields.body:
British ministers rejected draft proposals that could lead to the creation of a standardised EU-wide passport yesterday as European Commission officials in Brussels confirmed the move was one of several options under consideration.

The suggestion from Antonio Vitorino, the EU's Italian commissioner for justice and home affairs, was picked up by the Brussels-based magazine, European Voice, and spotted on its website by Euro-sceptic Sunday newspapers in London.

The Home and Foreign offices were quick to stress that Britain and other EU member states would block such a move - though officials insisted ministers were aware of it before being told by the Mail on Sunday. They stressed that the Vitorino draft has not yet been seen by fellow commissioners, who include Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten.

Francis Maude, the Tory foreign affairs spokesman, said: "The passport is a symbol of the nation. The EU is trying to give itself another of the trappings of statehood."

"There is no such proposal," Mr Vitorino's spokesman, Leonello Gabrici, explained last night. "But we are working on ideas to make travel documents more secure."

fields.headline: Peruvian soldiers seize mining town
fields.trailText: More than 50 soldiers led by a middle-ranking commander vowing to safeguard the honour of the army, and refusing to recognise the authority of President Alberto Fujimori, took control of a prominent mining town in southern Peru yesterday, blocking passage in or out.
fields.body:
More than 50 soldiers led by a middle-ranking commander vowing to safeguard the honour of the army, and refusing to recognise the authority of President Alberto Fujimori, took control of a prominent mining town in southern Peru yesterday, blocking passage in or out.

The uprising, in Toquepala, near the Chilean border, came a day after Mr Fujimori sacked his armed forces chief and three top generals in an effort to strengthen his grip on power, which is apparently being challenged by his fugitive former chief of intelligence, Vladimiro Montesinos.

"I will only lay down my arms when the chain of command is legitimate and there is a president who has been truly elected by the people to whom I would swear subordination and valour," the commander, Ollanta Moises Humala Tasso, told Reuters in a fax addressed to the Peruvian nation.

The army condemned the uprising as "a serious situation of indiscipline" and said it would take "appropriate action to put an end to this activity and safeguard the social and political stability of the country".

It said two officers, 49 soldiers and three unidentified civilians had also taken over the nearby copper mine. This was confirmed by a resident of the town who called a local radio station, contradicting earlier denials by mine officials.

"They're not letting anyone out," the caller said. "My husband is working [in the mining complex] and he can't come home. He called me and told me he couldn't leave."

Commander Humala Tasso said he was acting out of "duty" during a moral, political and economic crisis.

"I have the backing of those who are here. There are a lot of colleagues of mine who have the same idea," he told RPP radio by phone. "It's time this crisis situation was resolved for the good of everyone."

Mr Fujimori has been fruitlessly hunting for Mr Montesinos ever since he returned to Peru from a failed attempt at exile after sparking one of the country's biggest corruption scandals.

fields.headline: Fortress Europe confronts the unthinkable
fields.standfirst: Patricia Hewitt, the e-commerce minister, is in India this week to boost Britain's links with the hi-tech industry there, as the UN warns of a demographic crisis facing Europe unless immigration is substantially increased
fields.trailText: A huge decision is confronting Europe. If living standards are not to fall, EU countries may have to allow a 60-fold rise in immigration, feeding rightwing protests and causing additional damage to the region's fragile race relations. This is the considered view of demographic experts as they examine the reality of Europe's ageing population. Since parents are having fewer children and the old are living longer, the size of the economically active workforce supporting those over 65 is falling dramatically.
fields.body:
A huge decision is confronting Europe. If living standards are not to fall, EU countries may have to allow a 60-fold rise in immigration, feeding rightwing protests and causing additional damage to the region's fragile race relations. This is the considered view of demographic experts as they examine the reality of Europe's ageing population. Since parents are having fewer children and the old are living longer, the size of the economically active workforce supporting those over 65 is falling dramatically.

Who will keep the economy running and look after the growing army of the elderly? One option is to raise the retirement age to 75, but most people do not want to work longer. A more feasible plan is to accept more immigrants. But while this is beginning to happen, no EU government seems willing to admit that it is part of a historic new trend.

This summer Germany dropped its long-standing barriers to immigration to take in computer programmers from developing countries. It described the decision as temporary. Britain, where nearly a third of doctors are foreign-born, has radically relaxed its immigration rules to make it easier for skilled people to come from outside the EU. There was no public announcement.

To describe the choice for Europe as "grey power or black power" may be exaggerating. But even with the EU's enlargement to eastern Europe, the biggest source of potential immigration is the third world, mainly Africa and Asia.

Affluent

Mediterranean countries which used to send migrants northwards have become affluent enough to keep their own people. Hundreds of young Portuguese used to work in Paris as concierges but their children are going back to a booming Portugal. Spain has ceased to be a labour exporter, partly because of a sharp fall in its birth rate. "In one generation we have gone from being a society in which families of eight or even 12 children were not unusual to one in which childless couples are common, or people think long and hard about having a second child", said a Madrid sociologist, Victor Perez Diaz.

Immigration from developing countries has already produced social tension in most European states and tabloid headlines about a "flood" of foreigners.

It is not just a matter of skinheads murdering foreigners in Germany or beating up Asian bus conductors in Britain. Cardinal Giacomo Biff of Bologna recently shocked Italians by calling for immigration to be restricted to Roman Catholics to save "the nation's identity", pointing out that Muslims had "different food, festivals and family morals".

Yet behind the racist sensationalism there are serious issues. Has the public been given a chance to debate the situation, or has it been foisted on them by politicians afraid to discuss the pros and cons? The rise of ultra-rightwing parties in many states appears to be caused not just by immigration but by a sense that the establishment has not been honest.

The cautious effort to reopen the debate was sparked by a UN population division study this year. It found that by 2050 a quarter of Britain's population would be over 65. The figures were similar for France and Germany, and in Italy it will be a third.

In most European countries there has been a sharp decline in the potential support ratio (PSR), defined as the ratio of the population aged between 15 and 64 to that aged 65 andover. In Britain it was 6.24 people of working age to every pensioner in 1950 and had fallen to 4.08 this year. Assuming zero immigration after 1995, it would be 2.36 workers to every pensioner by 2050.

In Italy there were almost eight people of working age for every pensioner in 1950 but fewer than four today. By 2050, with no immigration, the ratio will be down to 1.52. Italy has moved faster than almost any other EU country from a norm where couples often had eight or nine children to one where many couples have one child or remain childless.

There is little chance that European birth rates will rise, so the UN made a number of projections about how to deal with the "demographic deficit". It calculated how many immigrants would be needed to maintain the size of the working-age population (15 to 64 years) at the same level in 2050 as it is today.

For Britain it found that an annual in take of 125,000 immigrants would be needed until 2050. This is almost double the average of 73,000 migrants a year from 1990 to 1998.

To maintain the current PSR until 2050, Britain would need a net immigration total of more than 1m migrants a year. If this happened the overall population would reach 136m by the mid-century, of whom 80m, or roughly 59%, would be post-1995 migrants or their descendants.

For Germany, 3.4m migrants would be needed every year to keep the workforce in the same proportion to the elderly as it is today. By 2050, 80% of the population would be foreigners or their descendants.

Controversial

No wonder that when European home affairs ministers discussed the issue of "replacement migration" for the first time this summer, it sparked fierce controversy. Jean-Pierre Chevènement, the then French interior minister, denounced it as an employers' tool to try to depress wages. If it were to happen, Europe should understand the implications and be prepared to become a racially hybrid society. "Public opinion must be told clearly that Europe, a land of immigration, will become a place where cross-fertilisation occurs," said a document prepared by the French presidency. "Public opinion needs to be enlightened and convinced."

Mr Chevènement favoured bringing in seasonal workers temporarily through contracts with their home governments which would require them to go back after a fixed period. But the immigrants who are needed in most of Europe are those with skills, and they will not come without the prospect of citizenship.

European governments may have to move to a quota system, like the US or Canada, which would favour skilled people from different countries, or set "points" for migrants depending on their qualifications or whether they have family links with earlier immigrants.

Another solution is to get people to work longer. For Britain to retain the same PSR as it has today would mean lifting the retirement age to 72. In practice, most countries are likely to use a mixture of approaches, by opening the door to migration, changing the pensions system, and encouraging those who want to stay at work after 65.

As Antonio Vitorino, the EU's dynamic Portuguese commissioner for justice and home affairs, told European ministers this summer, fortress Europe cannot go on. "The policy of zero immigration of the last quarter-century is no longer feasible."

'I miss my family a lot'

Kader, 30, from Algeria, works in a cafe in the racially mixed 10th arrondissement of Paris

"I came here almost exactly one year ago. I came because I wanted a change from my home country, to see different things, and because life in Algeria is difficult.

"There is a difficult political situation always, and often the risk of being caught up in a terrorist attack.

"So I wanted change, but it was hard to make the decision. I did not want very much to leave my parents, my brothers and sisters and my old friends - and I miss them and my family a lot. I also miss the things in daily life that tell you you're in your home country, the familiar little things you're comfortable with, the weather.

"But that is normal, of course, and it is important to be able to adapt to new situations. And France has been good for me so far. I like it here, I like the area I live and work in, I earn OK money, the people are friendly. Life here is good. For the moment I have no regrets."

'I've tried to adapt here'

Shahadat, from Bangladesh, owns a late-night convenience store in Brussels

"I came to Belgium in 1996 because of my wife, whose family moved here in the 1970s. Our marriage was arranged - we had two days to get to know each other.

"I'm happy here now. I was a bit depressed at first because of the difficulty of adapting to a new language but my wife has helped me learn French.

"Since I arrived I have taken courses in computing and running a small business. They don't accept my qualifications here so I can't get a good job. If I want to work it has to be washing dishes or cars. I tried this but this was embarrassing for me so I decided to start my own business.

"If I've had any problems with racism here it's been with foreigners and not with Belgians. Moroccans come into my shop and call me a Paki.

"I have tried to adapt here. I've never been unemployed or drawn social security and I pay tax to the government."

 Additional reporting by Jon Henley in Paris, Rory Carroll in Rome, Adela Gooch in Madrid and Tony Paterson in Berlin

Cardinal Giacomo Biff of Bologna recently shocked Italians by calling for immigration to be restricted to Roman Catholics to save "the nation's identity", pointing out that Muslims had "different food, festivals and family morals". Yet behind the racist sensationalism there are serious issues. Has the public been given a chance to debate the situation, or has it been foisted on them by politicians afraid to discuss the pros and cons? The rise of ultra-rightwing parties in many states appears to be caused not just by immigration but by a sense that the establishment has not been honest. The cautious effort to reopen the debate was sparked by a UN population division study this year. It found that by 2050 a quarter of Britain's population would be over 65. The figures were similar for France and Germany, and in Italy it will be a third. In most European countries there has been a sharp decline in the potential support ratio (PSR), defined as the ratio of the population aged between 15 and 64 to that aged 65 andover. In Britain it was 6.24 people of working age to every pensioner in 1950 and had fallen to 4.08 this year. Assuming zero immigration after 1995, it would be 2.36 workers to every pensioner by 2050. In Italy there were almost eight people of working age for every pensioner in 1950 but fewer than four today. By 2050, with no immigration, the ratio will be down to 1.52. Italy has moved faster than almost any other EU country from a norm where couples often had eight or nine children to one where many couples have one child or remain childless. There is little chance that European birth rates will rise, so the UN made a number of projections about how to deal with the "demographic deficit". It calculated how many immigrants would be needed to maintain the size of the working-age population (15 to 64 years) at the same level in 2050 as it is today. For Britain it found that an annual in take of 125,000 immigrants would be needed until 2050. This is almost double the average of 73,000 migrants a year from 1990 to 1998. To maintain the current PSR until 2050, Britain would need a net immigration total of more than 1m migrants a year. If this happened the overall population would reach 136m by the mid-century, of whom 80m, or roughly 59%, would be post-1995 migrants or their descendants. For Germany, 3.4m migrants would be needed every year to keep the workforce in the same proportion to the elderly as it is today. By 2050, 80% of the population would be foreigners or their descendants. Controversial No wonder that when European home affairs ministers discussed the issue of "replacement migration" for the first time this summer, it sparked fierce controversy. Jean-Pierre Chevènement, the then French interior minister, denounced it as an employers' tool to try to depress wages. If it were to happen, Europe should understand the implications and be prepared to become a racially hybrid society. "Public opinion must be told clearly that Europe, a land of immigration, will become a place where cross-fertilisation occurs," said a document prepared by the French presidency. "Public opinion needs to be enlightened and convinced." Mr Chevènement favoured bringing in seasonal workers temporarily through contracts with their home governments which would require them to go back after a fixed period. But the immigrants who are needed in most of Europe are those with skills, and they will not come without the prospect of citizenship. European governments may have to move to a quota system, like the US or Canada, which would favour skilled people from different countries, or set "points" for migrants depending on their qualifications or whether they have family links with earlier immigrants. Another solution is to get people to work longer. For Britain to retain the same PSR as it has today would mean lifting the retirement age to 72. In practice, most countries are likely to use a mixture of approaches, by opening the door to migration, changing the pensions system, and encouraging those who want to stay at work after 65. As Antonio Vitorino, the EU's dynamic Portuguese commissioner for justice and home affairs, told European ministers this summer, fortress Europe cannot go on. "The policy of zero immigration of the last quarter-century is no longer feasible." 'I miss my family a lot' Kader, 30, from Algeria, works in a cafe in the racially mixed 10th arrondissement of Paris "I came here almost exactly one year ago. I came because I wanted a change from my home country, to see different things, and because life in Algeria is difficult. "There is a difficult political situation always, and often the risk of being caught up in a terrorist attack. "So I wanted change, but it was hard to make the decision. I did not want very much to leave my parents, my brothers and sisters and my old friends - and I miss them and my family a lot. I also miss the things in daily life that tell you you're in your home country, the familiar little things you're comfortable with, the weather. "But that is normal, of course, and it is important to be able to adapt to new situations. And France has been good for me so far. I like it here, I like the area I live and work in, I earn OK money, the people are friendly. Life here is good. For the moment I have no regrets." 'I've tried to adapt here' Shahadat, from Bangladesh, owns a late-night convenience store in Brussels "I came to Belgium in 1996 because of my wife, whose family moved here in the 1970s. Our marriage was arranged - we had two days to get to know each other. "I'm happy here now. I was a bit depressed at first because of the difficulty of adapting to a new language but my wife has helped me learn French. "Since I arrived I have taken courses in computing and running a small business. They don't accept my qualifications here so I can't get a good job. If I want to work it has to be washing dishes or cars. I tried this but this was embarrassing for me so I decided to start my own business. "If I've had any problems with racism here it's been with foreigners and not with Belgians. Moroccans come into my shop and call me a Paki. "I have tried to adapt here. I've never been unemployed or drawn social security and I pay tax to the government."  Additional reporting by Jon Henley in Paris, Rory Carroll in Rome, Adela Gooch in Madrid and Tony Paterson in Berlin Tomorrow: Will Germany's plan to bring in thousands of Indian computer experts work? And where does that leave India?

webTitle: High fliers get first-class welcome but unskilled stay grounded

fields.headline: High fliers get first-class welcome but unskilled stay grounded
fields.standfirst: More visas as hi-tech firms snap up India's best brains
fields.trailText: While the most familiar image of the would-be migrant to the US may be that of the impoverished central American trying to slip over the border by moonlight, a new breed will be arriving first-class at the airports of big American cities.
fields.body:
While the most familiar image of the would-be migrant to the US may be that of the impoverished central American trying to slip over the border by moonlight, a new breed will be arriving first-class at the airports of big American cities.

Techno-migrants with all the necessary skills of the new technology are being actively courted and this month their path into the US has this month been smoothed by the president himself. They arrive at a time when the percentage of immigrants in the workforce is at its highest since the 1930s.

Earlier this month Bill Clinton signed into law legislation to increase the annual quota of H-1B visas available for skilled foreign workers from 115,000 to 195,000 over the next three years. The law came after pressure from technology companies worried by the shortage of qualified workers and anxious to snap up the cream of foreign brainpower, particularly from India.

The US has been attracted by the talented graduates of the Indian institutes of technology set up by Nehru in the 1950s. At the other end of the scale, the presence of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from central America provides a cheap and compliant labour pool for the service industries and allows companies to keep their overheads low.

"My administration has made clear that any increase in H-1B visas should be temporary and limited in number," Mr Clinton said. He added that the fee charged to employers for each visa should be increased significantly [to $1,000] and that most of the money generated should go to "fund training for US workers seeking the necessary skills for these jobs". It is estimated that the extra visas will raise $170m for training Americans.

What the legislation does not address is the position of a large number of immigrants who are either illegal or of uncertain status. Mr Clinton was unable to persuade the Republicans to extend the immigration largesse to those who do not have specific technical skills, and he has expressed his regret. "We need to meet the needs of the hi-tech industry by raising the number of visas for temporary hi-tech workers," he said. "But we also must ensure fairness for immigrants who have been in this country for years, working hard and paying taxes."

This is a tacit acknowledgement of the essential part played by immigrants, legal and illegal, in the US economy. According to the bureau of labour statistics, there are now 15.7m immigrants in the workforce, around 5m of them illegal. They amount to 12% of the workforce, a rise of 17% in the past three years alone.

Many of the illegal immigrants work in sweatshops, as farm workers and in the service industries, sometimes for as little as $3 an hour. They are unable to complain for fear of being deported.

There are an estimated 6m illegal immigrants - this includes children and those who are not in the workforce - in the US, and an estimated 260,000 enter every year. There is now pressure, particularly from the growing Latino constituency, for an amnesty for those who have entered and settled in the US.

The latest annual figures from the immigration and naturalisation service show that 789,378 people entered the US as legal immigrants. The largest number of those entering both legally and illegally came from Mexico, of whom 146,865 had legal status.

Earlier this year the AFL-CIO trade union federation dropped its opposition to illegal undocumented labour. This is partly in recognition of the fact that many of the most active union supporters come from the Latino immigrant community, and that the worst labour abuses are in the areas in which they work. This change is seen as the harbinger of a possible amnesty.

It was 1883 when Emma Lazarus wrote the words which are inscribed as a welcome on the statue of liberty: "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses, yearning to breathe free." Were she writing today, she might be inclined to swap the tired, poor and huddled for "your wired, your computer-literate and your techno-savvy."

The less qualified will still have to wait their turn.

fields.headline: Women 'falling through tax gap'
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown was yesterday urged to do more for women as a report warned they were "falling through the gaps" in a tax and benefit system that was based on an outdated view of the nuclear family.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown was yesterday urged to do more for women as a report warned they were "falling through the gaps" in a tax and benefit system that was based on an outdated view of the nuclear family.

Harriet Harman MP called on the government to treat the report by the Fawcett Society "very seriously indeed" ahead of the chancellor's pre-budget report, expected a week tomorrow.

"There is no doubt the system Labour inherited was based on outdated assumptions about men being the breadwinner and women looking after the children - assumptions which are long out of date," said the former social security secretary. "It is going to be a major task to modernise it. The government has done a lot but there is a great deal more to be done."

The report, Delivering for Women? The Next Steps, highlights failings in policy and suggests alterations that could be accommodated in the next budget, or in the maternity rights review expected by the end of next month.

It argues that 1.4m "economically inactive" women would like to get back to work but are unable to do so because, due to their partner working or gaining benefit on their behalf, they are ineligible for the new deal schemes.

The working families tax credit, while helping lone parents, also discourages mothers with working partners to return to work, leading many women to a lifetime of low individual incomes.

The state second pension, while including a number of "women friendly features", is not offered to women who earn less than £61 a week - affecting up to one in six women. Also, the pension, based on the male pattern of working for 49 years continuously, penalises women, with even those with a full basic state pension and state second pension receiving less than the minimum income guarantee within five years of retirement.

Rectifying many of these problems would be relatively simple, according to Mary-Ann Stephenson, the director of the Fawcett Society, which campaigns for gender equality.

The disincentives to second earners in the working family tax credit could be removed, she said, and the pensions system (already controversial) could be altered; the rules governing the new deal for the long term unemployed, which require a person to be registered unemployed for a year before being eligible for retraining, could also be loosened.

The report was described as "absolutely essential" by Ruth Kelly, Labour MP for Bolton West, who has pushed for better rights for women by campaigning for parental paid leave.

And she suggested that, with an election looming, the chancellor would be wise to take account of it. "It highlights some very significant and helpful points Labour has to address - and womens' votes are crucial to winning the next election."

The Treasury said last night: "As the [Fawcett Society] author herself points out, the government has made a commitment to delivering for women and has introduced several policies which have improved women's lives, along with other measures such as the record increase in child benefit."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Begging curb 'misguided'| Stress of flat sharing| Bowel cancer taboo| 36 mile sausage breaks record| One ticket wins £11m jackpot| Spring hope for Concorde| Ninth No 1 for Spice Girls| Hostess case man charged| Gadafy claim questions| Suicides link to Diana's death| Bombed bridge reopens
fields.body:
Begging curb 'misguided'

The government's clampdown on begging - with a £250,000 advertising campaign warning against giving to beggars in the run-up to Christmas - is fundamentally misguided, 60 social policy experts say in an open letter to Tony Blair.

Stress of flat sharing

A third of flat sharers found the experience stressful, and 15% would live alone if they had the choice, according to a survey for BBC Essentials, a website for 15-24-year-olds published today.

Bowel cancer taboo

Bowel cancer - the second biggest killer in the UK - is such a taboo subject that almost half the population would feel uncomfortable discussing symptoms with their doctor, according to a survey commissioned by Bupa to mark bowel cancer awareness day on Friday.

36 mile sausage breaks record

The world's longest sausage, measuring more than 36 miles, was completed yesterday by Hazlewood Foods in Sheffield for the Asda store chain, which will sell portions to raise money for the NSPCC's Full Stop! campaign.

One ticket wins £11m jackpot

One lottery ticket holder scooped Saturday's rollover jackpot of £11,375,130. The winning numbers were 1, 13, 14, 23, 31 and 47. The bonus was 9. Thunderball numbers 6, 8, 9, 10, 11, thunderball number 1.

Spring hope for Concorde

Concorde could be airborne again by spring next year, the Civil Aviation Authority said yesterday. The authority, British Airways and other bodies have been holding regular meetings to discuss manufacturing modifications since an Air France Concorde crashed in July shortly after leaving Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris, killing 113 people.

Ninth No 1 for Spice Girls

The Spice Girls had their ninth number one single, the double A side Holler Holler/Let love Lead the Way, their first release in two years. It went straight to the top of the charts. Only Madonna, Cliff Richard, Elvis and the Beatles have had more number one singles. The single is the first release from the Spice Girls' album Forever which is out today.

Hostess case man charged

A Japanese businessman being questioned about the disappearance of Lucie Blackman, British bar hostess working in Tokyo, has been charged with drugging and raping another hostess in 1996. Joji Obara, 48, was arrested after a complaint by a 23-year-old Canadian that she was raped after being plied with alcohol mixed with sleeping drugs.

Gadafy claim questions

David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, is to be interviewed by special branch tomorrow over his allegation that members of MI6 were involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy. He will appear in court on Thursday when his lawyers will fight an attempt to have all or part of his Official Secrets Act trial heard behind closed doors.

Suicides link to Diana's death

Suicide rates among women aged between 25 and 44 rose by 44% in the month after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997, according to research published in the British Journal of Psychiatry this week. The overall rise was 17% while the rise in women as a whole was 33%. The findings suggest her death exacerbated existing distress.

Bombed bridge reopens

Hammersmith bridge, west London, reopened yesterday after being closed since a terrorist bomb attached to a girder caused structural damage in June.

fields.headline: Moove along please
fields.standfirst: Art phenomenon hits London
fields.trailText: Anyone nursing a hangover through London early yesterday morning was not seeing things: there really were cows grazing in Westminster, and hundreds more are on the way next summer.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Anyone nursing a hangover through London early yesterday morning was not seeing things: there really were cows grazing in Westminster, and hundreds more are on the way next summer.

Cow Parade is an international public art phenomenon begun in Zurich two ago. The idea has an insane simplicity: life size cows (originally cast from pedigree Swiss animals) are decorated by artists, pastured for a few months in urban locations, and then auctioned for charity - here it will be Childline.

In Zurich the effigies were regarded as charming but not startling, since from the heart of the city real cows can be seen still, grazing on the mountains. But in US cities where they took over playgrounds, traffic islands, parking lots, and skyscrapers' roofs, they were a sensation. There have been cows painted to resemble yellow cabs, and others looking as if made of Delft tiles or as if built in red bricks; one cow leaning on a bar was entitled Looking for Mr Goodcow.

webTitle: Holy pass  'God's athlete' gives thanks for football

fields.headline: Holy pass  'God's athlete' gives thanks for football
fields.trailText: The trembling octogenarian once known as God's athlete, Pope John Paul II, inaugurated history's first papal football match yesterday with a plea for sport to keep its soul.
fields.body:
The trembling octogenarian once known as God's athlete, Pope John Paul II, inaugurated history's first papal football match yesterday with a plea for sport to keep its soul.

Players and fans at Rome's Olympic stadium bowed their heads as the former goalkeeper asked them to substitute love and integrity for racism, violence and doping. Five white doves flapped over a 70,000 crowd which for once did not make monkey noises when black players touched the ball.

The teams, Italy's national side against a selection of foreigners who play in Italy, did not spit, head-butt or roll on the ground in mock agony. They even refrained from scoring, leaving the result 0-0.

The former skier, canoeist, kayaker, swimmer and mountain-climber smiled as he watched, but leaning on a cross was as much as a body ravaged by age, disease and bullet wounds would allow.

His voice slurred by Parkinson's disease, the Pope appealed to the world of sport to transcend scandals and help banish intolerance and poverty.

"This is the appropriate time to give thanks to God for the gift of sport, in which man can exercise body, intelligence, and willpower while recognising that all these are gifts of the creator," he said.

Footballers with egos to match multimillion-pound salaries joined in a pledge to build a more fraternal, caring world of sacrifice and mutual respect. Watching but not playing was France's captain, Zinedine Zidane, football's most revered sportsman until last week when he head butted an opponent.

In a reference to doping, the Pope said the human body had to be safeguarded from "any type of attack against its integrity, from every exploitation, from every idolatry". The year 2000 should mark an examination of conscience.

Celebrating mass before the exhibition match, the 80-year-old pontiff recalled his days punching shots from the goal of the mixed Catholic-Jewish team in his home town of Wadowice, Poland. Yesterday's match was part of the Vatican's jubilee, a celebration the Pope regards as the climax of his 22-year papacy.

Black Arsenal players pitted against Lazio in the same stadium earlier this month endured chants and insults; an overt racism that infests Italian football.

The first pope to inaugurate a match he may be, but John Paul II is believed to be only the second to publicly watch one. The first was a predecessor - it is not clear which one - who in the 15th century cheered on a savage, day-long Florentine derby from the apostolic palace. During the second world war, the Vatican had its own league.

The first pope to inaugurate a match he may be, but John Paul II is believed to be only the second to publicly watch one. The first was a predecessor - it is not clear which one - who in the 15th century cheered on a savage, day-long Florentine derby from the apostolic palace. During the second world war, the Vatican had its own league.

fields.headline: The inside track: Getting physical
fields.trailText: It is said: try everything once except incest and folk dancing. While incest remains beyond the pale, it would not be a surprise, these days, to find a management consultancy recommending team-building through morris dancing - even if your workmates are far from Royal Ballet material.
fields.body:
It is said: try everything once except incest and folk dancing. While incest remains beyond the pale, it would not be a surprise, these days, to find a management consultancy recommending team-building through morris dancing - even if your workmates are far from Royal Ballet material.

Management training has taken an artistic turn of late, with companies springing up to offer classes in acting and dancing which promise to improve company performance. This often has nothing to do with the obvious point that a professional actor is well equipped to give advice on public speaking; instead the intention is to release such nebulous psychological forces as "creativity".

The origin of offbeat training for managers lies in the outdoor adventure courses in mountaineering, canoeing and survival used by corporations, and some government departments, for more than 30 years. Although such capers have no direct connection with office life, they are based on techniques developed by the armed forces to train officers in leadership, and so at least have some demonstrable benefits.

Urban myth would have it that such courses are highly risky, with managers keeling over dead from the shock of doing a day's work for a change. In fact, they have unparalleled safety records. As a rugged type who organises such things once explained to me: "Everyone knows it's dangerous, so we take safety precautions."

This is not always the case with more esoteric activities. Corporate firewalking, for example (yes, really), occasionally has predictably unpleasant consequences. There are, it seems, people who will walk barefoot over hot coals for no better reason than the fact that everyone else is doing it. And this quality apparently makes them more, rather than less, employable.

fields.headline: Just keep on dancing
fields.standfirst: Sorting out the Royal Ballet tutus is the less glamorous side of her job, Rachel Keen tells  Wendy Smith
fields.trailText: Sorting out the Royal Ballet tutus is the less glamorous side of her job, Rachel Keen tells Wendy Smith.
fields.body:
The success of Billy Elliot at the box office has added a whole new dimension to Rachel Keen's job. As PA to the director and assistant director at the west London-based Royal Ballet School, Keen has found herself with far more on her hands than taking letters and opening the post.

Since starting her job in September this year, Keen, 34, has been dealing with camera crews in the school corridors and journalists on the phone - all searching for an insight into the life of a dancer. "The film has been great at exploding the myth about dance just being something for boys from a specific background," she says. "We have 75 students here in the upper school; almost half are boys and they are from all backgrounds."

As she points out, ballet is not for the weak. "I would like to find a footballer who could lift a seven stone dancer with one hand and hold her up there in front of two thousand people." When she is not dealing with the press, Keen finds herself with a mixture of the usual, and more unusual, PA duties, such as getting the tutus dyed or entertaining international dancers. Both her bosses (director Gailene Stock and assistant director Jay Jolley) were "star dancers" before moving into education. "We really work together as a team here," says Keen. "They are both great at doing their own emails and correspondence and their time management is wonderful."

But what about the legendary "artistic temperament"? Are we talking temper tantrums before coffee? Keen is quick to defend. "They are both really good humoured," she insists. "We have a committed, dynamic and creative energy in the school that you wouldn't see in the corporate world." The school has a long and rich history. It started as the Sadler's Wells School in 1947 and the boys department came a year later in 1948. It wasn't until October 1956 that the school became known as the Royal Ballet School.

Since then the school has trained leading dancers such as Darcey Bussell, now a school governor, and Jonathan Cope, a dancer with the Royal Ballet. Picking through Keen's CV, it is plain to see that her move to the Royal Ballet School was a perfectly logical step. She spent time in a local dance school but realised quite quickly that she did not have the required flexibility to progress in dance and turned her sights to music. With an indecent number of grades in flute and piano to her name, she later took a music and dance degree at Birmingham University.

After graduating, she enrolled on a secretarial course to make herself marketable. One area she had no problems with was the keyboard. "Having trained as a pianist, the keyboard came naturally to me and I am a very fast typist," she says. After three years working in arts administration in Sydney, she spent seven years at the Royal Academy of Dancing, as PA to the chief executive and later as registrar for the Royal Academy's BA course.

Before moving to the Royal Ballet school she notched up two and a half years at College of Art and Design as PA to the dean and head of college. "At that time I really wanted to learn about education in a broader sense," she explains. But the temptation of the Royal Ballet School was not to be passed over. "I have always wanted to work in the ballet world and give back something I gained in childhood," she says.

Despite the artistic setting, her job does have the more mundane correspondence, diary and travel arrangement duties. But there's also the exceptional: "We have gala performances that we hold in the summer at the Royal Opera House and this year I'll be helping organise the Young British Dancer of the Year." The big project which is riding alongside the day-to-day running of the school is the proposed relocation to Covent Garden, to a building which will cost £15m to construct and is due to be finished by 2002. Needless to say, Keen is involved in the fundraising.

Even so, she still finds time to get out and about. "The students have performance opportunities in Swan Lake and The Nutcracker and they get to go to the rehearsals so it's great when the invitation is extended to the staff." She may also find herself visiting dance venues, sorting out seating plans or picking up a visa.

But what she really appreciates about her job is something that is fed into her office every day. "One of the wonderful aspects is the music and the sound of the piano playing. I go home with the repertoires singing in my ears."

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 9.Business language
fields.trailText: 9.Business language
fields.body:
Why is it that your attempts to join in board-level discussions are greeted with a patronising smile and a firmly closed door? Don't they appreciate what you have to contribute? Maybe not - but have you considered the possibility that it might be your fault?

* Like it or not, if you want to be accepted at senior level you have to talk the talk. If you've set your sights on joining the executive club, you need to get fluent in business-speak. This doesn't mean transforming yourself into a jargon-spouting automaton, but apposite nuggets dropped strategically into your conversation will help you to be taken more seriously.

* Begin by scrutinising your speech. Women tend to use emotional vocabulary, which can cloud your message. Try to replace the touchy-feely words such as "like", "love", "hate" and "touchy-feely". Find a more businesslike way to express your ideas. Don't say, "I don't think the guys in IT are going to like being moved to the fourth floor". Try, "I'm concerned that the IT team may not function as well on the fourth floor".

* Clear out all the obscuring fluff from your sentences. Drop words such as "just", "maybe", "perhaps", and never put "-y" or "-ish" on the end of your words. Why? Because they just make you sound sort of uncertain-ish, which doesn't go down well in business-y circles. (See what I mean?)

* Listen to senior executives. When did your managing director last say, "I really think it would be nice if we could find some money from somewhere, otherwise we're in trouble"? It would more likely be, "Sourcing new revenue streams is key if we're to maintain our current trading position". You don't have to go that far, but you do need to think about how you express your thoughts in the business arena. Jot down management's "in" words and try to use them. For example, if everything is "key" in your firm at the moment, make it your favourite adjective too. (But beware of over-use: it's not "key" that you get to lunch on time, nor is it "key" to phone your mum).

* Read around the business world. You don't have to absorb the Economist from cover to cover, but a regular browse of the business pages will help you to see who and what is making the news. Pick up the terms, check the definitions, and use them.

* Immediate buy-in to the project is vital to bringing the desired outcome to your key objective. (Which, roughly translated, means: do it now, if you want to succeed.)

fields.headline: WPM
fields.standfirst: Wednesday, dear readers, is National Stress Awareness Day, sponsored by Royal and Sun Alliance
fields.trailText: Wednesday, dear readers, is National Stress Awareness Day, sponsored by Royal and Sun Alliance
fields.body:
Wednesday, dear readers, is National Stress Awareness Day, sponsored by Royal and Sun Alliance whose website - www.howtomanagestress.co.uk - was WPM's site of the week a matter of weeks ago. For those who ignored her recommendation and who consequently remain unaware of stress, let WPM explain.

Stress, it appears, is a condition that affects literally lots of office workers. Some, it is said, find the efforts of carrying their workload so draining that they resort to relieving the strain through unorthodox practices, rarely to be seen in the more serene office environments, such as swearing, throwing polystyrene cups across desks and, in some very extreme cases, assaulting colleagues with rolled-up fax cover sheets. So this week, instead of forcing such tiresome workmates into headlocks and locking them in a toilet cubicle until they calm down, be aware that they might well be suffering from stress. Best point them in the direction of a website. It will be more tolerant than you of their griping. WPM, of course, manages to spare her colleagues the excesses of her moaning by relieving herself of all her stresses and grievances through this column. As she's sure you're aware.

* Bosses who think that there's no problems with stress in their firm should be aware that their employees are consummate liars. When questioned by mental health charity Mind about absences from work caused by stress, 27% of workers admitted that they would rather fabricate a purely physical reason for taking time off than tell their boss that they were suffering from stress. However, as 61% of people now cite stress in the workplace as the number one cause of mental illness, maybe it's unsurprising that the afflicted would rather confess to a hangover than to feeling under pressure.

* Secretaries are often charged with making business travel arrangements for bosses who can't figure out for themselves how to get from London to Frankfurt. They are also often blamed if tickets go astray, planes are cancelled, hotels are double-booked or they forget to request a room with an executive trouser press or the correct fluffiness of the complimentary bathrobe.

What can you do? Well, not much really. But you can stop your boss from being arrested or killed by not sending him or her to global danger-spots, which is bound to earn you brownie points back in the office (with the boss, if not the rest of the staff). www.hrworldclass.com launched in the summer, and the site has now added a survival manual (the full monty will, however, cost you; details online) with advice on how to avoid some of the world's less pleasant stop-overs. Lebanon and Bolivia are not ideal places to organise your firm's international conference, for example. But there are also some less obvious hints, such as making sure it's not monsoon season and booking a room between the third and eighth floors (fire engine ladders often don't reach above the eighth storey, and robbers are generally too lazy to bother sniffing around those higher levels).

And you can thwart the vanity of your jetsetting boss by pointing out that company logos on luggage are a big no-no - you might as well paint a huge target on your suitcase (well, at least it would match the imaginary one you've got pinned to their back ...)

* The feelgood factor is all very well, but sometimes it pays to think negatively. What with all those dot.coms going bust, it seems a shame to waste money on, say, office space when all it'll be used for in the end is exit interviews and sacked staff crying in the toilets. If that sounds like your idea of a business plan, then Corpnex, a bright-spark property company based in Mayfair, has hit on the perfect solution.

If you think your new company is likely to hit the rocks within a matter of weeks, then why not rent one of their offices for just three months. It does cost rather a lot, of course, but then your dot.com venture wouldn't be a real dot.com venture if it didn't spend its early life haemorrhaging cash. Staff might wonder at their boss's lack of faith in the longevity of the business, but then again the new, 21st-century flexible workers are all for short-termism and changes of scenery. Aren't they?

webTitle: Prescott calls for fresh talks with rail chiefs

fields.headline: Prescott calls for fresh talks with rail chiefs
fields.standfirst:
Emergency repairs prolong chaos for passengers

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott has called for a second summit meeting with rail boss Gerald Corbett, Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority and the rail regulator, government sources confirmed last night.
fields.body:
John Prescott has called for a second summit meeting with rail boss Gerald Corbett, Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority and the rail regulator, government sources confirmed last night.

As the emergency repair blitz continued to wreak havoc across the rail network, concern about Railtrack's management of the crisis was understood to be increasing among ministers.

Ministerial sources said yesterday the company had been given a last chance to prove it could put its own house in order and was now facing a race against time to provide clear indications that the national situation was improving.

It is understood the deputy prime minister, who has refused to give his backing to Railtrack's chief executive, will demand a full report on the progress of the national recovery plan when he meets Mr Corbett on Thursday.

There was also speculation among industry insiders last night that Railtrack could risk having its licence revoked if it failed to deliver significant changes.

A spokeswoman for the rail regulator said: "It would be possible for us to recommend this to the secretary of state but the decision would have to be his own. He is the only person who has the power to revoke the licence."

She added: "It is not something we are thinking of at the moment."

Meanwhile, as fears about the safety of the rail network rose, Railtrack launched an investigation into claims that an internal memo issued by a sub-contractor ordered workers not to cut out faulty sections of track because they were "not practical or cost effective" to fix.

The memo, leaked to the News of the World, allegedly shows GT Maintenance - which looks after 20,000 miles of track - was aware of crucial defects in the network and told safety managers to take out serious faults "only if they have the resources to do so".

Railtrack said it was concerned about the allegations highlighted in the letter and had immediately launched an investigation.

The company also confirmed that the urgent track inspections triggered by the Hatfield crash, which claimed four lives on October 17, were expected to be finished by midnight tomorrow.

Mr Corbett visited the crash site last night. He said: "It [the work] has severely affected passengers for which we truly apologise. It has been a dreadful week for passengers but they can rest assured that the railway is safe. This weekend I think we've turned the corner."

Passengers endured a weekend of disruption and delays as more than 20,000 people worked around the clock to investigate the incidence of "gauge corner cracking" and lay almost 25 miles of rail at 160 sites across the country.

Anthony Smith, national director of the Rail Passengers Council, said last night: "Every region has been affected, with some worse than others.

"Scotland and the north are less disrupted while the east coast mainline, Clapham Junction, South Wales and the Bristol area are terribly snarled up."

Further travel chaos was expected today as the biggest work programme on the railways for more than 100 years continued.

Mr Smith said: "The original predictions of it being over by Wednesday now appear optimistic and it's going to carry on for 10 days, two weeks, or longer."

One train company advised passengers to avoid using trains altogether as the crisis reached its peak yesterday.

Kevin Johnson, spokesman for Midland Mainline, which operates between London and Sheffield via the east Midlands, said yesterday: "It has been bad during the week and we have been told the disruption is going to last for at least two weeks, but today I would suggest people do not travel at all."

A Railtrack spokeswoman said the situation would become much clearer by Wednesday when the track inspections were completed: "The future depends on what we find when we have completed our inspections. We will have identified the sites where there is a need for track to be replaced and we will then have an idea of the scale of the job," she said.

She confirmed the network would be "stabilised" by today, when 10% to 15% of speed restrictions would be lifted and an emergency timetable brought into force. She added delays were inevitable. "Obviously there will still be speed restrictions in place. It is going to be one or two months before this is all over."

Meanwhile it emerged that the lack of highly skilled engineers in Britain has forced some firms to spend hundreds of thousands of pounds in an overseas drive to gain much-needed expertise from other countries.

Glasgow-based firm First Engineering, which is contracted to carry out engineering work on behalf of Railtrack, yesterday confirmed that it had hired 14 engineers from Romania to help rebuild Britain's crisis-hit rail network.

The engineers, who have all studied for six years at university in their home country, will begin work on signalling systems across the rail network. The are expected to start in Scotland and north-west England next year.

Kevin Johnson, spokesman for Midland Mainline, which operates between London and Sheffield via the east Midlands, said yesterday: "It has been bad during the week and we have been told the disruption is going to last for at least two weeks, but today I would suggest people do not travel at all." A Railtrack spokeswoman said the situation would become much clearer by Wednesday when the track inspections were completed: "The future depends on what we find when we have completed our inspections. We will have identified the sites where there is a need for track to be replaced and we will then have an idea of the scale of the job," she said. She confirmed the network would be "stabilised" by today, when 10% to 15% of speed restrictions would be lifted and an emergency timetable brought into force. She added delays were inevitable. "Obviously there will still be speed restrictions in place. It is going to be one or two months before this is all over." Meanwhile it emerged that the lack of highly skilled engineers in Britain has forced some firms to spend hundreds of thousands of pounds in an overseas drive to gain much-needed expertise from other countries. Glasgow-based firm First Engineering, which is contracted to carry out engineering work on behalf of Railtrack, yesterday confirmed that it had hired 14 engineers from Romania to help rebuild Britain's crisis-hit rail network. The engineers, who have all studied for six years at university in their home country, will begin work on signalling systems across the rail network. The are expected to start in Scotland and north-west England next year.

webTitle: NHS scheme to recycle patients' own blood

fields.headline: NHS scheme to recycle patients' own blood
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Up to 20% of all blood used in hospital operations may soon be recycled from patients themselves, to help combat blood shortages and allay fears of the human form of BSE contaminating transfusions.
fields.body:
Up to 20% of all blood used in hospital operations may soon be recycled from patients themselves, to help combat blood shortages and allay fears of the human form of BSE contaminating transfusions.

NHS officials and doctors will have to persuade hospitals to invest in the technology that makes the procedure possible. This involves equipment that sucks blood lost in operations into a container before forcing it through a centrifuge that separates and cleans the vital red blood cells and then transfers them into a bag ready for transfusion back to the patient.

Only about 10% of major hospitals are thought to have access to such equipment at the moment and this and other self-donating procedures are thought to account for under 2% of all blood used in operations in Britain. Experts in the field believe this could be increased 10-fold, including in cardiac and vascular surgery, orthopaedic procedures and genito-urinary operations.

They believe the present system of voluntary public donations is safer than it has ever been but it is not enough and alternatives must be made more available.

The Department of Health is anxious to develop the recycling options much further, as well as extending opportunities for patients who wish to donate their own blood in the weeks before operations.

But this "pre-deposit" scheme, already on offer at some blood transfusion centres, can be expensive, difficult to organise and wasteful if the patients' operations have to be cancelled.

Low-key discussion on the techniques, some of which are said to improve markedly the quality of blood given to patients and help reduce demand on donated blood supplies, has been under way for years. However, higher costs and disagreements over the health benefits and economic justification for changes have made progress slow.

But the continuing unease that using transfusions from unwitting carriers of the human form of BSE might infect patients with variant CJD has kickstarted the whole debate once more.

The government has already recognised the theoretical risk and introduced a series of control measures, including removal of white blood cells and a ban on British-sourced plasma products.

Last month, however, it was revealed that a BSE-like disease had been spread by blood transfusion between two sheep and the government is anxious to make contingency plans, especially since a test to detect vCJD in blood is unlikely to be available in the near future.

The Department of Health has commissioned an audit on how many NHS trusts have followed up a 1998 circular encouraging wider use of so-called autologous blood donation.

It said yesterday: "The results of the audit should be available before the end of the financial year. They will allow us to provide further advice and support to NHS blood services."

Tim Wallington, medical spokesman for the national blood service, said: "The most important thing is to ensure blood is used properly, not because it is dangerous, but because it is scarce and valuable.

"There is a big effort to improve practice going on. We can be proud of that. But there is a real concern not to overplay it so as not to frighten people too much. There is a duty also to get it right."

Michael Thomas, a spokesman for the autologous group of the British Blood Transfusion Society, said: "To raise public expectations before the facilities [for recycling blood] are there is unethical. It is not something that is going to happen overnight.

He added: "There are new techniques to be learnt, equipment to be bought or leased, people to be trained and standard operating procedures to be learnt."

But Michael Desmond, consultant anaesthetist at the Cardiothoracic Centre in Liverpool, said: "We are not talking about the latest toys here. We are talking about techniques that have been around 25 years or more and perfected elsewhere in the world."

Another enthusiast said donated blood was probably safer than it had ever been. "But no one knows how big an issue vCJD is. You can see why people are scared about it."

fields.headline: Fatigue 'costs NHS £633m a year'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A collective case of fatigue brought on by the rigours of modern life is sweeping the nation and costing a small fortune, it was claimed today.
fields.body:
A collective case of fatigue brought on by the rigours of modern life is sweeping the nation and costing a small fortune, it was claimed today.

The number of burned out, miserable people who go to the doctor complaining of exhaustion is reaching epidemic proportions and costing the NHS more than £633m every year, according to research by the vitamin supplement maker Supradyn Recharge.

The survey of 200 doctors found that one in 10 patients they saw each week had "run out of steam".

Sixty-seven of the doctors had seen a 50% increase in people aged 26 to 35 who felt low on energy in the past couple of years. Many young people said they were so tired that they had no energy for anything other than sleep.

Doctors are braced for a deluge of similar cases as the nights draw in leaving people more susceptible to feeling rundown and depressed.

With each GP consultation costing the NHS £20 and the number of people feeling under the weather increasing so rapidly, there are fears the multi-million pound bill will rise significantly.

The study said the lethargy was causing concern among health professionals, who blamed lack of sleep, being unfit and poor diet. There was a warning against bingeing on chocolate and coffee to raise energy levels.

The most common reasons for the malaise were found to be the pressure of juggling work and personal lives, having to work longer hours because of pressure to succeed, and hectic social lives.

Exhausted patients were concerned about their irritability because it affected their relationships, quality of life and work.

As well as eating better, resting more and exercising often, other ways offered by the study to banish the blues included more sex and sunshine, a ban on television and adding anti-depressants to the water supply.

webTitle: Arthritis is beaten, UK team hopes

fields.headline: Arthritis is beaten, UK team hopes
fields.standfirst: Early drugs trials give exciting results, doctors say
fields.trailText: British scientists say they have a radical treatment that could end the pain of more than 750,000 people with rheumatoid arthritis in the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
British scientists say they have a radical treatment that could end the pain of more than 750,000 people with rheumatoid arthritis in the United Kingdom.

Researchers at University College London have identified drugs they believe give unprecedented results in stopping the debilitating disease, which is caused by the body mistakenly attacking healthy joints and tissue.

The treatment, which has been tested on 20 sufferers who had failed to respond to conventional medication, is due to be announced today at the annual meeting of the American College of Rheumatology in Philadelphia by Jonathan Edwards, leading the team at UCL.

Professor Edwards said yesterday from Philadelphia that after 18 months the first five patients - who had had the disease an average of 20 years - had only residual pain.

"They have returned to leading a more or less normal life, with one going to the gym and one taking up gardening. So far, of 20 patients only two have had no benefit at all. We have one who after two years looks as though she has got herself out of the arthritis cycle. She has had no inflammation and the rheumatoid arthritis antibodies have disappeared.

"It is early days and it is only a few patients, but the results are so much better than even I had expected that it really is quite exciting."

The next tests are due to be in progress by Christmas, with 150 patients from around the world. Arthritis charities and doctors reacted yesterday with enthusiasm tempered by caution. "The treatment is at a very early stage, but if it proves to be as good as it sounds it is tremendous news," said Richard Gutch, chief executive of Arthritis Care.

The treatment centres on B-cells - white blood cells that defend the body against viruses and bacteria by making antibodies. Due to a genetic mistake they occasionally make rogue antibodies that attack healthy tissue. The antibodies can trigger the production of copies of themselves, which the UCL team says leads to a huge self-sustained attack on joints and tissue.

"It probably takes just one genetic mistake in a lifetime to trigger this reaction but once it gets going it becomes a vicious circle," said Prof Edwards.

"Unlike with other cells in the immune system, most people can live without any B-cells for a while. By the time we reach adulthood we have already made most of the antibodies we need."

After one treatment to wipe out all the B-cells the body responds by making fresh ones. According to Prof Edwards, the chances of new B-cells making the same mistake and thereby triggering a return of rheumatoid arthritis was very small.

Anthony Clarke, medical director of the Royal National hospital for rheumatic diseases in Bath, was enthusiastic. "In broad terms the idea that you could safely take out of the inflammatory process those cells that are driving it without affecting others is very attractive. Rheumatoid arthritis is a very unpleasant condition, [and] up until now we have only been able to treat the symptoms or keep it off the boil with drugs that can have very unpleasant side effects, so this is potentially very exciting."

Dr Clarke warned that it could be two or three years before the drug was generally available. "There is no point in anyone going to their doctor tomorrow morning," he said. "It needs to be tested on a far larger group to make sure it can be used safely and without side effects. Those are the sort of things that have to be looked at carefully before it can be licensed."

Mr Gutch called on the government to make funds available if it did prove successful. "Two of the issues now will be: is it very expensive and will the drug budgets be increased so the treatment can be prescribed? We would argue it would be a good investment - enabling people to stay at work and not be on social security, as well as relieving the terrible pain and suffering."

Prof Edwards believes the therapy could help other auto-immune diseases, from multiple sclerosis to Crohn's disease. "If our explanation is right, auto-immune diseases could be like bugs in a computer programme. The solution is to turn everything off and start up afresh."

The victims of joint disorder

 More than 3 m people in the UK are significantly disabled by rheumatic diseases.

 One child in every thousand has arthritis. Around 20% of all visits to the doctor are arthritis related.

 Rheumatoid arthritis, which affects more than 750,000 people, is a common inflammatory disease of the joints.

 It is the one rheumatic disease most associated with severe physical handicap and is three times more common among females than males.

 There is currently no cure although treatments can help reduce the symptoms, but often with unpleasant side effects.

 Surgery, physiotherapy and occupational therapy can also help damaged joints work better.

 Rheumatoid arthritis costs the taxpayer more than £1.3bn a year in treatments, care and disability benefits.

fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.standfirst: Hacienda to give up its glories
fields.trailText: There is little about the derelict textile warehouse next to Manchester's Deansgate station to suggest it is any different from the scores of factories in the city that have given way to loft conversions. But when the wreckers move into the Victorian red brick building next month they will dismantle its fixtures and fittings with a reverence usually reserved for relics from an archaeological dig.
fields.body:
There is little about the derelict textile warehouse next to Manchester's Deansgate station to suggest it is any different from the scores of factories in the city that have given way to loft conversions. But when the wreckers move into the Victorian red brick building next month they will dismantle its fixtures and fittings with a reverence usually reserved for relics from an archaeological dig.

The Hacienda nightclub, birthplace of the "Madchester" scene, is to be broken up and sold. Nostalgic clubbers can own a piece of the legend, from the stage on which Madonna made her first UK appearance in 1984 to the DJ booth from which the house revolution kicked off four years later.

Such is the reverence in which the Hacienda is held, the developers are confident that everything from the dancefloor to the light fittings will be snapped up when the salvaged items are auctioned for charity next month. The most sought-after lots are likely to be the striped steel columns, but those whose memories of "the Hac" are particularly fond can even bid for the toilet doors.

"There's such a huge cultural history around the Hacienda, and many people want to own a piece of it," said Geoffrey Dickens, sales director for developers Crosby Homes, which will be overseeing the auction on November 25. It has already had a call from a pop museum in Seattle, but he expected most of the interest to come from former clubbers who remember the club's glory days, when Time magazine called it "the most famous nightclub in the world".

From its establishment in 1982 by the band New Order and a group of local music enthusiasts to its demise 15 years later, the club rode the crest of the cultural wave. Bands such as Frankie Goes to Hollywood and Culture Club played early gigs. In 1986 Mike Pickering, later of M People, played the first house record in the club. By 1988 Happy Mondays and the Stone Roses had kicked off the "summer of love" and the exuberant Madchester movement.

But not all that was new was welcome. In 1989 16-year-old Claire Leighton collapsed at the club and later died, the first ecstasy death in the UK. Despite the best efforts of its owners, the Hacienda never quite managed to shake off the drug dealers and gangs. It was forced to close in 1997, with debts of £500,000.

The broadcaster Anthony Wilson, one of the founders, said yesterday he was resolutely unsentimental about the Hacienda being demolished, and he was sanguine about the club's failure ultimately to make money or to exploit its brand. "We have a catchphrase which is, 'We didn't make money, we made history.' I suppose I would rather have made history."

webTitle: The best plagiarism scene: Bring It On

fields.headline: The best plagiarism scene: Bring It On
fields.trailText: Prize-winning cheerleaders Missy Pantone (Eliza Dushku) and Torrance Shipman (Kirsten Dunst) have visited East Compton High School to check out their rival squad, The Clovers. With horror, Torrance realises that the routine her coach Big Red has taught them has been stolen from The Clovers. As Missy and Torrance head for the parking lot, they're followed by head Clover Isis (Gabrielle Union) and her colleagues Jenelope (Natina Reed) and Lava (Shamara Fears).
fields.body:
Prize-winning cheerleaders Missy Pantone (Eliza Dushku) and Torrance Shipman (Kirsten Dunst) have visited East Compton High School to check out their rival squad, The Clovers. With horror, Torrance realises that the routine her coach Big Red has taught them has been stolen from The Clovers. As Missy and Torrance head for the parking lot, they're followed by head Clover Isis (Gabrielle Union) and her colleagues Jenelope (Natina Reed) and Lava (Shamara Fears).

"Hey," Isis bawls. "You guys enjoy the show?"

"Yeah," sneers Jenelope, "were the ethnic festivities to your liking today?"

Torrance turns, attempting to appear enthused.

"You guys are awesome."

"Really?" Isis retorts. "So, ready to share those trophies?"

Lava turns to her friends.

"Can we just beat these Buffys down so we can go home?"

"Look," stutters Missy, "there's no need for that..."

"She's right," says Isis. "Because then we'd be doing them a favour. Then they could feel good about sending Raggedy-Ann up here to jack our cheers."

"Raggedy-Ann? I don't understand."

"Ugly redhead with a video camera permanently attached to her hand. Y'all coming up here for years trying to steal our routines."

Torrance tries to apologise. The three Clovers form a semi-circle around her.

"Our free cheer service is over. As of now."

"Over."

" Finito."

See also: The Hudsucker Proxy, The Dark Horse, The Rebel

Don't see also: Weeds

Pointless trivia: Kirsten Dunst beat Christina Ricci to roles in both Interview With A Vampire and Little Women.
